(n)  Performance evaluation means a periodic written report approved by the appointing authority or designee relative to the work-related conduct and performance of the employee and which is issued in accordance with this chapter. A negative performance evaluation shall not constitute an adverse action within the meaning of this chapter. 
(o)  Probationary employee means any employee appointed to a permanent position who has not completed the required probationary period in a given class. 
(p)  Reprimand means a written report to an employee by a department head or supervisor calling attention to the employee's substandard work performance or inappropriate conduct and requiring correction of the substandard work performance or inappropriate conduct within a specified timeframe. A written reprimand shall not constitute an adverse action within the meaning of this chapter. 
(q)  Separation means termination of the employment relationship as described in Code section 4-1055. 
(r)  Suspension means the temporary removal of an employee from a position of employment with the city with or without pay. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1012. - Right to file appeal. 
(a)  Any permanent employee in the classified service of the city against whom adverse action is proposed, i.e., suspension without pay, demotion or dismissal, shall have the right to appeal the action as provided in this article. 
(b)  An employee against whom any adverse action is proposed, desiring to appeal such action shall initially appeal for a hearing before the city manager by filing notice of such appeal on or before 5:00 p.m. of the fifth business day after the employee receives notice of the proposed adverse action against him or her. The city manager shall render a written decision within five business days following such hearing. 
(c)  In the event of an appeal to the city manager by an employee against whom an adverse action is proposed, the withholding of wages, salary or dismissal based upon the adverse action shall be abated pending a hearing before the city manager. Such abatement shall only be in effect until a decision is rendered by the city manager in accordance with this code section. 
(d)  An employee who, having first appealed a proposed adverse action to the city manager pursuant to sub-paragraph "a" of this code section, is dissatisfied with the determination of the city manager, shall have the right to appeal to the civil service board of appeals in accordance with section 4-1013. 
(e)  Unless otherwise provided, all appeals to the civil service board of appeals are entitled to a hearing which shall be conducted by a hearing officer of the civil service board of appeals pursuant to this article. However, with the written consent of all parties and the approval of the hearing officer, a hearing may be waived and the appeal considered on the written record. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1013. - Notice of appeal. 
(a)  Time for filing appeal. All employee appeals of adverse actions to the civil service board shall be initiated by filing a written notice of appeal with the city manager, in accordance with the procedures established under this article. Unless otherwise provided, the notice of appeal shall be filed with the city manager or postmarked within five business days after the later of: 
(1)  The date when the employee receives final written notice of the action or decision from the city manager or the date final notice from the city manager is delivered by certified mail to the employee's last-known address. 
(2)  The effective date of the action or decision of the city manager. 
(b)  The notice of appeal shall be considered timely if postmarked within the time allowed for an appeal but shall not be considered filed until actually received by the city manager. Untimely appeals shall be summarily dismissed by the board. 
(c)  Transmittal of copies of notice within city and assignment to hearing officer/panel. Upon receipt of the notice, the city manager shall immediately transmit a true copy of the notice to the employee's department head. The city manager shall assign the appeal for hearing by a hearing officer of the civil service board in the normal rotation of hearing officer assignments as provided in section 4-1014. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1014. - Civil service board members serving as hearing officers. 
(a)  Hearing officers. For the purposes of holding hearings on appeals and otherwise assisting in the resolution of appeals under this article, individual member of the civil service board of appeals shall serve as individual hearing officers. In a dismissal, a panel of three board members shall be convened for the purpose of hearing the dismissal. Notwithstanding any other authority and duties given to the civil service board members, as individual hearing officers they shall receive and compile evidence, prepare findings of fact, render written decisions and the basis therefore, certify records and make investigations of matters under the jurisdiction of this article where a review is appropriate. 
(b)  Assignment of hearing officers to appeals. Upon appointment to the civil service board, the appointee's name shall be placed in the alphabetical listing of civil service board members for the purpose of being assigned appeals as scheduled by the city manager. Appeals will be assigned according to hearing officers in a continual alphabetical rotation of names. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1015. - Authority and duties of hearing officers/panels. 
Any duly appointing hearing officer/panel shall have the authority to do the following in connection with any hearing under this article: 
(a)  Administer oaths and affirmations to witnesses appearing before the board. 
(b)  Regulate the course of the hearing. 
(c)  Set the time and place for continued hearings and prehearing conferences, which shall be in a location owned or operated by the city. 
(d)  Fix the time for filing written arguments as deemed appropriate. 
(e)  Dispose of motions to dismiss for lack of the board's jurisdiction over the subject matter or parties or for any other grounds. 
(f)  Dispose of motions to amend or to intervene. 
(g)  Provide for the taking of testimony by deposition or interrogatory. 
(h)  Reprimand or exclude from the hearing any person for any indecorous or improper conduct committed in the presence of the hearing officer. 
(i)  Make informal disposition of any case by stipulation, agreed settlement, consent order or default, unless such disposition is precluded by law. 
(j)  Render a final decision in writing based upon the witnesses and evidence introduced at the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1016. - Hearing procedures. 
Under this article, the following are established to provide uniform procedures for the conduct of hearings by the board or hearing officer appointed by the board: 
(a)  Notice of hearing. The hearing shall be held within thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice of appeal by the city manager. Within ten days prior to the date for which the hearing is set, the city manager shall designate, from an alphabetical rotation system, a hearing officer/panel of the civil service board and an appropriate time and place to conduct the hearing and shall so notify all parties in writing. Such notification shall be mailed or served at least ten days prior to the date for which the hearing is set. Any hearing officer/panel shall have the authority to postpone or to continue a hearing upon its own motion or upon the motion of either party. 
(b)  Representation. Opportunity shall be afforded both parties to obtain legal representation. All arrangements for providing legal counsel shall be the responsibility of the party desiring such representation. Only representatives of employee organizations recognized by the city in accordance with section 4-1024 of this code may provide non-lawyer representation to an employee. The city attorney may represent the appointing authority. 
(c)  Pre-hearing conference. The hearing officer/panel may arrange a pre-hearing conference for the purpose of reviewing the matter being appealed and establishing stipulations to expedite the hearing. 
(d)  Witnesses. The employee or the department may request the attendance of employees or other persons as witnesses when their testimony will aid in establishing the facts in the case. Employees appearing as witnesses shall be released from duty without the loss of pay or time and without effect on their service rating. No person shall directly or indirectly use or threaten to use any official authority or other influence which would tend to discourage any other person from testifying. 
(e)  Subpoenas. 
(1)  Request for subpoena. The employee, the city manager, the employee's department head, or the hearing officer/panel may request the city clerk to issue subpoenas for witnesses for hearings. The cost for securing the attendance of witnesses who are non-city employees, including fees or mileage, shall be computed and assessed in the same manner as prescribed by law for civil cases in the superior court. 
(2)  Issuance of subpoenas. Subpoenas shall be issued without discrimination between public and private parties. When a subpoena is disobeyed, any party in the matter may apply to the superior court of the county in which the hearing is being held for an order requiring obedience. Failure to comply with such order shall be cause for punishment as for contempt of court. 
(3)  Quashing or limiting subpoenas. Once issued, a subpoena may be quashed or limited by the hearing officer/panel upon the motion of the hearing officer/panel or any party or at the request of the witness, if it appears that the subpoena was used primarily as a means of harassment, that the testimony or documents sought are cumulative, that the testimony or documents sought are not relevant or material, that to respond to the subpoena would be unduly burdensome or that for other good reasons basic fairness dictates that the subpoena should not be enforced. 
(f)  Record of hearing. A certified court reported shall be engaged by the city to provide a take-down of all hearings; however, the recording of a hearing shall not be transcribed unless approved by the city manager. If the transcription is so made pursuant to a request by either party in the hearing, the cost thereof shall be borne by the party making the request. In addition to the recording of the hearing of the transcription thereof, all documents entered into the record during the hearing shall be made part of the official record of the hearing. 
(g)  Appointing authority's opportunity to be heard. At the request of the appointing authority or at the invitation of the hearing officer/panel or the board, the appointing authority or that official's designee shall be entitled to be heard and to submit evidence in any appeal in which the interpretation of a civil service rule, regulation, policy or practice is at issue. 
(h)  The chief of police may assign, and upon request by the city manager shall assign a police officer to attend all hearings of the civil service board of appeals and in all hearings the police officer in attendance at the hearing shall enforce and carry out all lawful orders of the city manager or the hearing officer/panel, and anyone violating such orders shall, upon conviction thereof in the City of East Point Court, be punished as provided for in section 1-1006 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1017. - Conduct of hearing. 
In the hearing of an appeal under this article, the proceeding shall be informal but orderly. The following procedure shall prevail: 
(a)  The hearing officer/panel shall open the hearing by explaining the procedure to be followed in the hearing. At the discretion of the hearing officer/panel, any or all witnesses may be sequestered. 
(b)  The hearing officer/panel shall read or cause to be read the charges and specifications as contained in the notice of appeal, as filed with the city manager. Any written response to the notice of appeal as filed with the city manager shall then be read. By agreement, these documents may be inserted in the record without reading. 
(c)  The facts not in dispute shall be stipulated. 
(d)  Each party shall be given the opportunity to make a brief opening statement identifying the issues and stating what is to be proven. 
(e)  All witnesses shall testify under oath or affirmation. 
(f)  Each party may conduct such examination of the witnesses as shall be required for a full and true disclosure of the facts. In addition, the hearing officer may examine the witnesses. 
(g)  Official notice may be taken of facts generally recognized by the public. In addition, official notice may be taken of technical facts within the specialized knowledge of the hearing officer. Parties shall be notified either before or during the hearing, by reference in preliminary reports or otherwise, of the material officially noted, including any staff memoranda or data, and they shall be afforded an opportunity to contest the materials so noticed. 
(h)  The hearing officer's/panel's experience, technical competence, and specialized knowledge may be utilized in the evaluation of evidence. 
(i)  Before closing the hearing, the hearing officer/panel shall allow both parties the opportunity to make brief oral or written closing statements. 
(j)  The hearing officer/panel who presided shall, within fifteen (15) days from the close of the evidence, issue a decision. However, for good cause the time may be extended for rendering a decision but in no case shall exceed an additional fifteen (15) days. The decision shall be to the city manager, the affected department head and the appealing employee, or their representatives. The hearing officer's/panel's decision shall become final, and there shall be no right to any additional administrative appeals. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Section 4-1018. - Evidence and attendance at the hearing. 
(a)  Evidence. With respect to all hearings before the board or the hearing officer/panel under this division, the following rules regarding the evidence shall govern: 
(1)  Formal, legal rules of evidence shall not be strictly applied. Evidence may be admitted if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. The hearing officer/panel shall follow the state rules of evidence regarding privileges, recognized by the law of the state. 
(2)  Irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence may be excluded. 
(3)  Objections to evidentiary offers may be made and shall be noted in the record. 
(4)  When a hearing will be expedited and the interest of the parties will not be prejudiced substantially, any part of the evidence may be received in written form, including but not limited to the use of depositions or interrogatories. 
(5)  Documentary evidence may be received in the form of copies if the original is not readily available. Upon request and at the discretion of the hearing officer/panel, parties shall be given the opportunity to compare the copy with the original document. 
(b)  Attendance at hearing. Upon the motion of either party, the hearing officer/panel may close the hearing of any appeal under this article, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 50-14-3(6), or by any federal privacy statute. An appeal file containing evidence received in a closed hearing shall not be included in a public record. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1019. - Decision of hearing officer/panel. 
(a)  Requirements of decision. As part of the final decision, the hearing officer/panel shall include findings of fact and any law on which the decision is based, separately stated, and the effective date of the decision or order. Findings of fact shall be accompanied by a concise and explicit statement of the underlying facts supporting the findings. Copies of the decision or order shall be mailed to all parties of record by the city manager. 
(b)  Finality of decision. The decision of the hearing officer/panel shall be binding on both parties. The hearing officer/panel may modify the adverse action of the appointing authority but may not increase the severity of such action on the employee. The appointing authority shall promptly comply with the final decision as may be issued as a result of the appeal. 
(c)  Relief of employee. If the decision of the hearing officer/panel is in favor of the employee on appeals of dismissal, suspension or demotion, the employee shall be reinstated in accordance with the decision to the classification from which the employee was removed. The effective date of the reinstatement shall be the date immediately following the effective date of the appealed action as if there had been no break in service, unless otherwise specified in the order. The employee shall be entitled to the same salary, with any increments in the position or salary which would have automatically inured to the employee if the employee had remained in actual service. The employee shall receive payment as if there had been no break in service, minus any amount earned by or paid to the employee from other employment and wage substitutions, including but not limited to unemployment compensation, during the period off the job and minus any amount paid the employee for annual leave. Sick and annual leave shall be restored to the employee in the same amount that existed at the time of the appealed action, plus sick and annual leave that would have been earned for the period if the employee had actually been in service. However, any period of postponement or continuance of the hearing for the convenience of the employee shall be excluded from any payment of benefits due, and this period of time shall be considered as if the employee had been on leave without pay. Prior to any payment to the employee, the employee shall certify under oath the amount of any income received from other employment and any wage substitutes received during the period off the job, which shall be deducted from the backpay owed by the city. 
(d)  The decision of the hearing officer/panel under this division shall not limit the right of either party to judicial review, and such decision shall be stayed by the filing of a petition for review. Any party, including the city or any city department, who has exhausted all administrative remedies available before the board and who is aggrieved by a final decision or order of the board on any hearing may seek judicial review of the final decision or order of the board in the superior court of Fulton County by writ of certiorari. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1020. - Dismissal of appeal. 
Upon the motion of either party or upon its own motion, the hearing officer or panel may dismiss any appeal under this division prior to holding a full hearing of the appeal upon the following conditions: 
(a)  The employee failed to exhaust administrative remedies by first appealing to the city manager as provided by section 4-1012(c); 
(b)  The appeal is clearly moot; 
(c)  The appeal is without merit; 
(d)  The appeal is untimely; 
(e)  The appeal was not properly filed with the city manager; or 
(f)  The appeal is not within the scope of the hearing officer's/panel's authority. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 3, 3-17-08)  
ARTICLE C. - PERSONNEL RULES AND REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note Article C, Personnel Rules and Regulations, is derived from the appendix to ordinance number 672-77 of November 21, 1977. It was adopted as part of that ordinance and is codified herein as a separate article at the discretion of the editors. 
 
Sec. 4-1021. - Positions covered. 
These rules and regulations cover all employees in the classified service of the city.  
Sec. 4-1022. - Administration. 
These rules shall be administered by the personnel director or his designee under the direction of the city manager and in accordance with the chapter establishing a personnel system.  
Sec. 4-1023. - Outside employment. 
No employee may engage in anv paid activity and/or employment in addition to his employment with the city unless it is approved in accordance with Code section 2-4013. 
(Ord. No. 011-09, § 2, 8-17-09)  
Sec. 4-1024. - Confidential information. 
No employee shall directly or indirectly permit any other or others to make use of confidential information acquired by virtue of employment with the city in the furtherance of any private interest.  
Sec. 4-1025. - Gifts and gratuities. 
(a)  An employee shall not accept gifts, gratuities or loans from organizations, business concerns, or individuals with whom he has official relationships by virtue of his or her capacity with the city. No employee of the city shall grant any improper favor or receive anything of service or value for the discharge of his official duties of the city from any entity. These limitations are intended to prohibit the acceptance or the granting of any thing for consideration which is not distributed or made available at the same or no cost to other members of the general public. 
(b)  It is particularly important that inspectors, contracting officers and enforcement officers refrain from relationships which might be construed as creating an interference of favoritism/coercion, unfair advantage or collusion.  
Sec. 4-1026. - Political activity. 
(a)  Employees of the city are encouraged to exercise their right to vote, but no employee shall make use of city time or equipment to aid a political candidate, political party or political cause or use a city position to persuade, coerce or intimidate any person in the interest of a political candidate, political party or political cause. 
(b)  Any employee who has qualified or seeks to qualify for any elected office shall comply with the following provisions: 
(1)  Within three (3) days of qualifying, notify the personnel director and file a statement indicating what steps the candidate will take to assure that no city time, resources or equipment will be used to assist in the campaign and what steps will be taken to meet the employee's job responsibilities if elected. 
(2)  Provide notice to the personnel director, city manager and city council of his qualification or intent to qualify and seek elective office, together with the office to which election is sought. 
(3)  Provide notice of the date the employee will take leave of absence by vacation or leave without pay in the event insufficient accumulated vacation time is available to the employee. In no event shall the date of leave of absence of such employee from employment with the city be less than forty-five (45) days preceding the date of the election or primary for which said employee is seeking election. No sick leave time will be allowed to any employee seeking elective office or participating in the political process. In the event any city employee is seeking an office should succeed to a runoff election, the leave of absence hereinabove provided shall extend through the period of time of any such runoff election or primary runoff. 
(4)  Any city employee seeking election to an elective office as part of the governing authority of the city, either mayor or city council, shall be required, upon election to such office, to resign from employment with the city effective immediately upon the date after election certification. 
(5)  In the event a city employee is elected to an office other than an elective office of the governing authority of the city, the employee shall be required to show proof satisfactory to the city manager and approval upon the city manager's recommendation by the city council showing that the employee will not be required to devote any portion of his time in his capacity as employee of the city to serve or fulfill his function and obligations by virtue of his elected position; or take leave from employment with the city (either with or without pay, depending upon availability of such leave, not including sick leave) or resign employment with the city. 
(6)  In the event a city employee is elected to an office having legislative or other regulatory powers or jurisdiction over the governing authority of the city, or an elected position with any political body or entity which, at the time of election, has any contractual relationship with the city, notwithstanding the provisions of subparagraph (b)(5) above, the employee shall be required to resign employment with the city effective as of the date of taking office or the position to which such employee is elected or in any other manner assuming the responsibilities of said elective position or office. In the event, during the interim period of time from election to taking office, the city manager is not satisfied that the employee will not be devoting any portion of his time in his capacity as an employee of the city to said elected post, the city manager, after obtaining the concurrence of the governing authority of the city, may require such employee to resign from employment with the city immediately upon such determination by the city manager with the concurrence of the governing authority of the city. The provisions hereof shall apply to any reelection of a city employee to any such office which since the initial election of such employee to such office has since established a contractual relationship with the city. 
(Ord. No. 787-82, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-82) 
Editor's note The amendments to subsections (b)(3) and (6), as enacted by Ord. No. 787-82, will become effective on approval by the federal justice department, civil rights division.  
Sec. 4-1027. - Definition of classification plan. 
The classification plan is the systematic grouping of positions into appropriate classes. 
(1)  A position is a group of current assigned duties and responsibilities requiring the full or part time employment of one person. A position may be occupied or vacant. 
(2)  A class is a group of positions (or one position) that: 
a.  Has similar duties and responsibilities; 
b.  Requires like qualifications; and 
c.  Can be equitably compensated by the same range of pay. 
(3)  The class title is the official designation or name of the class, and it shall be used on all personnel records and transactions.  
Sec. 4-1028. - Use of class specifications. 
Specifications are to be interpreted in their entirety and in relation to others in the classification plan. Particular phrases or examples are not to be isolated and treated as a full definition of a class. Specifications are descriptive and explanatory of the kind of work performed and not necessarily inclusive of all duties performed.  
Sec. 4-1029. - Maintenance of the classification plan. 
The personnel director, under the direction of the city manager, shall maintain the classification plan so that it will reflect the duties performed by each employee in the classified service. He or she shall periodically review the entire classification plan and recommend appropriate changes in allocations or in the classification plan. Reclassification shall not be abused or used to impose disciplinary action upon an employee.  
Sec. 4-1030. - Allocation of positions. 
When a new position is established, or duties of an existing position change, the department head involved shall submit in writing a position description stating the duties and responsibilities of the position. The personnel director shall investigate the actual or proposed duties and recommend to the city manager the appropriate class allocation or the establishment of a new class. The city manager then shall approve or change the recommendations and allocate the position to a class.  
Sec. 4-1031. - Allocation appeals. 
An employee who considers his position improperly classified shall submit his reclassification request, in writing, to his supervisor who shall make a recommendation to the personnel director within seven (7) days of receipt of the appeal. The personnel director shall proceed as outlined in section 4-1030 of this article.  
Sec. 4-1032. - Classification plan in effect. 
The classification plan shall be considered a part of this section and shall have the same force and effect as these personnel rules and regulations. A certified copy of the classification plan shall be maintained by the personnel director and filed with the city clerk.  
Sec. 4-1033. - Reclassification. 
(a)  In situations of reclassification to a higher grade and pay range, the employee shall be granted a pay increase equal to at least the first step of the new pay grade and in no case less than a one-pay-step increase. 
(b)  In the situation of a reclassification to a lower pay grade, the employee shall receive no salary reduction, but shall be compensated at a pay step equal to the employee's present pay, or if the new reclassified pay grade is less than the employee's present pay, the employee's pay shall remain the same until the newly reclassified pay grade exceeds the employee's present pay.  
Sec. 4-1034. - Composition of pay plan. 
The pay plan includes the adopted salary schedule and the schedule of salary ranges consisting of rates of pay for all classes of positions included in the classification plan.  
Sec. 4-1035. - Maintenance of the pay plan. 
The pay plan is intended to provide fair compensation for all classes in the classification plan, considering range of pay for other classes; rates of pay for comparable services in private and public employment in the area; the city's financial condition and policy, and other factors. The personnel director shall at least annually make or cause to be made comparative studies of all the factors affecting the level of salary ranges as appropriate.  
Sec. 4-1036. - Entrance salary. 
The minimum rate established for this class is the normal hiring rate. Appointments, under special conditions and subject to the prior approval of the city manager, may be made above the minimum rate when such action is determined to be necessary in the best interest of the city. Approval will be based on such conditions as shortage of qualified applicants available at the minimum step and qualifications of the applicant being in excess of the requests for the class.  
Sec. 4-1037. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 1180-94, § 1, adopted July 18, 1994, repealed § 4-1037 in its entirety. Former § 4-1037 pertained to promotion of employees and carried no history note.  
Sec. 4-1038. - Salary reviews. 
(a)  When funds have been specifically allocated in the budget for such purposes, and upon approval of the city manager, an annual salary increase of one step shall be granted on the service anniversary date to classified employees who have not reached the maximum step of their pay range. 
(b)  Upon the establishment of a salary review system based on standards of work performance, salary increases will be granted to individual employees that meet the standards.  
Sec. 4-1039. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 1047-93, § 1, adopted Feb. 1, 1993, repealed former section 4-1039 in its entirety which pertained to a longevity bonus for city employees and derived from the original codification.  
Sec. 4-1040. - Pay plan in force. 
The pay plan shall be considered a part of this section and have the same force and effect as these personnel rules and regulations.  
Sec. 4-1041. - Employment opportunities. 
The recruitment, selection, appointment and promotion of employees shall be in such a manner as to promote equal employment opportunity for all persons without regard to race, age, color, creed, sex, national origin, ancestry, religious affiliation, political affiliation, or disability.  
Sec. 4-1042. - Vacant positions. 
(a)  Department heads shall be responsible for notifying the personnel director of vacant, or soon to be vacant authorized positions in their department. The notification shall include the class title and salary range. The city manager shall review the information and determine whether the vacancy should be filled. 
(b)  As far as practical, vacancies shall be filled by promotion of employees of the city. All vacancies shall be announced to city employees; a vacancy announcement shall be posted for at least three (3) work days in a specified location for each department. 
(c)  In the event that an employee continues his employment as a deemed retiree, and remains in the same position as he is then employed, no vacancy occurs for such position as contemplated by this section and a vacancy announcement is not required. 
(Ord. No. 005-04, § 1, 2-16-04)  
Sec. 4-1043. - Recruitment for vacant positions. 
All full-time vacancies shall be publicized by the personnel director, by posting announcements and by other such means as necessary to assure obtaining well qualified candidates for the positions. The announcement shall specify the title and salary range of the vacant position, any minimum qualification requirements, manner of making application, the final date on which applications shall be received and other pertinent information. Every reasonable effort shall be made to publicize vacancies so that all interested persons are informed and qualified persons are attracted to compete.  
Sec. 4-1044. - Application forms. 
Application shall be made on the city application forms. The forms shall include information covering training, experience and other pertinent factors. All applications shall be signed by the person applying.  
Sec. 4-1045. - Disqualification. 
The personnel director may remove from further consideration the application of an applicant who: 
(1)  Does not meet the minimum qualifications established for the position; 
(2)  Has a health handicap that would prevent satisfactory performance of the duties of the position; 
(3)  Has made false statements of material fact or practiced deception in this application; 
(4)  Is addicted to the habitual use of drugs or intoxicating liquors; 
(5)  Has an unsatisfactory employment record of such a nature as to demonstrate unsuitability for employment; 
(6)  Has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude; or 
(7)  Has failed to submit his application within the prescribed time limit.  
Sec. 4-1046. - Selection. 
(a)  The personnel director shall review all applications for employment to determine whether the applicant meets the established standards for employment. The information may be required as is necessary to make such determination. When appropriate, examinations may be used which may be written or oral or a combination of these. The tests shall be practical in character and shall relate to the duties and responsibilities of the position for which the applicant is being examined. 
(b)  Applicants meeting the employment standards will be referred to the employing department head by the personnel director. The personnel director may reasonably limit the number of applicants referred to the department head; however, the department head may request that all applications of persons applying for the job be referred to him. The department head shall make a selection from the applicants referred and shall notify the personnel director of his recommendation as soon as he makes a decision.  
Sec. 4-1047. - Appointment. 
The city manager or personnel director shall review and either accept or reject the recommendation of the department head as to the applicant to be employed. If the applicant recommended by the department head is rejected, the department head shall make another recommendation to the city manager or personnel director. Upon the failure or refusal of the department head to make a recommendation, or another recommendation if previous recommendation is rejected, the city manager may select the person considered to be the most qualified to fill the position for employment with the city. When an applicant is selected, the city manager or personnel director shall authorize or direct an offer of employment. 
(Ord. No. 751-81, § 1, 8-17-81)  
Sec. 4-1048. - Emergency appointment. 
When an emergency involving the serious impairment of the public business makes it impossible to fill a vacant position by normal procedure, the department head, with the approval of the personnel director and the city manager, may appoint any qualified person to the position on a temporary basis in order to prevent stoppage of public business or loss, or serious inconvenience to the public. Such an appointment shall be for a period not to exceed thirty-one (31) days during which time the normal selection procedures would be followed in order to fill the position permanently.  
Sec. 4-1048.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 032-08, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 2008, repealed former § 4-1048.1 in its entirety which pertained to the employment of deemed retirees and derived from Ord. No. 005-04, § 1, adopted Feb. 16, 2004.  
Sec. 4-1049. - Employment of relatives. 
It has been determined to be in the best interest of, and is therefore the policy of the city not to employ any person in a position in which such person directly supervises, or is directly supervised by, a member of an employee's immediate family. As used herein, "immediate family" shall mean any person holding a relationship with a present employee of the city of husband, wife, son, daughter, brother or sister, and to father, mother, father-in-law, mother-in-law, sister-in-law, brother-in-law, son-in-law, or daughter-in-law. This policy applies to promotions, demotions, transfers, reinstatements and new employees. 
(1)  If two (2) employees marry while working with the city then one shall not thereafter be in a supervisory capacity over the other. If two (2) employees are married and one is in a supervisory capacity over the other or attains a supervisory position while working in the same department, one must transfer, within thirty (30) days of the date of their marriage, to another department, if both are to continue working for the city. Subject to the approval of the city manager, the two (2) employees may agree which would prefer to transfer. In the event the city manager does not approve the agreement between the two (2) employees, or the two (2) employees are not able to agree upon which should transfer, the employee with the shortest seniority in the department will be required to transfer. In the event there has been no position available for transfer at the end of the thirty (30) days, the transferring employee shall be required to take a leave of absence without pay, unless such employee has accrued vacation or compensatory time, and shall have five (5) months thereafter within which to effectuate such transfer to the first available position. If said additional five-month period expires without said transferring employee transferring to another position, all continued rights of employment shall cease. If or when said transferring employee is on a leave without pay pending transfer, all benefits of the city shall cease during the period of said leave and not recommence thereafter until such transferring employee resumes employment with the city. 
(2)  If a city institutes a reorganization which changes departmental boundaries where immediate family members would be supervising or is directly supervised by, another member of his or her immediate family, one of such employees must transfer to another department within thirty (30) days of the date of the reorganization if both are to continue working with the city. Subject to the approval of the city manager, the two (2) employees may agree which would prefer to transfer. In the event the city manager does not approve the agreement between the two (2) employees, or the two (2) employees are unable to agree upon which should transfer, the employee in the lowest pay grade in the new department will be required to transfer. If in the event there has been no position available for transfer at the end of the thirty (30) days, the transferring employee shall be transferred to any position designated by the city manager, to the highest pay grade available for such position, if such transfer results in a reduction in pay for such individual; provided, that said transferring employee's pay does not exceed the pay of an employee in the lower pay grade with like seniority of the transferring employee. Thereafter, the transferring employee may transfer to any other department in the city provided said employee may not resume a position in the department wherein an immediate family member holds a supervisory position. 
(Ord. No. 802-82, § 1, 8-16-82; Ord. No. 969-88, § 1, 8-15-88)  
Sec. 4-1050. - Objective of probationary period. 
The probationary period shall be regarded as an integral part of the selection process and shall be utilized for closely observing the employee's work, for securing the most effective adjustment of a new employee to this position and for rejecting any employee whose performance is not satisfactory. Employees serving their probationary period do not have appeal rights unless there is alleged discrimination because of political affiliation, religious affiliation, race, age, color, creed, sex, national origin, ancestry or disability. Employees who are separated from the city service prior to the completion of their probationary service shall receive no vacation pay.  
Sec. 4-1051. - Duration. 
The probationary period shall be for a minimum of six (6) months to a maximum of twelve (12) months. The length of the probationary period for each class shall be established by the personnel director with the approval of the city manager. If a department head requests an extension of an established probationary period prior to fifteen (15) days before expiration, the personnel director, with the approval of the city manager, may extend the probationary period of a particular employee up to three (3) months beyond the end of the normal probationary period.  
Sec. 4-1052. - Evaluation of performance. 
After the employee has completed one-half of his established probationary period, the department head shall report to the personnel director, in writing, his observation of the employee's work and his judgment as to whether or not the employee's services have been satisfactory. During the probationary period, the employee's supervisor will tell the employee when he is not performing satisfactorily. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the expiration of an employee's probationary period, the department head shall notify the personnel director, in writing, whether or not an employee has satisfactorily completed his probationary period.  
Sec. 4-1053. - Dismissal. 
During the probationary period, the department head may remove an employee with or without cause. The department head shall immediately report the removal to the personnel director, and to the employee and shall state his reasons. Employees serving their probationary period do not have appeal rights unless there is alleged discrimination because of political affiliation age, race, color, creed, sex, religion, national origin, ancestry or disability.  
Sec. 4-1054. - Promotional appointments. 
The probationary period shall be used in connection with promotional appointments in the same manner as it is used for entrance appointments. If an employee is removed from his position during his probationary period following a promotion, he shall be entitled to his former position.  
Sec. 4-1055. - Type of separation. 
Separations of employees from positions in the classified service shall be designated as one of the following and shall be accomplished in the manner indicated: Resignation, compulsory resignation, layoff, disability, death, retirement and dismissal.  
Sec. 4-1056. - City equipment. 
At the time of separation and prior to final payment, all records, assets and other items of city property in the employee's custody shall be transferred to his department head and certification to this effect shall be signed by the employee. Any amount due because of shortage in the above shall be withheld from the employee's final compensation.  
Sec. 4-1057. - Rights of employees. 
Employees who separate shall receive payment for all earned salary and certify compensatory time subject to deductions as outlined in section 4-1056 of this chapter, and those employees who have completed their probationary service shall also receive payment for all earned annual leave.  
Sec. 4-1058. - Resignation. 
To resign in good standing, an employee shall give notice, in writing, to his department head at least ten (10) working days prior to the effective date of his resignation. Normally, failure to comply with this rule shall be entered on the service record of the employee, and may result in a deduction from accrued vacation pay.  
Sec. 4-1059. - Compulsory resignation. 
Any employee who without valid reason fails to report to work for three (3) consecutive work days without authorized leave shall be separated from the payroll and reported as a compulsory resignation.  
Sec. 4-1060. - Layoff. 
The city manager may identify numbers of positions by job title to be vacated which will result in the layoff of an employee in the classified service when he deemed it necessary because of shortage of funds or work, or other material changes in the duties or organization or for related reasons which do not reflect discredit upon the service of the employee. When any positions so vacated are refilled within a period of two (2) years following a layoff, the persons removed therefrom, if available and able to efficiently perform the duties of such positions, shall be first entitled to be restored to the position. The layoff of employees shall be made in inverse order, on the basis of length of service in the job title. 
(Ord. No. 011-04, § 1, 4-19-04)  
Sec. 4-1061. - Disability. 
An employee may be separated for disability when he cannot perform the required duties, or when continuance on the job is a danger to himself or others. Action may be initiated by the employee at his expense, or the city at its expense, but in all cases, it must be supported by medical evidence acceptable to the city manager. An employee agrees upon request by the city, to submit to examination by a doctor of the city's choice and agrees to cooperate fully with the examination.  
Sec. 4-1062. - Death. 
When a full time employee dies while in the service of the city, all compensation due in accordance with section 4-1057 of this chapter shall be paid to the legal representative of the employee's estate or any other properly designated individual.  
Sec. 4-1063. - Retirement. 
(a)  When an employee meets the conditions of retirement set forth in the employees' retirement system, he or she may, after providing ninety (90) days' prior written notice of intent to retire, retire, and shall receive such compensation due in accordance with the provisions of sections 4-1057 and 4-1078(f) of this chapter. To the extent any employee's notice of intent to retire is less than the minimum amount prescribed above, the amount by which such employee's notice violates the above minimum time frame shall be reduced or deducted from any entitled compensation pursuant to the provisions of sections 4-1057 and 4-1078(f). 
(b)  The minimum time frames for notice of intent to retire prescribed in (a) above may be waived or reduced in the sole discretion of the city. 
(Ord. No. 837-83, § 1, 3-9-83)  
Sec. 4-1064. - Dismissal. 
The city manager may dismiss an employee for cause as outlined in section 4-1066 of this chapter. The employee shall be furnished notice of dismissal in writing, stating the reasons and the employee's right to answer the charge, and the employee's right to appeal as provided in section 4-1013 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 010-08, § 2, 3-17-08)  
Sec. 4-1065. - Types of disciplinary action. 
The following provisions shall govern disciplinary actions affecting employees in the classified service. A department head, subject to the appeal rights of the employee, shall have the following alternatives for disciplinary action: 
(1)  A department head may submit a written reprimand to an employee, when an oral warning has not resulted in the expected improvement; or when more severe initial action is warranted. Copies shall be filed with the personnel director and the city manager. 
(2)  A department head may, for cause, suspend without pay an employee in his department for up to ten (10) days. A written statement specifically setting forth reasons for suspension shall be furnished to the employee. Copies shall be filed with the personnel director and the city manager. With the prior approval of the city manager, the length of the suspension may be extended. 
(3)  With the prior approval of the city manager, a department head may reduce the salary of an employee within the range provided in the pay plan or demote the employee for cause to a lower class. A written statement of the reasons for the action shall be furnished to the employee. Copies shall be filed with the personnel director and the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 871-85, § 2, 1-22-85)  
Sec. 4-1066. - Reasons for disciplinary action. 
Listed below are some reasons which might be cause for disciplinary action referred to in section 4-1065 of this chapter, but disciplinary action is not limited to the offenses listed: 
(1)  Being convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(2)  Being absent without an excused or excusable leave; 
(3)  Excessive tardiness which is defined as that absence from work which interferes with the efficient performance of job responsibilities and work production; 
(4)  Abuse of sick leave which is defined as that absence from work which interferes with the efficient performance of job responsibilities and work production; 
(5)  Inefficient, negligent, incompetent, or total failure in performance of one's duties; 
(6)  Careless, negligent or improper use of city property or equipment; 
(7)  Willfully giving false statements to supervisors; 
(8)  Violation of city ordinances, administrative regulations or departmental rules; 
(9)  Being under the influence of alcohol or illegal drugs when reporting for work or partaking of such things while on duty, except that prescribed medication may be taken within the limits set by a physician as long as it is medically necessary; or 
(10)  Instigation of, participation in, or leadership of a strike, work stoppage, slowdown or artificial restriction of productive work.  
Sec. 4-1067. - Emergency relief from duty. 
If determined to be in the best interest of the city, a nondepartment head supervisor may relieve an employee from duty for disciplinary purposes. Relief from duty shall be only from the time the action is initiated by the supervisor until the beginning of the employee's next scheduled work period. The supervisor shall report the action and circumstance to the department head who shall review the action and initiate any further disciplinary action which may be warranted.  
Sec. 4-1068. - Policy of grievances and appeals. 
The most effective accomplishment of the work of the city requires prompt consideration and equitable adjustment of employee grievances. It is the desire of the city to adjust grievances informally and both supervisors and employees are expected to make every effort to resolve problems as they arise. However, it is recognized that there may be grievances which will be resolved only after a formal appeal and review. No employee shall be disciplined or discriminated against in any way because of use of the grievance procedure.  
Sec. 4-1069. - Definition. 
A "grievance" is a complaint made by an employee concerning the interpretation of these rules and regulations or departmental work rules or working conditions.  
Sec. 4-1070. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 010-08, § 1, adopted March 17, 2008, repealed former § 4-1070 in its entirety which pertained to appeals and derived from the following: Ord. No. 871-85, § 3, 1-22-85; Ord. No. 1181-94, § 2, 7-18-94; Ord. No. 1120-96, § 3, 2-5-96.  
Sec. 4-1071. - Grievance procedure. 
(a)  An employee shall first present his grievance to his immediate supervisor who shall make careful inquiry into the facts and circumstances of the complaint. The supervisor shall attempt to resolve the problem promptly and fairly. 
(b)  An employee who is dissatisfied with the decision of his supervisor may submit his grievance, in writing, to his department head. The department head shall make a separate investigation and inform the employee, in writing, of his decision and the reasons for it within five (5) working days after receipt of the employee's grievance. 
(c)  If the employee is dissatisfied with the department head's decision, he may obtain a review by the city manager by submitting a request, in writing, within five (5) working days following the receipt of the department head's decision. The city manager shall make such investigation and conduct such hearings as he deems necessary and shall, within ten (10) working days after the receipt of the employee's request for review, inform the department head and employee, in writing, of his findings and decision. 
(d)  The employee shall have the right, at all levels, to a closed hearing and may be represented at the hearing.  
Sec. 4-1072. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 1120-96, § 4, adopted Feb. 5, 1996, repealed former section 4-1072 in its entirety which pertained to the appeal of disciplinary action and derived from this codification.  
Sec. 4-1073. - Hours of work. 
The hours of operation for each department shall be established by the department head with the approval of the city manager. The work schedule shall be placed on file with the personnel office and it will be the responsibility of the department head to notify the personnel office of any changes.  
Sec. 4-1074. - Overtime. 
(a)  Overtime. Department heads are authorized to grant overtime at the rate of time and one-half (½) when the work being performed is mission critical or as required by law. Any overtime which is not pre-authorized by action of city council must be justified in writing as mission critical. Overtime is paid after forty (40) hours per week for all general employees and police personnel. Overtime is paid after two hundred twelve (212) hours in the designated twenty-eight-day work period for fire sworn personnel as in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act 207(k) exemption. 
(1)  Mission critical. Mission critical overtime is defined as overtime necessary to prevent disruption of essential city services. These services include but are not limited to the following: 
a.  Sewer or waterline breaks during non-working hours of assigned crews. 
b.  Power-outages as a result of tree limbs, broken poles, storm damage, etc. 
c.  Storm-related emergencies for sanding of streets, clearing roadways, or restoring basic city services. 
d.  Shortage of manpower which necessitates calling in personnel to prevent the closing down of emergency equipment. 
e.  Shortage of manpower which necessitate calling in additional personnel to prevent the reduction of emergency services. 
f.  Street or bridge cave-ins or collapse which would effect the safety of the public. 
g.  Seasonal leaf pick-up when determined that not working overtime would disrupt collection schedules. 
h.  Revenue critical functions needed to maintain cash-flow and schedule of hearing mandates in the area of court services. 
(2)  Legal requirements. Under federal law, fire personnel must be paid overtime after an average of fifty-three (53) hours per week of work time. This does not sufficiently cover the hours to maintain a twenty-four-hour operation. When minimal staffing levels to do not allow time off, overtime will be paid to meet federal guidelines. 
(3)  Assignment of overtime. 
a.  Assignment of overtime must be managed such that the work is performed by the least number of employees needed to accomplish the task required, and should be performed by the employees at the lowest rate of pay who have the required skills and experience to perform the mission critical tasks. 
b.  Overtime paid per employee must be documented with justification for the overtime as mission critical, and this documentation must be made available upon request for management review. 
(b)  Compensatory time. 
(1)  For employees hired on or after September 1, 2002, compensatory time, or time off in lieu of overtime, may be granted for overtime hours worked. These hours worked over the maximum regular hours allowed in each work period (forty (40) hours for employees except fire personnel) will be accrued at the rate of time and one-half (½) of the employee's regular pay rate. For employees hired before September 1, 2002, compensatory time may be taken in place of overtime at the employee's discretion. 
(2)  Employees who accrue overtime earned as comp-time may be required to take comp-time at a time when city services will not be seriously affected, as determined by the department head. The maximum accrued comp-time per employee is two hundred forty (240) hours for general employees and four hundred eighty (480) hours for fire and police personnel. All overtime earned after the maximum comp-time accrual is reached must be paid as overtime pay. Any accrued and unused comp-time must be paid in full when the employee ceases to be employed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 805-82, § 1, 9-7-82; Ord. No. 024-02, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-02)  
Sec. 4-1075. - Holidays generally. 
The following days are designated as holidays: New Year's Day, Martin Luther King Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, the day after Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. When Christmas Day and New Year's Day falls on a Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday employees shall receive one day leave on Christmas Eve and one-half-day leave on New Year's Eve. Other work days may be declared holidays by the mayor and council at their discretion. When a holiday falls on Saturday, the preceding Friday shall be observed as the holiday. When a holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be observed as the holiday. 
(Ord. No. 1046-93, § 1, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 1161-98, § 1, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 025-02, § 1, 9-3-02)  
Sec. 4-1075.1. - Holiday pay for holiday non-essential personnel. 
Employees shall be eligible for pay for all city designated holidays. 
(Ord. No. 025-02, § 1, 9-3-02; Ord. No. 008-014, § 1, 5-19-14 )  
Sec. 4-1075.2. - Holiday pay for holiday essential personnel. 
The employees required to work the holiday shall be compensated at the pay rate of time and one half for having worked the holiday. 
(Ord. No. 025-02, § 1, 9-3-02; Ord. No. 008-014, § 1, 5-19-14 )  
Sec. 4-1075.3. - Absence prior to or following the furlough day or designated holiday (paid or unpaid). 
Any period of absence occurring on a scheduled work day immediately prior to or immediately subsequent to a designated holiday or a furlough day will require a medical certificate signed by a licensed physician to substantiate the leave request in order to receive compensation for the period of absence. This requirement will apply to all absences except pre-approved annual or personal leave. 
(Ord. No. 025-02, § 1, 9-3-02; Ord. No. 008-014, § 1, 5-19-14 )  
Sec. 4-1076. - Holidays for part-time employees. 
Part-time employees shall not be paid for observed holidays which are not worked.  
Sec. 4-1077. - Vacation leave; rate of accrual. 
All regular full time employees employed after July 21, 1980, shall accrue annual leave at the rate of .833 days per month, or ten (10) days per year; and all employees employed prior to July 22, 1980, shall accrue leave at the rate of one day per month, or twelve (12) days per year. 
After completing four (4) years service, annual leave shall be accrued at the rate of one and twenty-five hundredths (1.25) days per month, or fifteen (15) days per year. 
After completion of fourteen (14) years of service, annual leave shall be accrued at the rate of one and sixty-one hundredths (1.61) days per month, or twenty (20) days per year. 
After completion of nineteen (19) years of service, annual leave shall be accrued at the rate of two and eight hundredths (2.08) days per month, or twenty-five (25) days per year. 
(Ord. No. 822-82, § 2, 12-13-82)  
Sec. 4-1078. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Sick leave with pay shall be granted to regular, full time employees only in the case of: actual sickness or disability of the employee, or the employee's immediate family member, resulting from causes beyond the employee's control; or medical or dental examinations or treatments for which arrangements cannot be made outside of working hours. 
(1)  For purposes of this section "immediate family member" means an employee's child, spouse, grandchild, grandparent, parent, or any dependents as shown in the employee's most recent tax return. 
(b)  The employee shall report to his supervisor the reason for his use of sick leave prior to his schedule work time if possible. If this is not possible, he shall see that his absence is reported within thirty (30) minutes after the time he is scheduled to report for work. Failure to do so may be cause for denial of sick leave with pay for that day and for each subsequent day that prior notification has not been given. Special consideration will be given to emergency situations. 
(c)  A medical certificate signed by a licensed physician will be required by the department head to substantiate leave requests or sick leave for the following reasons: 
(1)  Any period of absence consisting of three (3) or more consecutive days. 
(2)  Sick leave of any duration if absence from duty recurs frequently or habitually provided that an employee has been notified that a certificate will be required. 
(3)  Any period of absence occurring on a work day prior to or subsequent to a holiday as defined in this chapter. 
(d)  Full-time employees begin to accrue sick leave immediately upon employment at the rate of one day per month. Sick leave may not be taken in increments smaller than one-half of a day. No sick leave may be taken beyond that which is already accrued. 
(e)  Unused sick leave may be carried into the next calendar year, on an unlimited basis. 
(f)  Sick leave compensation upon retirement. 
(1)  Employee shall not be compensated upon retirement for unused sick leave accumulated after December 31, 1978. 
(2)  Employees who, upon retirement from their employment freeze their retirement benefits, shall not be paid for any accumulated unused sick leave. 
(3)  Employees on the payroll prior to December 12, 1977, shall be paid upon retirement for all unused sick leave accumulated and recorded in the personnel office through December 31, 1978; less sick leave taken which exceed unused sick leave accumulated after December 31, 1978. Payment for accumulated sick leave shall be by continuation of salary until said accumulated sick leave has been paid and commencement thereafter of any pension entitlements of said retiring employee. 
(4)  Employees hired after the adoption of these rules and regulations shall not be compensated for accumulated unused sick leave upon retirement. 
(Ord. No. 845-83, §§ 1, 2, 5-2-83; Ord. No. 1113-95, § 1, 7-3-95; Ord. No. 081-017 , 11-20-17)  
Sec. 4-1079. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 881-85, § 1, adopted June 3, 1985, deleted § 4-1079, pertaining to on the job injury leave, which section did not contain history notation.  
Sec. 4-1080. - Worker's compensation. 
Employees are covered under the provisions of worker's compensation law. If an employee is injured while on the job, such an injury must be reported to the supervisor immediately. 
(Ord. No. 1042-92, § 1, 10-5-92)  
Sec. 4-1081. - Funeral leave. 
Funeral leave of up to three (3) working days shall be granted, with pay, for employees in the event of death in the immediate family. Immediate family shall mean husband, wife, son, daughter, brother or sister. For the purposes of this provision, immediate family is defined to include those members set forth herein previously together with mother, father, grandmother or grandfather of an employee or his or her spouse.  
Sec. 4-1082. - Military leave. 
(a)  Any permanent employee who leaves the service of the city to join the military forces of the United States during time of war or other national emergency, or is inducted by selective service, may upon written request prior to his induction into the military, be placed on military leave without pay, such leave to extend through a date ninety (90) days after he is relieved from the military service. Such an employee shall be entitled to be restored to the position which he vacated, provided he makes application within ninety (90) days of the date of honorable discharge or discharge under honorable conditions and if physically and mentally capable of performing the work of his position. 
(b)  An employee who is a member of the National Guard or an organized military reserve of the United States will be allowed leave of absence not to exceed fifteen (15) calendar days during any calendar year to attend training camp upon presentation of orders pursuant to the training. The city shall pay the employee any difference in the amount received for the military service and the employee's regular salary.  
Sec. 4-1083. - Civil leave. 
An employee shall be given the time off with pay for jury duty or when subpoenaed to appear before any public body or commission.  
Sec. 4-1084. - Leave of absence without pay. 
Leave of absence without pay may be granted to an employee upon his department head's recommendation, by the city manager for a period not to exceed six (6) consecutive months. No accrual privileges or benefits are allowed for an employee who is on leave of absence. Consideration for leave without pay will be given for reasons such as personal illness or disability of a member of the employee's household, or continuing education. The needs of the city will be the controlling factor. 
When an employee is precluded from meeting the responsibility of the position to which he/she is assigned, because of being hurt off the job, personal illness, pregnancy, disability of a family member, physical limitation due to drugs, alcohol or physician's orders, leave of absence may be granted as set forth above, and when such leave of absence is granted, the employee shall pay the city's share of the employee's health and accident and life insurance. 
(Ord. No. 838-83, § 1, 3-9-83)  
Sec. 4-1085. - Training. 
The personnel director, under the direction of the city manager, shall be responsible for the development and promotion of inservice training of employees in order to improve the quality of city service and to assist employees in preparing themselves for advancement in the city employment.  
Sec. 4-1086. - Reimbursement for training expense. 
An employee who enters a job related training program with the prior approval of his department head and the city manager may be reimbursed for expenses such as tuition and books upon successful completion of the program. Approval may be dependent on budget allocations. An expense advance may be issued if recommended by the department head and approved by the city manager.  
Sec. 4-1087. - Service rating. 
The personnel director, under the direction of the city manager, and in cooperation with department heads, shall establish a system of service ratings based on standards of performance. The primary purpose of service ratings shall be to discuss with employees how they are performing on their job, and how their work performance could be improved. Department heads or supervisors shall review service ratings with employees, but the ratings shall be confidential between the supervisor, the department head, the employee and the personnel director.  
Sec. 4-1088. - Responsibility for safety. 
It is the responsibility of the city to provide safe working conditions, tools, equipment and work methods for employees. All employees shall use the safety equipment provided, and shall follow all safety rules and safe working methods. Violation of safety rules shall be considered the same as violation of any departmental rule, and an employee in violation may be subject to disciplinary action.  
Sec. 4-1089. - Reporting of accidents. 
Any on the job accident or injury shall be reported immediately to the supervisor. It is the responsibility of the supervisor to arrange for prompt medical attention if such is necessary, and to complete and submit a written report of the accident to the personnel director and his department head.  
Sec. 4-1090. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 001-05, § 1, adopted Jan. 18, 2005, repealed former section 4-1090 in its entirety. Former section 4-1090 pertained to an code of ethics incorporated by reference and derived from Ord. No. 1159-98, § 1, adopted April 20, 1985.  
Sec. 4-1091. - Certain employees required to maintain working telephone at place of residence. 
All city employees working in the police, fire and communications departments and all city department heads are required to have a working telephone at their place of residence. All such employee's telephone numbers shall be reported to the personnel office by the respective employees. Also, any change in such telephone number shall be reported to the city manager's office by the affected employee within ten (10) days following such change. 
(Ord. No. 1053-93, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Editor's note Nonamendatory Ord. No. 1053-93, § 1, adopted July 6, 1993 has been included herein as a new § 4-1091 at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 4-10924-1100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE D. - RETIREMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note An amended and restated retirement plan was issued by the city council and became effective on Jan. 1, 2001. This plan replaced former §§ 4-11014-1117 which pertained to the former retirement plan and derived from Ord. No. 1106-95, § 1, 6-5-95; Ord. No. 1157-98, §§ 16, 9, 5-18-98; Ord. No. 003-00, § 1, 12-6-99. 
Charter reference Retirement benefits, § 4-501. 
 
Sec. 4-1101. - Statement of purpose. 
(a)  Background. The plan initially was adopted and effective June 19, 1975 and subsequently amended and restated at various times. The plan, as set forth in this document, is intended and should be construed as a restatement and continuation of the plan as previously in effect. This restatement is intended to (i) consolidate various amendments made to the plan since the last restatement, (ii) clarify and modify certain provisions of the plan, and (iii) bring the plan into compliance with laws and regulations enacted or issued prior to the effective date of this restatement. 
(b)  Purpose. The primary purpose of the plan is to recognize employees' contributions to the operations of the City of East Point and to reward the same by providing eligible employees with an opportunity to accumulate a retirement benefit for their future security and that of their beneficiaries. 
(c)  Type of plan. The plan is intended to be a governmental defined benefit pension plan qualified under Section 401(a), with the related trust qualified under Section 501(a), of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
(d)  Applicability of amendment. The plan is hereby amended, and adopted by the city council, effective October 20, 2003. Any person who is covered by the plan as in effect before October 20, 2003, and who retired or otherwise terminated employment before October 20, 2003, shall continue to be entitled to the rights and benefits, if any, provided under the plan as in effect on his retirement or termination of employment. 
The accrued benefit of an eligible employee who is a participant in the plan as of October 20, 2003, shall not in any circumstances be less than the participant's accrued benefit as of October 19, 2003, determined under the terms of the prior plan as in effect on October 19, 2003. 
(Ord. eff. 1-1-01, Art. 1; Ord. No. 003-04, 2-2-04)  
Sec. 4-1102. - Definitions. 
For purposes of the plan, the following terms, when used with an initial capital letter, shall have the meanings set forth below unless a different meaning plainly is required by the context. 
Accrued retirement benefit means the pension benefit to be provided for each participant (other than city council) commencing on the first day of the month next following his actual retirement date. This is payable during the participant's lifetime, with seventy-five (75) percent continued to a qualified spouse, or children until age eighteen (18), in a monthly amount equal to (a) times (b) times (c), where: 
(a)  is the applicable benefit percentage, 
(b)  is the years of credited service, and 
(c)  is the average monthly compensation. 
The child's benefit shall continue to age twenty-four (24) if the child is a full-time student. It will be reduced fifty (50) percent and continued for the life of the child if, in the sole discretion of the pension board, the child is handicapped and unemployable. 
Actuarial equivalent means amount is the actuarial equivalent of any other amount if the actuarial reserve required to provide the same is equal to the actuarial reserve required to provide such other amount. 
(1)  Optional payment forms other than lump sum. This is computed on the basis of the 1983 Group Annuity Mortality Table blended eighty (80) percent male and twenty (20) percent female, and an annual interest rate of seven (7). 
(2)  Lump sum distributions. (A lump sum payment does not reduce the seventy-five (75) percent survivor's benefit.) This is computed on the basis of the interest rates and mortality tables specified by Section 417(e)(3)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code, as follows: 
a.  Interest. The rate of interest for thirty-year Treasury securities (as specified by the IRS in Notice 2002-26) during September preceding the calendar year of distribution. 
b.  Mortality. 
1.  For distributions with annuity starting dates on or after December 31, 2002, Revenue Ruling 2001-62 requires the unloaded male and female mortality rates in the 1994 GAR Tables, projected to 2002 and weighted 50%/50%. 
2.  For distributions with annuity starting dates before December 31, 2002, Revenue Ruling 95-6 requires the male and female mortality rates in the 1983 GAM tables weighted 50%/50%. 
Actuary means the person, firm or corporation, one of whose officers shall be an enrolled actuary (as defined by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended), appointed by the Board to render actuarial services for the plan. 1.04 Applicable Benefit Percentage means the percentage based on retirement age as follows:
