CHAPTER 1. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 1179-99 §§ 1, 2, adopted April 5, 1999, amended former Ch. 6, Arts. AD, in its entirety which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1969 and the following: Ord. No. 698-79, § 1, 4-16-79; Ord. No. 878-89, § 1, 7-17-89; Ord. No. 920-86, § 1-8-4-86; Ord. No. 1179A-94, § 1, 7-18-94. 
 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 6-1001. - East Point chief of police; duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The East Point chief of police shall be the chief law enforcement officer for the City of East Point, Georgia as provided for in Charter and Related Local Laws section 1-104 Specific powers Nos. 32, 40, and in the Georgia Laws. The East Point police chief shall meet requirements of O.C.G.A. 35-8-10 Certification Requirements for State Peace Officer License. 
(b)  The chief of Police shall meet the requirements of O.C.G.A. 35-8-8 concerning the hiring requirements for peace officers for the State of Georgia. The East Point police chief shall also meet the requirements of O.C.G.A. 35-8-20 to 35-8-20.1Special Training for Police Chiefs and O.C.G.A. 3 5-8-21Annual Training Required for Peace Officers. 
(c)  The East Point chief of police shall promulgate written Standard Operating Procedures (S.O.P.) for all personnel assigned to the police department. These rules, regulations, and procedures, shall govern the conduct, efficiency, effectiveness, operation, responsiveness, discipline, and delivery of services for the police department. Each employee assigned to the police department shall have a copy and be responsible for the contents of the Standard Operating Procedure (S.O.P.). The Standard Operating Procedure (S.O.P.) will be updated and revised by the police chief and staff as needed. A copy of the Standard Operating Procedure (S.O.P.)shall be on file with the mayor and city council. Violations of the Standard Operating Procedures (S.O.P.), rules, or regulations may be grounds for reprimand, transfer from current position or department, demotion, suspension, or termination. 
(d)  The chief of police or his designee shall administer the oath of office to all sworn police officers, detention officers, and communication officers as agents for the city to enforce all laws. 
(e)  The chief of police shall have full responsibility and in charge of space utilization of the Law Enforcement Building. This responsibility will be for all departments, (police department, jail, court, communications and any other group assigned to the Law Enforcement Center). No changes, modifications, or painting shall be made to the building without approval of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1002. - Administrative staff. 
The chief of police shall assemble an administrative staff to assist in operations and administrative services of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1003. - Requirements for police officers. 
Police applicants must meet the following requirements for employment with the police department and for state certification, as stated in part of O.C.G.A. 35-8-8 and Chapter 464-3 Georgia P.O.S.T. Rules; applicants must be twenty-one (21) years of age, must have a valid Georgia driver's license, no felony convictions, no D.U.I.'s, no significant number of misdemeanors as to reflect a disregard for traffic laws, honorable discharge if prior military service, must be a United States citizen, possess a high school diploma or state certified GED, must not have been terminated from previous police job or asked to resign for accusation of any misconduct or conduct, must become a Georgia resident, must furnish copy of P.O.S.T. certification peace officer number, must pass written entry level police test, must pass polygraph testing, must pass medical and drug testing, must pass P.O.S.T. police entry level test, and complete thorough background and interview process. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1004. - Hiring pay steps. 
Non-certified police officer hires are to be hired at entry level step one of the current pay plan in effect when they do not have a two-year accredited college degree. The chief of police has the authority to hire prior P.O.S.T. certified police officers with two years of police experience and training at step two in the current pay plan. The chief of police shall also have the authority to hire previous P.O.S.T. certified police officers that have previously worked for the East Point police department at step two in the current pay plan in effect. After completing the required probationary period, all above hires shall be moved to the next step. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1005. - Police department organization. 
The chief of police has the authority to organize the police department into divisions within the department and to assign and transfer personnel which would best correspond with the needs of the department, residents of the City of East Point, and the city government. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1006. - Familiarization with Standard Operating Procedure (S.O.P.). 
Every employee shall be furnished with a copy of the Standard Operating Procedure (S.O.P.) governing the police department and shall thoroughly familiarize themselves with the rules and regulations. Ignorance of any rule or regulation contained in the (S.O.P.) shall not be an excuse to an officer that is charged with a violation of the same. Each employee shall keep their (S.O.P.) up to date at all times. Revisions or updates shall be given out when necessary. Failure to keep (S.O.P.'s) up to date or produce the manual when notified shall be cause for suspension. Violations of the Standard Operating Procedure (S.O.P.) are covered by policy A-060, unless specifically covered in this or other chapters of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1007. - Demeanor and conduct of officers/employees. 
Each officer/employee shall conduct themselves in a quiet, civil, and orderly manner. At all times, officers/employees shall maintain decorum, attention, control of temper, patience, discretion, and must refrain from harsh, violent, coarse, profane, or insolent language. Officers/employees shall not answer in a short, abrupt manner and shall not be biased in their decisions. All answers shall be with courtesy, respect, and attention. Proper respect shall be shown at all times to the public, other officers, to the ranking system in the police department. Violations of this section may result in suspension or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1008. - Required devotion to duty. 
Police officers/employees shall devote their entire working time and attention to the business of the police department, city, and public. All officers and employees of the department are subject to be responsive to calls for service and must act immediately on notice that their services are required. All officers/employees must work their regular hours or return to work when properly notified. All officers/employees shall have correct uniforms and equipment when working on or off duty. Violations of this section may result in suspension or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1009. - Acceptance of gratuities/making bail bonds. 
No officer/employee shall directly or indirectly recommend or suggest to any person arrested, or to any prisoner in custody, the employment, hire of any specific attorney or bail bondsman. No officer/employee shall become a surety or grantor, or go on the bond of, or furnish bail for any person arrested and charged with a crime except members of their immediate family. No officer/employee shall accept from any person any gratuity, reward, gift, or other compensation for services rendered or for expenses incurred in connection with official duties. Violations for this section may result in suspension or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1010. - Discharge of officers/employees; conduct/misconduct. 
Any officer or employee shall be discharged from the city and/or police department for cause shown, after a hearing and conviction for a failure to discharge their duties or for any conduct unbecoming of a police officer/employee or for any misconduct while on or off duty. Any officer or employee discharged for above offenses shall have five (5) business days on which to file a written notice of appeal after they have received written notice of such discharge. Appeals are regulated by section 4-1012 Appeals of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1011. - Compliance with lawful, just, and legal orders. 
All officers/employees of the police department shall promptly execute the lawful, just, and legal orders or instructions of a supervisor. Violations of this section shall result in suspension to dismissal depending upon the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1012. - Relief from duty/work hours. 
The chief of police has the authority to set work hours for all police officers and other employees of the police department. All personnel shall remain on duty until relieved. In situations where an officer or other employee must be sent home for cause, and the chief of police is not available, watch commanders are authorized to send an officer or employee home for one (1) day and to have employee report to the chief of police on the next day. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1013. - Dissemination of protected information. 
Information should not be given out that would interfere with the successful conclusion of an investigation, pose a security threat, violate federal, state, or city laws or privacy laws, that is detrimental or defeats the ends of justice, prejudicial to the rights of the suspect, accused, or employee; that will impact on the dignity of the department or personnel. Background information on police applicants or other employees are confidential and are also covered by this section. Violations of this section shall result in suspension to dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1014. - Treatment of arrested persons. 
Police officers shall not mistreat or use unnecessary force or violence to any person while under arrest or being arrested; nor shall they use their office or position to oppress, persecute, or annoy any person. Sick or injured prisoners shall be medically treated as expedient as possible. Violations of this section shall result in suspension to dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1015. - Uniforms/police Vehicles/equipment. 
The chief of police shall devise professional, proper uniforms and designate correct insignia for all police officers and require proper apparel for all other civilian employees assigned to the police department. All police department personnel shall report to work with all assigned equipment as designated by the chief of police. The chief of police shall have full charge and approve the assignment of all police department vehicles and develop a take home car policy. All police enforcement vehicles shall be marked in accordance with state laws and shall use flashing blue lights. Police department vehicles shall only be used for official police business. Department personnel shall not carry non-authorized guns, weapons, equipment, gear, and other provisions. Violations of this section may result in suspension or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1016. - Police department clothing allowance. 
All sworn police officers, detention officers, communication officers, identification technicians, and school crossing guards shall receive a clothing allowance from the police department. The clothing dollars amounts for each division shall be set by the city with a recommendation from the police chief. All clothing allowances for personnel shall run from January to December of each year. Newly hired personnel shall be expended one-half (½) of the normal regular amount that is authorized for their classification to buy uniforms at hire date. Personnel assigned to investigative or plain clothes work shall receive their clothing allowance on a paycheck basis per rules established by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1017. - Incident and accident reports. 
The chief of police shall ensure that police personnel record crime incidents that occur in the East Point city limits in accordance with the F.B.I. Uniform Crime Reporting Regulations. Accident reports shall be completed when incidents meet state guidelines for reporting. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1018. - Re-hiring of previous police officers. 
The chief of police may re-hire previous P.O.S.T. certified police officers that have worked for the police department providing that their work record, dependability, responsibility, conduct, attitude, performance, and work ethics have been established and determined and that they left with proper notice and in good standing. They shall start over in seniority. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1019. - Phone numbers/correct addresses. 
All police department personnel shall have a telephone as a requirement of employment. All employees of the police department shall notify their supervisors of their correct phone numbers, emergency contact numbers, pager numbers, and addresses. Violations may result in suspension to dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1020. - Police officers sworn as Fulton County deputy sheriffs. 
The chief of police shall authorize selected P.O.S.T. certified police officers within the police department to be sworn and administered the oath as Fulton County deputy sheriffs or Fulton County Police Officers to enable them to discharge their duties of investigation and arresting, outside the city limits as well as within the city limits provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1021. - Riders in police vehicles. 
Only authorized personnel or arrestees are allowed to ride in police vehicles. All other persons must have written permission from the chief of police or his designee to ride in police vehicles. Violations may result in suspension or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1022. - Pictures/video tapes of crimes/accidents; charges. 
The police department is authorized to charge and receive a fee for each picture or video tape of a crime, crime scene, accident, or line up. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, §, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1023. - Pictures/video tapes; furnishing for use against city. 
It shall be unlawful to furnish any picture or video tape for use against the city or any of its department's, agencies, officers, or employees, or furnish such picture or video tape in any circumstances or situation if it is reasonable to suspect that the interest of the city or any of its agencies, officers, or employees may ultimately be adversely affected by the use of such picture or video tape as evidence in any court, inquiry, or investigation unless previous consent has been obtained by the chief of police. Violations of this section may result in suspension to dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1024. - Official use of photo/video Cameras/video recorders. 
It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the police department to use, occupy time of any officer/employee or use funds or city property in taking or making pictures, photographs, or video tapes for their own use or for another without authorization. Violations of this section may result in suspension or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1025. - Fees for fingerprinting, criminal history checks, crime statistics; fees for records, reports, photographs, video tapes, indoor/outdoor pistol firing range. 
The chief of police is authorized to set fees for fingerprinting, checking criminal history, or for gathering crime statistics for the public, groups, agents, or others not directly employed by the city. The chief of police is also authorized to set fees for copies of reports, pictures, video tapes, and other such records or information. The chief of police is also authorized to set fees for use of the police department's indoor/outdoor pistol firing range. These fees are be based on cost of factors as determined by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1026. - Lost/found property. 
All lost/found property shall be turned into the police department. 
Officers shall make reports and tag the property in accordance with established Standard Operating Policies (S.0.P.). Violations of this section may result in suspension or dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1027. - Return of lost/found property. 
The chief of police shall select a lost/found property officer for the police department. It shall be the duty of the lost/found property officer to ensure that any lost/found property coming into possession of the police department be returned to the rightful owner as soon as ownership can be determined, except in cases where further possession of the property shall be necessary for use as evidence in the trail or any case where the use of such property as evidence may be necessary. Where such use of such property is necessary, such property shall be retained in custody of the police department. Such property retained by the police department shall be restored to the rightful owner, if known, as soon as it is practicable after such trial. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1028. - Sale/advertisement of lost/found property. 
(a)  If the owner of any lost or stolen property cannot be determined from search and inquiry, the chief of police and/or lost/found property officer is authorized on/or after sixty (60) days from the date the same comes into the possession of the point police department to sale the property. The department shall publish a one (1) time notice of the sale date and listing partial descriptions of such property as practical in the local newspaper which serves the city. Such advertisement shall also contain a notice of sale hours and date. The lost/found property sale shall take place on the Tuesday after the sale notice has ran in the local paper and shall start at 8:30 am. and last until all items are sold. The newspaper notice shall state that all sales are final and that only cash will be accepted. 
(b)  All sales shall take place on the grounds of the police department. All such sales shall be public, and shall be to the highest bidder for cash. No checks or money orders shall be accepted. Additional sale notice shall be placed on the entry doors to the police department for a period of twenty (20) days before the sale. The lost/found property officer may consolidate certain bid items to expedite the sale. There shall be no express or implied warranties as to any sale item. All items shall be sold in an "as is" condition. All sales are final. All monies shall be deposited back to the city general fund budget. Title shall not be warranted nor guaranteed on sale items. 
(c)  The police department is authorized to destroy unclaimed property of prisoners that is determined to be of no value after said property has been held and unclaimed for at least thirty (30) days. Property that is of value and held unclaimed for at least sixty (60) days, will be sold at sale in a manner consistent with the requirements of this section. The lost/found property officer is authorized to destroy and/or discard any lost/found property that is of no value or that would be illegal for resale or violate certain state or federal laws. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1029. - Return of stolen shoplifted property. 
The police department shall return all stolen or shoplifted property once the rightful ownership has been established. Officers should make reports and/or take pictures for evidence if necessary of the items or property that is returned. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1030. - Auxiliary/emergency police force. 
The chief of police is authorized, in cases of emergency, to call upon volunteers from the community thereof to aid and assist the police department and members thereof in the prevention of crime and lawlessness. The chief of Police is also authorized to use volunteer P.0.S.T. certified police officers in cases of large events located within the city. This use should be for crowd control, parades, or other large crowd control measures. In either case, volunteers shall not have arrest powers unless sworn as a police officer by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1031. - Badge at retirement/identification card. 
Certified police officers that meet regular retirement regulations from the point police department and that have served a minimum of twenty years shall be awarded their duty badge and a retired ID card at the time of their retirement. Officers receiving disability retirements shall also be awarded their duty badge. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1032. - Police department promotions. 
The chief of police is hereby authorized to establish a promotional system for the police department. The promotional system may take into account an employee's work history, responsibility, dependability, seniority, work ethic, report writing, disciplinary actions, oral interviews or review boards, and may be subjected to a written performance test or any other job related factors. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Secs. 6-10336-1040. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE B. - EAST POINT MUNICIPAL JAIL OPERATIONS 
 
Sec. 6-1041. - General provisions authorization. 
The city hereby establishes the East Point Municipal Jail as a detention facility for arrestees, inmates, and/or prisoners. The municipal jail shall meet state guidelines for housing arrestees, inmates, and/or prisoners. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1042. - Establishment of standard operating procedure for jail. 
The chief of police is authorized to establish guidelines, procedures, and regulations dealing with the incarceration, detention, lock up, feeding, supervision, visiting, health care, work regulations, disciplinary actions, and accountability of inmates or prisoners. The chief of police is also authorized to establish guidelines, rules, and regulations for detention personnel. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1043. - Supervision for municipal jail operations. 
The chief of police is authorized to select the director for municipal jail operations. The jail director shall have responsibility for all operations within the municipal jail operations. The jail director shall set work hours, work regulations, policies, procedures, and regulations with the approval of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1044. - Hiring of detention officers. 
Detention officers shall be twenty (20) years of age, pass oral interview process, pass background process, pass criminal and driving history requirements, pass physical and drug testing, pass polygraph requirements, be able to meet state law 35-8-24 and Georgia P.O.S.T. Rules Chapter 464-13-.05 (Jail Officer Training Standards) concerning P.O.ST. certification as a jailer, must have a high school diploma or state issued GED, and must have an honorable discharge if prior military service. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1045. - Police/jail supervision of inmates. 
The police department shall have full custody of all inmates arrested and placed into the municipal jail. The police chief is authorized to have the jail director organize work details for working inside the police department, the Law Enforcement Center, and for outside work details. Outside work details shall have certified police officers or certified detention personnel as supervisors of such work. Once inmates are sentenced from the municipal court, the police department municipal jail operations has sole responsibility for said inmates. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1046. - Hiring steps for detention officers. 
All detention officers shall be hired at step 1 of the current pay plan in effect at the time. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Secs. 6-10476-1049. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE C. - EAST POINT POLICE COMMUNICATIONS 
 
Sec. 6-1050. - East Point police communications division. 
The chief of police is authorized to establish, organize, manage, supervise, arrange, and classify the East Point police communication division. The chief of police is authorized to select the officer in charge of the police communications division. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1051. - Communications division standard operating procedure (S.O.P.). 
The chief of police is authorized to establish a section of operating procedures for the communications division. The communication division is also responsible for obeying, submitting, and complying to the regular police department Standard Operating Procedures (S.O.P.). Violations may result in suspension to dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1052. - Clothing allowance; uniform regulations; dress code. 
The chief of police is hereby authorized to establish clothing allowances, uniform regulations, and dress codes for the communication division. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1053. - Hiring requirements/certification. 
All communication operators shall be at least twenty (20) years of age. Applicants shall meet the requirements of state law 35-8-23 and Georgia P.O.ST. Rules Chapter 464-14 (Communications Operators) in order to qualify for a position. Applicants shall also have clean criminal and driving histories, pass written test, pass oral interview, polygraph, medical/physical, drug testings, and background procedures. All applicants will serve a one-year probationary status. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Secs. 6-10546-1059. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE D. - TRAFFIC DIVISION 
 
Sec. 6-1060. - Authority to establish. 
The chief of police is hereby authorized to establish a traffic division within the East Point police department. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1061. - Traffic division commander established. 
The chief of police shall establish the office of and select the officer in charge of the traffic division. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1062. - Duties/responsibilities. 
The traffic division shall be responsible for the administration of the school crossing guards, traffic police officers, paint and sign crew, and working with the Georgia Department of Transportation. Other duties and responsibilities shall be assigned by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Sec. 6-1063. - Traffic officers. 
Five (5) traffic police officers shall be assigned to the traffic division when personnel are available. Duties, responsibilities, work hours, assignments, functions, and tasks to be assigned by the traffic supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 1179-99, § 2, 4-5-99)  
Secs. 6-10646-1070. - Reserved.  
CHAPTER 2. - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION  
ARTICLE A. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 6-2001. - Chief of fire department; election; term; removal. 
The fire chief shall be elected by the mayor and council and city manager. The chief of the fire department shall hold office during good behavior and efficient service; provided, that such good behavior and efficient services shall be judged of by the mayor, city council and city manager, who shall have power to remove him from office in accordance with the provisions of the charter and related laws.  
Sec. 6-2002. - Duties and responsibilities of the chief of the fire department. 
(a)  The fire chief of the City of East Point shall be the chief authority over emergency management and fire rescue in the City of East Point. The fire chief is responsible for managing the prevention and suppression of fire; delivering emergency medical services; managing and coordinating the fire department administration and operations sections in order to protect life and property; enforcing all city fire codes, ordinances and fire laws and regulations of the state; ensuring that the work of all department employees is monitored; establishing and monitoring procedures for firefighting, pre-fire planning, non fire hazards, medical emergencies, or other emergencies; overseeing the hiring, promotions, and termination processes, investigating internal and external complaints, and working to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of fire protection. 
(b)  The fire chief shall ensure that the city manager remains current and abreast of all major policies affecting the administration of the department and other city departments regarding major fire policies, services or business, attend meetings and present reports to the city manager, mayor, city council, and other committees, commissions and groups as requested. 
(c)  The fire chief is responsible for preparing and implementing management plans and strategic plans for all areas of fire department including prevention, homeland security, rescue/medical, station relocation, etc. 
(d)  The fire chief shall establish rules and regulations, standard operating procedures, controls and disciplines for the department in accordance with applicable rules, regulations, city policy, city ordinances, state and federal law. 
(e)  The fire chief will supervise, direct, and evaluate assigned staff; handle employee concerns and problems; direct work, counsel, discipline and evaluate fire department employees in firefighting, pre-fire planning, hazardous material emergencies, rescue operations and other related emergencies. 
(f)  The fire chief shall coordinate mutual fire protection plans with surrounding municipalities; establish ongoing meetings with other fire and police departments and other agencies to stay abreast of homeland security strengths, weaknesses and threats. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 1, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2003. - Three platoon system established. 
(a)  The fire chief, or the chief's designee, has the authority to set work hours for all fire personnel and other employees of the fire department. 
(b)  The fire department of the city shall be operated on what is known as the "Three platoon system." 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 2, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2004. - Suspension of three platoon system. 
The fire chief, or the chief's designee, of the fire department shall have the power to suspend the three-platoon system when deemed necessary to maintain adequate fire department operations. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 3, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2005. - Uniforms. 
The members of the fire department shall be provided with a uniform or a uniform allowance each calendar year, as approved by the city council. The uniform or allowance shall be in addition to all other compensation.  
Sec. 6-2006. - Uniform specifications. 
All fire department uniforms shall conform to specifications of the fire chief, or the chief's designee. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 4, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2007. - Unauthorized use of uniforms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, without authority, to wear the uniform or any distinctive part thereof, or anything similar to a distinctive part thereof, which has been designed and approved by the East Point Fire Department.  
Sec. 6-2008. - Dissemination of protected information. 
No information shall be released that would interfere with the successful conclusion of an investigation, pose a security threat, violate federal, state, or city laws or privacy laws, is detrimental to or defeats the ends of justice is prejudicial to the rights of the suspect, accused, or employee; or that will impact on the dignity of the department or personnel. To the extent allowed by law, background information on firefighter applicants or other employees shall be confidential. Violation of this section shall result in suspension to dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 5, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2009. - Notifying the fire department. 
(a)  Whenever an unfriendly fire occurs in any building or on any premises of any kind, the owner, manager, occupant or any person in control of such building or premises, upon discovery of an unfriendly fire, or evidence of there having been an unfriendly fire, even though it has apparently been extinguished, shall immediately notify the fire department of such fire whether the fire has been extinguished or not. This requirements shall not be construed to forbid the owner, manager or other person in control of the aforementioned building or premises from using all diligence necessary to extinguish such fire prior to the arrival of the fire department. 
(b)  No person shall make, issue, post or maintain any regulation or order, written or verbal, that would require any person to take any action that would delay notifying the fire department of a fire. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, §§ 6, 7, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2010. - Mutual aid. 
The fire chief, at the chief's discretion, may make available for duty employees, property or equipment of East Point to assist other municipalities or counties with fire protection and all risk mitigation. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 8, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2011. - Authority to cut wires. 
The chief of the fire department, or other authority acting under him, is hereby authorized to cut any electrical wires which they shall deem necessary to cut, to stop the occurrence of any fire without expense to the city for so doing.  
Sec. 6-2012. - Injuring implements, materials or apparatus; interfering with firemen. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person wilfully and knowingly to injure or damage, in any way or by any means whatsoever, any engine, hose, hood, ladder or other implement, material or apparatus of any kind, belonging to, connected with or used by any of the fire companies in the city, as a part of their machinery or material for extinguishing fire or for the performance of their profession. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully and knowingly interfere with firemen exercising their lawful duties for the city.  
Sec. 6-2013. - Promotion in department. 
Fire department promotional procedures shall be set by the chief of the fire department, or the chief's designee, in conjunction with local, state and federal laws. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 9, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2014. - Duty of owner or operator to provide service. 
It shall be the duty of all persons owning or operating any business, or any of the following occupancies: industrial, storage, places of assembly, educational, health care or penal, residential, mercantile or others when declared by the fire chief to be an imminent fire or life hazard to provide approved watchman service throughout such occupancy until such time as the chief of the fire department shall determine and certify that such service is not necessary in order to protect persons and property.  
Sec. 6-2015. - Authority to collect acceptable needles. 
The chief of the fire department, or other authority acting under him, is hereby authorized to collect used needles and lancets at fire stations throughout the city, provided that each needle or lancet is in an acceptable disposal sharp container. 
(Ord. No. 1183-99, § 1, 5-3-99)  
Secs. 6-20166-2030. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE B. - FIRE PREVENTION 
 
Sec. 6-2031. - Fire marshal designated. 
The fire chief is the fire marshal unless the chief designates or assigns someone to serve in that capacity. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 10, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2032. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 001-07, § 11, repealed former § 6-2032 in its entirety which pertained to the bureau of fire prevention and investigation and derived from this codification.  
Sec. 6-2033. - Duties of the division of fire prevention and investigation. 
(a)  The Fire Prevention Codes, NFPA Fire Protection Handbook, NFPA National Fire Codes, Georgia Arson statutes and all other related statutes and all other applicable legal documents, ordinances, regulations, rules, laws and codes enforceable by the fire department or City of East Point, Georgia may be enforced by the division of fire prevention and investigation, under the supervision of the fire marshal and fire chief or the chief's designee of the fire department 
The personnel of the city division of fire prevention and investigation shall be vested with the necessary power and authority to carry out all adopted codes and ordinances of the City of East Point, Georgia. These personnel shall be vested with full authority to inspect premises, issue citations, investigate fires, and appear in court for the purpose of providing sworn testimony. 
(b)  The fire prevention division shall monitor compliance with fire and life safety regulations as defined in the applicable code, perform complex inspections in all types of commercial and residential occupancies to assure they are in compliance with the adopted fire code, ordinances and regulations as they pertain to the design, construction and installation of fire protection equipment and Hazardous Materials Regulations; investigate complaints of the fire hazards and hazardous materials violations; write correction notices, issue citations and perform other duties necessary to prevent the reoccurrence of safety related crimes or violations; appears in court as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 1214, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2034. - Police powers to fire chief, fire marshal and fire inspector/investigators. 
The police chief of the city is hereby authorized and directed to provide and grant police powers to the fire chief or the chief's designee, fire marshal and fire inspectors/investigators of the city for the purpose of the enforcement of all provisions of the East Point Fire Prevention Codes, adopted city ordinances, and rules and regulations of the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner and state arson statutes. 
Cross reference Building and technical code enforcement, Part 10, Chapter 4.  
Sec. 6-2035. - Cooperation with state officials. 
All city officials, department heads and fire personnel shall lend cooperation to the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, State Fire Marshal and his deputies, or assistance whenever called upon in the enforcement of the Georgia laws. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 17, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2036. - State fire laws adopted; adoption of rules and regulations of the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner. 
The rules and regulations now and hereafter promulgated for the prevention of destruction of life and/or property by fire, explosion and related hazards in this state by the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner shall be and are hereby adopted as the rules and regulations of this city.  
Sec. 6-2037. - Fire prevention code. 
(a)  The Fire Prevention Code 1976 edition, recommended by the American Insurance Association, consisting of 31 Articles and including Appendix A, is by reference made a part of this chapter. The Fire Prevention Code, except as hereafter set forth shall be and the same is hereby adopted as the Fire Prevention Code of the City of East Point. 
(b)  The aforesaid fire prevention code shall be and the same is declared to be public record of the City of East Point and shall be accessible to members of the general public. The code shall be kept in the office of the city clerk of the City of East Point. 
(c)  Violation of any provisions of the aforesaid fire prevention code hereby adopted shall upon conviction thereof, in the city court, be punishable as prescribed by 1-1006 of this Code. 
(d)  The fire prevention code adopted in subsection (a) is amended as follows: 
(1)  Add to Sec. 1.12. Definitions. 
Whenever the term "Corporation Counsel" is used in the Fire Prevention Code, it shall be held to mean the Attorney for the City of East Point. 
(2)  Article 1, Sec. 1.13 of the East Point Fire Prevention Code is hereby amended by adding new sections to be numbered sections 1.13.1, 1.13.2, 1.13.3, 1.13.4, 1.13.5, 1.13.6, and 1.13.7 and shall read as follows: 
Sec. 1.13.1. (Reserved) 
Sec. 1.13.2. Coordinated inspections. 
Whenever in the enforcement of the Fire Prevention Code the responsibility of more than one enforcement official of the municipality may be involved, it shall be their duty to coordinate their inspections and administrative orders as fully as practicable so that the owners and occupants of buildings shall not be subjected to visits by numerous inspectors nor to multiple or conflicting orders. Whenever an inspector from any municipal agency having authority under this code observes an apparent or actual violation of some provision thereof, or of the provision of some other law, ordinance or code of the municipality, not within his jurisdiction, he shall report his observations or findings to the official having jurisdiction; and such official shall cause an inspection to be made and, if it is found that a violation exists, shall issue the necessary orders for the correction thereof. 
Sec. 1.13.3. Reserved. 
Editor's note The editor has treated § 18 of Ord. No. 001-07, adopted Jan. 16 2007, has beden treated by the editor as superseding former fire prevention code amendment § 1.13.3. Similar provisions are found at § 6-2038 of this Code. 
Sec. 1.13.4. (Reserved.) 
Sec. 1.13.5. New materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
The City Manager, Chief of the Fire Department, Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention and the Councilmatic Board of the City shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in said Code. The Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
Sec. 1.13.6. Repeal of conflicting ordinances. 
All former ordinances or parts thereof conflicting or inconsistent with the provisions of this ordinance or of the code hereby adopted are hereby repealed. 
Sec. 1.13.7. Validity. 
It is hereby declared that should any section, paragraph, sentence, or word of this ordinance or of the code hereby adopted be declared for any reason to be invalid, it is the intent of the City of East Point that it would have passed all other portions of this ordinance independent of the elimination herefrom of any such portion as may be declared invalid. 
(3)  Article 3, Section 3.4 of said Code be and is hereby stricken in its entirety and the following inserted in lieu thereof: 
Sec. 3.4. Burning operation. 
The burning of wrecked or discarded automobiles or any parts thereof, or junk or any waste material shall be done only in an incinerator approved by the Fulton County Health Officer to comply with applicable air pollution control laws. 
(4)  Article 3 of the East Point Fire Prevention Code is hereby amended by adding a new section to be numbered Sec. 3.6 and to read as follows: 
Sec. 3.6. Removal of all gasoline tanks and all other dangerous and hazardous containers. 
No automobile or vehicular or other wrecking yard, junk yard, or waste salvage or waste material handling plant or reclaimer plant or other shall be allowed to process any object without first removing and rendering completely safe any object that may cause an explosion or fire or might cause danger or damage to life or property. Such object as gasoline tanks, propane tanks, butane tanks, flammable or combustible liquid tanks or container, compressed gas tanks, cylinders and any other dangerous and hazardous object. 
(5)  Article 12 Sec. 12.4 of the code be and is hereby stricken in its entirety and the following section inserted in lieu thereof: 
Sec. 12.4. "Blasting Permits and Bond Required for Blasting Before a permit to do blasting as required under section 12.3a(3) shall be issued, according to the rules and procedures delineated below: 
"BLASTING PERMITS. 
Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or contractor wishing to engage in the use of explosives or blasting within the limits of the City of East Point first obtain a permit therefor. 
PRELIMINARY PERMIT. 
For such preliminary blasting permit, anyone seeking same shall first post a bond or a certified copy of a liability insurance policy in the minimum amount of $50,000 property damage per individual per occurrence, $100,000 aggregate property damage per occurrence and $300,000 bodily injury per person per occurrence with an aggregate bodily injury of $300,000 per occurrence or in such additional amount as may be deemed necessary by the fire chief, said bond or insurance policy shall be in a form payable for any damages arising from such preliminary test explosions and all damages arising from subsequent blasting operations if the production blasting permit issues. 
Before commencing initial test explosions a survey shall be conducted of all structures (where permitted by owner) contiguous to the blasting area and also other structures possibly endangered, based on location and/or condition. Color photographs are to be taken of typical conditions in each structure to reflect its condition prior to blasting. All exposed structures shall be carefully protected from the effects of the blasts and all blasts shall be covered with blasting mats, dirt, heavy timbers or other suitable material. The blasting shall be done by experienced workmen. Any damage done shall be promptly repaired by the contractor at his own expense. All blasting supplies shall be stored in a manner approved by the State Fire Marshal and a watchman shall be stationed at all times at the place of the storage. 
Care shall be taken for the initial test explosions and all subsequent explosions to minimize ground vibrations with a maximum peak particle velocity, as measured at the nearest structure, not to exceed 2.0 inches per second. The over pressure (noise or concussion) shall be minimized and sufficient stemming and matting used to prevent over pressure in excess of 120 db. Precaution shall be taken to minimize flying rock and sufficient matting used to prevent rocks from striking any person or structure. 
The preliminary permit shall be issued for the purposes of making initial test explosions at which time vibration recording instruments shall be used on the initial test explosions, and all others deemed necessary to determine proper blasting procedures. These instruments shall be of the type which records on direct-reading tape the three (3) components of velocity. The analysis of these recordings are to be signed by a registered, professional engineer licensed in the State of Georgia. The tapes and all other recorded documentary information are to be filed with the Fire Department at the time of making application for the blasting permit. Blasting is not to be conducted which will produce a scale distance less than previously recorded for at least three (3) different explosions deemed to be safe. The scale distance is to be determined by the distance from the shot to the nearest structure subject to potential damage from ground vibrations. 
Overpressure (concussion) is to be recorded on a direct recording tape, preferably at the same recording as the vibration. The instrument used for measuring concussion shall be the type specifically designed for impact type overpressure from explosions. 
For initial test shots under the preliminary blasting permits, care shall be taken to assure that ground vibrations with a maximum peak particle velocity, as measured at the nearest structure, do not exceed 1.0 inches per second. 
In the initial testing phase of explosion or blasting operations, prior to instrumentation, a scale distance of fifty (50) for residential structures, and a scale distance of twenty-five (25) for commercial and engineered structures or Numerically greater may be used to determine the maximum charge weight per delay interval of seventeen milliseconds or greater. (NOTE: A commercial or engineered structure to qualify for the scaled distance limitation of twenty-five (25) under the above regulation is one in which the load bearing frame is of steel or reinforced concrete with no inclusions of wall or ceilings for residential type construction, i.e., plastic walls or ceilings supported by studs or joist or rafters of wood, commonly associated with what is commonly known as "carpenter construction." All scale distance and blasting shall conform with standards and formulations set forth in table 1, attached hereto. 
All blast testing vibration and seismographic equipment shall conform to the standards and procedures set forth in table 2, attached hereto and which is by reference incorporated herein and made a part hereof. 
For preliminary testing, blasting and all production blasting, records shall be maintained in conformance with the information required on Table 3, attached hereto and which is by reference incorporated herein and made a part hereof. 
All blasting, whether preliminary testing or production blasting, shall conform with the safety standards set forth on Table 4, attached hereto and which is by reference incorporated herein and made a part hereof. 
Upon completion of tests, blasting and after certification by an engineer, it shall be submitted to the Fire Department of the City of East Point for approval and issuance of a production blasting permit and setting of a bond and/or liability insurance policy. It is required before the issuance of a production blasting permit that said bond or certified copy of liability blasting insurance be filed with the Fire Chief of the City of East Point. Said bond or blasting liability insurance policy shall on its face become payable for payment for any damages arising from such permitted blasting. Upon furnishing of all of said items and establishment of the amount of the bond or blasting liability insurance policy, the Fire Chief of the City of East Point shall issue a production blasting permit." 
TABLE 1 
DEFINITIONS 
1.  SCALED DISTANCE is defined as the product obtained by dividing the distance (in feet) to the nearest building structure by the square root of the weight of explosive per time delay in pounds. 
2.  BLASTER is any person who, engaging in a blasting operation decides hole size, spacing, or depth; decides total quantity of explosive; decides quantity of explosive in each hole; and/or decides timing delays to be used. Such person must be present when the charge is detonated and either physically detonates the charge or gives the order to detonate the charge. 
BLASTING STANDARDS 
A.  In all blasting operations, except as hereinafter otherwise provided, the maximum peak particle velocity of the ground motion in any direction shall not exceed two inches per second at the immediate location of any dwelling house, public building, school, church, commercial or institutional building. 
B.  This ground velocity limit is not construed to mean on property owned, leased, or contracted by the blaster or blaster's company or on property on which the owner gives a written waiver. 
C.  No two consecutive subcharges within any charge shall be separated by a time delay of less than seventeen milliseconds. 
D.  The standard table for the maximum charge per delay period shall be for distances greater than 300 feet generated by the following formula: 
W =( D / 50 ) 2 
Where W is the weight of explosive in lbs and D is the distance to the nearest dwelling house, public building, school, church, commercial or institutional building in feet. On sites where the City decides it necessary to comply with the provisions of the law this formula may be altered. 
E.  For the purpose of well shooting below 100 ft., the table shall be generated by the following formula: 
W =( D / 50 ) 3 
Where W is the total weight of explosives in the hole and D is the distance from the charge to the nearest dwelling house, public building, school, church, commercial institutional building. 
F.  If on a particular site the peak ground particle continuously exceeds ½ inch per second after a period of one (1) second following the maximum ground particle velocity, the City shall require the total time delay of blasting operations to be less than 200 milliseconds or the charge per delay be reduced so that this limit is complied with. 
G.  For distances less than 300 feet, the following table shall be used: 
ACTUAL DISTANCE IN FEET 	POUNDS PER DELAY INTERVAL OF 8 MILLISECONDS OR GREATER 
 5-10 	1/8 lb. 
11-15 	¼ lb. 
16-20 	½ lb. 
21-25 	¾ lb. 
26-30 	1.0 lb. 
31-300 	1 lb. + 1/8 lb. for each foot of distance above 30 feet. 
 
Less than 5 feet the total charge should not exceed 1/8 lb. 
TABLE 2 
TESTING EQUIPMENT 
A.  If a blaster decides that the table provided by the City is too conservative, or limiting, he may on 15 days notification to the Department of Mines and Minerals use seismograph measurements and increase the charge per delay period, provided the velocity of 2 inches per second limit is not violated. He must use the seismograph on every shot thereafter so long as the table is not being complied with. If the blaster decides to return to the use of the table, he may do so by notifying the department 15 days in advance. 
B.  If a blaster considers the table too limiting or too conservative, for his particular area, he may upon submission of seismograph reports, petition for a modified table for blasting operation at that particular site but in no case shall the department allow a table that would permit velocities above the 2 inch per second limit. 
C.  In making a seismograph determination of the velocity at a particular position, the following formula shall be used: 
V = V o D<inf>o</inf> / D 1.5 
Where V o is the maximum ground particle velocity at the seismograph, D o is the distance from the blast, and D is the distance from the blast to the position in question and in the same general direction. The distance D o may not be greater than D, and D cannot be more than five (5) times D o . This determined velocity at the site of any dwelling house, public building, school, church, commercial or institutional building shall not exceed the two (2) inches per second limit. 
D.  In seismic tests for compliance or petition, the analysis of seismic data shall be conducted by a completely independent company, one not related to the company performing the blasting or for whom the blasting is being performed, under the direction of a professional engineer registered in Georgia. 
E.  A direct reading velocity instrument shall be approved only if it has a frequency range of 5 cycles per second to 150 cycles per second or greater, a velocity range from zero to 2.0 in/sec. or greater, adheres to design criteria for portable seismographs as outlined in USBM RI-5708, USBM RI-6487. 
F.  Instruments of both the direct reading velocity type and the displacement type are approved for use as follows: 
(1)  Particle velocity reading may be calculated from results obtained by a displacement instrument or obtained from an approved direct reading velocity instrument in any blasting operation where all of the following conditions exist: 
(a)  Recording distance is over 200 feet from the blast; 
(b)  Scaled distance is numerically greater than 25; 
(c)  Frequency range is 40 cycles per second or less. 
(2)  A direct reading velocity instrument will be required in any blasting operation where all of the following conditions exist: 
(a)  Recording distance is less than 200 ft. from the blast; 
(b)  Scaled distance is numerically less than 50. 
(3)  A direct reading velocity instrument will be required in any blasting operation where all the following conditions exist: 
(a)  Recording distance is more than 200 ft. from the blast; 
(b)  Scaled distance is numerically less than 25. 
(4)  A direct reading velocity instrument will be required in any blasting operation where all of the following conditions exist: 
(a)  Recording distance is more than 200 ft. from the blast; 
(b)  Frequency range is in excess of 40 cycles per second. 
Scaled distance is defined as 
D;sub§\sub;- <sqrt / D ;W> 
Where D is the actual distance in feet and W is the weight of explosives in pounds per delay period of seventeen milliseconds or greater. 
TABLE 3 
RECORDS 
A record of each blast shall be kept. All records including seismograph reports shall be retained at least two years and shall be available for inspection by the City and shall contain the following minimum data: 
(1)  Name of Company or Contractor. 
(2)  Location, date and time of blast. 
(3)  Name, signature and license number of blaster in charge. 
(4)  Type of material blasted. 
(5)  Number of holes, burden and spacing. 
(6)  Diameter and depth of holes. 
(7)  Types of explosives used. 
(8)  Total amount of explosives used. 
(9)  Maximum amount of explosives per delay period of eight (8) milliseconds or greater. 
(10)  Method of firing and type of circuit. 
(11)  Direction and distance in feet to nearest dwelling house, public building, school, church, commercial or institutional building neither owned nor leased by the person conducting the blasting. 
(12)  Weather conditions. 
(13)  Type and height or length of stemming. 
(14)  If mats or other protections were used. 
(15)  Type of delay electric blasting caps used and delay periods used. 
(16)  The person taking the seismograph reading shall accurately indicate exact location of seismograph if used, and shall also show the distance of seismograph from blast. 
(17)  Seismograph records, where required: 
(a)  Name of person and firm analyzing the seismograph record. 
(18)  Maximum number of holes per delay period of seventeen (17) milliseconds or greater. 
TABLE 4 
SAFETY STANDARDS 
A.  When blasting operations, other than those conducted at a fixed site as a part of any industry or business operated at such site, are to be conducted within two hundred feet of a pipe line, the blaster or person in charge of the blasting operations shall take due precautionary measures for the protection of the line, and shall notify the owner of the line or his agent that such blasting operations are intended. 
B.  Blasting operations near streams shall be prohibited in all cases where the effect of the blasting is liable to change the course or channel of any stream without first obtaining a permit from the department which has been approved by the Division of Water in the Department of Natural Resources. 
C.  Mudcapping in blasting operations shall be permitted only where it would endanger the safety of the workmen to drill the rock or material to be blasted. If mudcapping is necessary, no more than ten pounds of explosives shall be used for each charge. 
D.  All trunk lines of detonating cord may be covered, except that trunk lines of detonating cord must be covered if located within eight hundred feet of any public highway, dwelling house, public building, school, church, commercial or institutional building. 
E.  In blasting operation, flying rocks shall not be allowed to fall greater than one-half the distance between the blast and a dwelling house, public building, school, church, commercial or institutional building. Protective material should be used to insure this limit. 
F.  When operating within 800 feet of a highway, if there is chance of flying rock landing on the highway, traffic must be stopped at a safe distance. Blasted material shall not be thrown on a public highway in sufficient quantity to impede traffic, and any material thrown on a highway must be removed promptly. 
G.  The contractor or operator as well as the blaster shall be responsible for the conduct of blasting on any operation. 
H.  These regulations are in no way intended to relieve the contractor or operator or other persons or responsibility and liability under any other laws.

e.  Establishment of limits of districts (zones) in which storage of Explosives and Blasting Agents is to be prohibited. 
The limits referred to in section 12.5b are all areas (zones) within the City except areas zoned industrial. Any amounts stored in industrial areas will require the City of East Point Councilmatic approval.

(8)  Article 16, Section 16.22 a Restricted Locations of the East Point Fire Prevention Code is hereby amended by adding a new section to be numbered 16.22 a (1). 
Sec. 16.22a. 
(1) Establishment of limits of Districts (zones) in which storage of flammable liquids; Class I liquids in outside aboveground tanks to be prohibited. 
The limits referred to in Sec. 16.22a of the East Point Fire Prevention Code in which storage of flammable liquid; Class I liquids in outside above ground tanks is prohibited as are all areas (zones) within the City of East Point except Industrial Zone areas. Any above ground flammable liquid; Class I liquid storage tank shall be protected by an approved automatic fixed extinguishment system. 
(9) Article 16, Section 16.23 d. Abandonment or Removal of Underground Tanks. 
Establishment of time limits referred to in Section 16.23 d. (1) (a) of the East Point Fire Prevention Code is further amended by adding to Section 16.23 d. (1) (a) the following: 
If permanent abandonment of underground tanks is the intent of the owner, the tanks must be removed from the ground within sixty (60) days of abandonment. 
If the tank is not to be abandoned permanently, they must be filled with water. Most of the gasoline can be removed from the tank by the regular station pump. The few gallons usually remaining below the end of the suction pipe can be pumped out with a pitcher pump through a suction hose inserted in the fill opening. Water is then introduced into the fill pipe of the tank and is permitted to overflow the fill pipe for some time, so that the remaining gasoline, which is lighter than water, will be washed away. The water level should be such as to insure that all parts of the tank are filled with water. Periodic inspections should be made to insure that water is kept at the proper level, as loss may occur due to evaporation or leakage. After each inspection the fill cap and any other opening cover, except the vent, should be locked or screwed down tight. 
When the use of any tank is discontinued for more than twelve (12) months, it shall be considered permanently abandoned and must be removed. 
(10) Article 16. Sec. 16.61 Bulk Plants. 
Location of Plants of the East Point Fire Prevention Code is hereby amended by adding a new section to be numbered Section 16.61.1. and reads as follows: 
Sec. 16.61.1. 
The limits referred to in section 16.61 of the East Point Fire Prevention Code, in which new bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids are prohibited are all areas (zones) within the city except Industrial zoned areas. Any above ground flammable liquid; Class I liquid; or combustible liquid new bulk storage tanks shall be protected by approved, automatic fixed extinguishing system and will require the City of East Point Councilmatic approval.

(16) Article 28 of the East Point Fire Prevention code governing precaution against fire, general is hereby amended by adding a new section to be numbered 28.17, 28.18, 28.19, 28.20 and to read as follows: 
Sec. 28.17. Tar Heating Equipment. It is hereby prohibited for any person, firm or corporation to heat tar, asphalt, pitch or other combustible material in, on or within fifty (50) feet of any building, structure, combustible material, or substance for roofing, weatherproofing, waterproofing, or insulation purposes except in conformance with the following safety requirements: 
(a)  The fire prevention bureau shall be notified before any kettle or other container used for heating the above mentioned materials, shall be placed in, on, or within fifty (50) feet of any building, structure, combustible material or substance, and no such kettle or heating equipment shall be operated within any building, except by the written permission of the chief of fire prevention bureau of the City of East Point. 
(b)  There shall be a kettle operator experienced with the equipment involved, familiar with the fire hazards, the precautions to be observed, and the use of fire extinguishing facilities required, in attendance at the kettle at all times the kettle is being fired or heated, and so remain until the temperature of the kettle and its contents does not exceed three hundred fifty (350) degrees Fahrenheit as may be determined by a thermometer which shall be provided and maintained at or near the kettle at all times. 
(c)  There shall be at all times at or near the kettle and readily accessible to the operator, one approved Class B fire extinguisher with a minimum rating that equals or exceeds the Class B Hazard. At least one 20 B rated approved fire extinguisher. 
(d)  Not more than six hundred (600) pounds of combustible material or substance to be heated shall be stored within twenty-five (25) feet of any kettle while same is in operation. 
(e)  No kettle using flammable liquid for fuel shall be refueled while in operation and any flammable liquid placed within twenty-five (25) feet of a kettle shall be stored in an approved safety container which shall be kept sealed or closed at all times the kettle is in operation. 
(f)  No mop or other applicator which has been used or submerged in tar, pitch, asphalt or other combustible material or substance in the process of applying roofing, weather-proofing, waterproofing, or insulation shall be left overnight in, on or within twenty-five (25) feet of any building, structure, or combustible material or substance. 
(g)  Fired roofing kettles shall not be operated on roofs of buildings. 
(h)  All improved streets shall be protected from burning by use of sand and other noncombustible materials under roofing kettles. Streets shall be cleaned of all excess tar and other debris upon completion of work. 
(i)  No person shall use solid fuel or Class I flammable liquids as fuel for a roofing kettle. 
(j)  Compressed and liquefied gases shall be stored, handled, transported and used in accordance with applicable provisions of NFPA codes and standards. Storage and handling of compressed and liquefied gases not covered by NFPA codes and standards shall comply with applicable provisions of: Standards of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI); Code of Federal Regulations, Title 49, Parts 173 through 190 (transportation); Pressure Vessels, Section VIII, of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code (container fabrication); or the container fabrication specifications of the American Petroleum Institute. 
(16) Sec. 28.18. Vacant Structures. 
Every person owning, or in charge or control of, any vacant and/or fire damaged or unsafe building or structure shall remove therefrom all accumulations of flammable or combustible contents, waste, debris or rubbish and shall securely lock, barricade, or otherwise secure all doors, windows and other openings thereof. The premises shall be maintained free and clear of any waste or hazardous materials. 
(17) Sec. 28.19. 
Gas connections to stoves, heaters and other appliances shall be made by approved metal pipe or by approved metal tubing securely fastened in place, except that for devices which require a moveable connection, approved, flexible tubing may be used provided there is no shut-off on the device. 
(18) Sec. 28.20. Hazardous Gas in Balloons and Other Objects. 
It is prohibited to inflate toy balloons or other objects with any flammable, oxidizing, toxic, corrosive, or reactive gas including hydrogen. Air and inert gases, such as Nitrogen and Helium, are not prohibited for this purpose. It is prohibited to sell or to use toy balloons or objects so inflated. 
(19) Article 31, Section 8.8 is amended, to include AAI (Agricultural Ammonia Institute, Memphis, Tennessee) No. M-1, 1967 edition. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 18, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2038. - Modifications. 
The fire chief or the chief's designee shall have the powers to modify any of the provisions of the applicable codes upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or the owner's or lessee's duly appointed agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the fire chief or the chief's designee shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1959, § 10-5; Ord. No. 001-07, § 17, 1-16-07  
Sec. 6-2039. - Barbecue grills in multi-family dwellings. 
Georgia Law provides that no charcoal or liquefied petroleum gas or liquid fueled burners shall be kindled or maintained on balconies/patios or within ten (10) feet of combustible patios on ground floors. No grills may be used or stored in breezeways, balconies/patios, stairways, or exit access areas. The city further prohibits the use of grills, pits, or outside fireplaces on balconies or patios within ten (10) feet of patios or balconies in multifamily dwellings. 
(Code 1959, § 10-6; Ord. No. 001-07, § 19, 1-16-07)  
Sec. 6-2040. - Fees for response to false alarm. 
(a)  Automatic response alarm systems. For a fire response to any false alarm of an automatic response fire alarm system, the fire chief or the fire chief's designee shall charge and collect a fine from the person or business having or maintaining the automatic response alarm system on the premises owned or occupied by such person or business on and after the third alarm according to the fire department false alarm fee schedule. The fire department false alarm fee schedule shall be posted in the office of the city clerk and the city fire marshal. 
(B)  Independent alarm systems. For the second fire response within a calendar year to an alarm activation of an independent fire alarm system that proves to be false, the corrective actions to be taken are the same as prescribed in the previous section. On the third response to a premise within a calendar year, the independent alarm system shall be deemed a nuisance. Failure of the alarm user to abate such nuisance will make the alarm user subject to penalties and fines as provided for in the fire department false alarm fee schedule referenced above. 
(Ord. No. 001-07, § 20, 1-16-07)  
Secs. 6-20416-2043. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 001-07, § 21, adopted January 16, 2007, repealed former §§ 6-20416-2043 in their entirety. 
Former § 6-2041 pertained to notification of the fire department of inoperative fire safety equipment and derived from this codification.
