Any person engaged in the business of limousine carrier domiciled within the city shall obtain annually a business license as provided under Part 5 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of East Point. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 2, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5053. - Place of operation. 
The city shall not license any limousine carrier unless such carrier shall be operated from a commercial office independent of any private residence. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 2, 12-5-94)  
Secs. 11-505411-5064. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE C. - NON-EMERGENCY TRANSPORTATION[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Note See editor's note to Art. B of this chapter. Section numbers of Art. C have been renumbered by the editor to avoid duplication. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 11-5065. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, have the meanings as set out herein: 
(1)  Non-emergency transportation driver's permit shall mean the permission granted by the chief of police to a person to drive a non-emergency transportation vehicle upon the streets of the city. 
(2)  Non-emergency transportation vehicle shall mean any motor vehicle operated for hire, the destination of which is under the direction of the passenger transported therein, which is not a cab as defined under city ordinance or a limousine as defined under state law. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
DIVISION 2. - DRIVERS' PERMITS 
 
Sec. 11-5066. - Non-emergency vehicle driver's permit required. 
No person shall operate a non-emergency transportation vehicle for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or controls a non-emergency vehicle shall permit it to be so driven, unless the driver of the non-emergency vehicle shall first have obtained or have then in force a valid non-emergency vehicle driver's permit issued under this division. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5067. - Application for non-emergency vehicle driver's permit; required information; filing fee. 
(a)  An application for a non-emergency vehicle driver's permit shall be filed with the chief of police on forms provided by the police department, and the application shall be verified under oath and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers; 
(2)  Educational background of the applicant; and 
(3)  A concise history of his employment. 
(b)  Fingerprints of all applicants shall be taken by the police department. Applicants for permits to drive non-emergency vehicles shall file with the police department two (2) photographs, size two and one-half (2½) inches by two and three-fourths (2¾) inches. 
(c)  No permit shall be granted unless it shall appear that the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age and has been granted the appropriate state driver's license. 
(d)  Each application shall be accompanied by a certificate from a reputable physician of the city certifying that, in his opinion, the applicant is not affiliated with any disease or infirmity which would make him an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. At the time the application is filed, the applicant shall pay the city thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5068. - Current state motor vehicle operator's permit required. 
Before any application is finally passed on by the chief of police, the applicant shall show that he has a current motor vehicle operator's permit issued by the state. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5069. - Police investigation of applicant. 
The police department is charged with the duty of investigating all applications for permits to drive non-emergency transportation vehicles and to report to the chief of police the results of such investigation. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5070. - Authority of the chief of police to issue; persons eligible. 
The chief of police may issue a temporary driver's permit for any person to drive a non-emergency transportation vehicle within the city if the applicant has a state driver's license that has never been revoked, suspended, cancelled or modified and which does not show the holder thereof to have been convicted of operating an automobile while under the influence of any intoxicant or drugs or reckless driving within the last four (4) years; or any felony conviction within the last ten (10) years. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5071. - Temporary drivers' permits use for forty-five days authorized. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of a non-emergency transportation vehicle to drive in excess of forty-five (45) days on a temporary driver's permit. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5072. - Grounds for nonissuance and revocation. 
(a)  No driver's permit shall be issued if the applicant has been convicted of any of the following offenses: 
(1)  Manslaughter, or vehicular homicide, resulting from operating a motor vehicle; 
(2)  Driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquors or drugs. Any conviction under this subsection shall not be a bar to the issuance of a permit if the conviction occurred more than five (5) years prior to the date of application, or upon a recommendation of the chief of police more than three (3) years prior to the date of application for a permit; 
(3)  Any felony in the commission of which a motor vehicle is used; 
(4)  Failure to stop and render aid as required under the laws of this state, or leaving the scene of an accident as specified by the laws of this state; 
(5)  Perjury or false swearing in making any statement under oath in connection with this application for driver's permit; 
(6)  Convictions, or forfeiture of bail, not vacated, upon three (3) charges of a violation of the motor vehicle laws of this state within a period of twelve (12) months; 
(7)  Conviction of the violation of any law involving violence, theft or any form of stealing, or any crime involving moral turpitude that is reasonably related to the permit referred to herein, within five (5) years preceding the filing of the application for this permit; 
(8)  Repeated violations of the city ordinances which affect the safety of human life or limb on the streets of the city; or 
(9)  Possession by a non-emergency transportation vehicle operator within the vehicle of opened or unopened malt beverages, whiskey or wine, or of drugs or other stimulants not specifically prescribed for him by a medical doctor for his private use, or of stolen goods or any contraband property of any kind. 
(b)  Conviction of any of the above offenses is grounds for revocation of driver's permit. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5073. - Issuance of permits; duration; renewal fee. 
Upon approval of an application for a non-emergency transportation vehicle driver's permit, the city shall issue a permit to the applicant which shall bear the name, address, age, signature and photograph of the applicant. The permit shall be in effect for one (1) year from the date of issue. A permit for each year thereafter shall issue upon the payment of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) unless the license for the preceding year has been revoked. Duplicate permits may be obtained by the payment of the fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). Each permit set forth above shall be renewed on an annual basis by the last day of the month of its expiration each year.) 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5074. - Display of permit. 
Every driver licensed under this division shall have in his possession at all times his non-emergency transportation vehicle driver's permit and shall display the permit for inspection by a passenger upon the passenger's request. Failure of a driver to have the permit in his possession and/or to display it for inspection upon request shall be sufficient cause for revocation of the permit by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
Sec. 11-5075. - Duty of drivers to obey state laws and city ordinances and to have due regard for safety. 
The drivers of vehicles provided for in this article shall operate them in accordance with the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city. They shall have due regard for the safety, comfort and convenience of their passengers, and for the safety and careful transportation of property and the safety of the general public. Failure to do so will justify the chief of police's suspending or revoking a license. 
(Ord. No. 1090-94, § 3, 12-5-94)  
CHAPTER 6. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES AND ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, adopted Nov. 1, 1999, amended former Ch. 6 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 6 pertained to similar subject material and derived from Ord. No. 830-83, § 1, adopted Jan. 18, 1983. 
 
Sec. 11-6001. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article: 
Adult bookstore means a commercial establishment: 
(1)  Which as one of its principal business purposes offers for sale or rental, for any form of consideration, any of the following: 
a.  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, which depict or describe human genitals in the state of arousal, the cleft of the buttocks, anus, male or female genitals, or areola of the female breast or a state of dress which fails to opaquely cover the above described areas, buttocks anus, male sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law; 
b.  Instruments, devices, or paraphernalia which are designed for use in connection with sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law excluding condoms and other birth control and disease prevention products. 
(2)  Which regularly excludes all minors from the premises or section thereof because of the sexually explicit nature of the items sold, rented or displayed therein. 
Adult entertainment facility means any establishment which offers for commercial purposes on its premises: 
(1)  Acts or actions, actual or simulated, permitting, performing or engaging in, in person clothed or unclothed, on the premises: 
a.  Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts prohibited by law; 
b.  The touching, caressing or fondling, either of one's self or of another, of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitalia. 
(2)  Opportunity to view another person who appears live and unclothed or live and in such attire, lingerie, costume or clothing so as to expose, whether continually, intermittently or occasionally any portion of the female areola, any portion of the anus, vulva, genitalia, cleft of the buttocks, or attached male or female pubic hair. 
(3)  Showing or permitting the showing or viewing of films, still pictures, electronic reproductions, videographic or other visual images depicting masturbation or acts of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law and in which the unclothed contact of genitalia is clearly visible. 
Provided, however, that random acts of patrons or employees, whose actions do not constitute actions taken pursuant to encouragement or acquiescence of the management or ownership of the establishment and are not for a commercial purpose shall not constitute adult entertainment as defined in this section; provided that nothing herein shall be deemed to make legal any conduct that otherwise may be prohibited by law. 
Adult nightclubs means a bar, tavern, restaurant, cabaret or commercial establishment which regularly features: 
(1)  Persons who appear in a state of nudity in such a state of dress which fails to opaquely cover the cleft of the buttocks, anus, genitals, or areolas of the female breast; or 
(2)  Live performances which are characterized by the exposure of any portion of the anus, vulva or genitalia, cleft of the buttocks, or attached male or female pubic hair. 
(3)  Films, motion pictures, videos, slides or other photographic reproductions which are characterized by the depiction of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual act prohibited by law or any portion of the female areola, any portion of the anus, vulva or genitalia, cleft of the buttocks, or attached male or female pubic hair. 
Employee means an individual working or performing services for any sexually oriented business, including any independent contractor irrespective of whether said person is paid a salary or wage, contract rate or has the opportunity to obtain tips or prize money. 
Licensee means a person in whose name a license to operate a sexually oriented business has been issued, as well as individuals listed as an applicant on the application for a sexually oriented business license. 
Sexually oriented business means an adult bookstore, adult nightclub or adult entertainment facility. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6002. - Permitted locations. 
(a)  Sexually oriented businesses shall be allowed only in districts zoned I-2 Heavy Industrial District. 
(b)  Each sexually oriented business shall be prohibited from operating with any portion of its premises within a radius of two hundred (200) yards of any church, church book store, public park, public housing project, hospital, school (public or private), college, recreation center or residence. 
(c)  Each sexually oriented business shall be at least one thousand (1,000) feet from any other licensed sexually oriented business. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6003. - Advertising. 
No sexually oriented business shall advertise its location by signs more than six (6) inches in height placed on the front of the building which shall state the name of the business and hours of operation, only. No adult entertainment facility shall advertise its location with flashing or other kinds of lights, signs, banners or other devices intended to attract the attention of the general public, especially minors, to its location. Adult bookstores shall maintain all windows in a clear, unobstructed manner so as to provide an open and clear view throughout the interior of the book store. Adult entertainment facilities shall maintain all windows in a clear and unobstructed manner, so that the entire reception area, lobby, ticket sales area of the facility is open and clear to view by the public from all public thoroughfares. All rooms or cubicles are to be open when in use to inspection and view at all times from any and all hallways or access corridors leading thereto, it being the purpose of this requirement upon adult service establishments to create an environment that will not encourage patrons to solicit employees for acts that could cause revocation of this license. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6004. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a sexually oriented business without a valid license, issued by the city for the business, or to employ a person who is not licensed as a sexually oriented business employee as provided by subsection (b) of this section or who is not authorized to work or perform services pursuant to subsection (c) of this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be an employee of a sexually oriented business without a valid license. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to an employee of an adult bookstore, unless such bookstore is operated in combination with an adult nightclub, or to such adult bookstore's operator if the operator is not required to comply with sections 11-6001 through 11-6003. 
(c)  An applicant, for a sexually oriented business license and employee license shall file in person at the office of business license inspector, an application on a form prescribed and qualified according to the provisions of this chapter. The application shall be signed under oath by the applicant and notarized. The application shall include but not be limited to the following information: 
(1)  The full true name of the applicant and any other names used in the preceding five (5) years. 
(2)  Current residential mailing address and telephone number. 
(3)  If the application is for a sexually oriented business license, the name, business location, business mailing address and phone number of the proposed establishment. 
(4)  Written proof of age, in the form of a birth certificate, current driver's license with picture or other picture identification document issued by a government agency. 
(5)  A photograph of the applicant and two (2) sets of the applicant's complete fingerprints taken by a law enforcement agency. 
(6)  The effective dates and issuing jurisdictions of any license or permit relating to a sexually oriented business, whether any such license or permit has been denied, revoked or suspended and, if so, the reasons therefore. 
(7)  All criminal charges, complaints, information or indictments in the preceding five (5) years which resulted in a conviction, plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere. 
(8)  The name and address of the statutory agent or other agent authorized to receive service of process. 
The information provided pursuant to paragraphs (1) through (8) of this subsection shall be supplemented in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested to the business license inspector within ten (10) working days of a change of circumstances which would render the information originally submitted false or incomplete. 
(d)  The application for a sexually oriented business license shall be accompanied by a sketch or diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including the total number feet of floor space. 
(e)  If the applicant is not an individual, each officer, director, general partner or other person who will participate directly in decisions relating to the management of the business shall sign the application for a license as applicant. Each applicant must be qualified under sections 11-6004 and 11-6005 and each applicant shall be considered a licensee if a license is granted. 
(f)  The information provided by an applicant in connection with the application for a license under this chapter shall be maintained by the business license inspector on a confidential basis, except that such information may be disclosed to other governmental agencies in connection with a law enforcement or public safety function. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6005. - Issuance of license. 
(a)  The business license inspector shall approve or deny the issuance of license under this chapter within thirty (30) days after receipt of a proper application. Said application shall be approved unless: 
(1)  An applicant is under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(2)  An applicant or an applicant's spouse is delinquent in the payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines, or penalties assessed against or imposed upon the applicant in relation to a sexually oriented business and/or adult entertainment establishment or arising out of any other business activity owned or operated by the applicant or the applicant's spouse and licensed by the city. 
(3)  An applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form. 
(4)  An applicant or an applicant's spouse has been convicted or pled nolo contendere of a violation of a provision of this chapter, other than operating without a license, within two (2) years immediately preceding the application. Appeals of a conviction shall be of no effect. 
(5)  Failure to pay license application fee. 
(6)  An applicant or proposed establishment is in violation of the zoning ordinances of the City of East Point. 
(7)  An applicant or an applicant's spouse: 
a.  Has been convicted or pled nolo contendere to any of the following offenses if committed in this state or any offense committed outside this state would constitute one of the following offenses: 
1.  As described in O.C.G.A. Chapter 16: 
(i)  Public indecency 
(ii)  Rape; statutory rape 
(iii)  Sodomy; aggravated sodomy 
(iv)  Enticement for indecent purposes 
(v)  Child molestation 
(vi)  Sexual assault 
(vii)  Bestiality 
(viii)  Necrophilia 
(ix)  Prostitution, keeping a place of prostitution 
(x)  Pimping 
(xi)  Pandering 
(xii)  Masturbation for hire 
(xiii)  Fornication 
(xiv)  Adultery 
(xv)  Incest 
(xvi)  Sexual battery 
(xvii)  Sexual abuse 
2.  As described in O.C.G.A. Title 43 occupying rooms for immoral purposes. 
3.  An offense involving moral turpitude. 
b.  Is registered, under O.C.G.A. § 42-1-12, within the State Sexual Offender Registry. 
c.  Has been, within a period of fifteen (15) years immediately prior to the filing of the application, convicted of or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving lottery, gambling illegal possession or sale of any narcotics, drugs or chemicals for which the sale thereof is controlled or prohibited by law, the control of the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages, prostitution, solicitation of prostitution, sodomy, solicitation of sodomy, masturbation for hire, or receiving stolen property. 
(b)  Appeal of a conviction shall be of no effect on the disqualification of the applicant or applicant's spouse. 
(c)  The license, if granted, shall state on its face the name of the person or persons to whom it is granted, the number of the license issued to that applicant, the expiration date, and, if the license is for a sexually oriented business, the address of the sexually oriented business. A sexually oriented business employee license shall contain a photograph of the license. All sexually oriented business licenses shall be clearly posted within the business. 
A sexually oriented business employee shall keep the employee's license on his or her person or on the premises where the licensee is working and shall produce such license for inspection upon request by an officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6006. - Fees. 
(a)  The annual nonrefundable application fee for a sexually oriented business license is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). The annual application fee for a sexually oriented business employee license is one hundred dollars ($100.00). A year shall be January first to December 31 and such fees shall not be prorated. 
(b)  Application for a sexually oriented business license does not exempt the applicant from adhering to all other laws of the City of East Point and the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6007. - Inspection. 
(a)  An applicant, operator or license shall permit entry by officers of the city and any other federal, state, or county agency, in performance of any functions connected with the enforcement of this chapter, to inspect the premises of a sexually oriented business for the purpose of insuring compliance with this chapter, at all times the facility is open for business or occupied. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a license, operator or employee of a sexually oriented business to refuse to permit a law enforcement officer or any agency enumerated in subsection (a) of the section to inspect the premises at any time the premises is occupied or open for business. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6008. - Suspension. 
The license inspector shall suspend a sexually oriented business license for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days if she determines that: 
(1)  Licensee or an employee of the licensee violated this article or any applicable provision of the East Point Zoning Ordinance. 
(2)  Licensee refused inspection of the sexually oriented business premises. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6009. - Revocation. 
(a)  In addition to the penalties prescribed herein, the mayor and council, upon becoming aware of an alleged violation of this article or of any state law regulating sexually oriented businesses or controlled substances on the licensed premises, may notify the license holder to appear for a hearing at such time and place, as established by the city council, to answer to charges of the alleged violation and to show cause why his license should not be suspended or revoked. At least ten (10) days written notice shall be provided to a license holder of any hearing under this section. 
(b)  Any conviction, plea of guilty or plea of nolo contendere for violating a provision of this article, or of the city zoning ordinance, other city ordinances or of state laws relating to the conduct of the business or to alcoholic beverages shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of a sexually oriented business license by the city council. 
(c)  The provisions of this section are independent of any other actions taken against the licensee for violation of laws of the city, state or county. 
(d)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the revocation of the license. 
(e)  Any revocation may be appealed to the superior court of Fulton County within thirty (30) days from revocation. Failure to appeal within the allotted time shall make such revocation final. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6010. - Transfer of license. 
A licensee shall not transfer his license to another, nor shall a licensee operate a sexually oriented business under the authority of a license at any place other than the address designated in the application. Any change in ownership or management shall be cause of issuance of a new license. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6011. - Signage; loitering and exterior lighting and monitoring requirements. 
(a)  No sign advertising a sexually oriented business may be larger than four (4) feet in width and three (3) feet in height. Such signs shall not be placed above the height of the building such facility is located, nor shall it be filled with neon gases or the like; such signs shall state only the name of the business, which shall contain no obscene language under the law. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the operation of a sexually oriented business to: 
(1)  Initiate and enforce a no loitering policy within the external boundaries of the real property upon which the sexually oriented business is located. 
(2)  Post conspicuous signs stating that no loitering is permitted on such property. 
(3)  Provide adequate lighting of the exterior premises to provide for visual inspection or video monitoring to prohibit loitering. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6012. - Penalties. 
A person who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
Sec. 11-6013. - Regulations pertaining specifically to sexually oriented business featuring live nudity or live performances. 
(a)  It shall unlawful to permit the sale of alcoholic beverages in sexually oriented businesses featuring live nudity or live performances which are characterized by the exposure of human genitals, the cleft of the buttocks, anus, male or female pubic hair or areola of the female breast. 
(b)  An employee may not touch the breast, buttocks, or genitals of a patron, nor may a patron touch the breast, buttocks or genitals of an employee. 
(c)  A person below the age of eighteen (18) years may not observe or appear in a state of nudity or in such live performances on the premises of a sexually oriented business. 
(Ord. No. 1192-99, § 1, 11-1-99)  
CHAPTER 7. - CABLE TELEVISION[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference Obtaining utilities and cable television service by device, trick or theft of equipment, § 13-1017. 
 
Sec. 11-7001. - Regulations of cable television industry adopted. 
(a)  This ordinance [Ord. No. 1191-99] shall be known as the "City of East Point Cable Ordinance." 
(b)  This ordinance is established to create comprehensive cable television regulations to govern the franchising and operation of cable systems within the City of East Point, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 944A, § 1, 7-21-80; Ord. No. 1191-99, §§ 1.1. 1.2, 10-4-99) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 1191-99, adopted Oct. 4, 1999, enacted new cable television regulations for the city. Former cable television regulations derived from Ord. No. 944A, adopted July 21, 1980. The regulations of Ord. No. 1191-99 have not been set out at length herein but are available in the offices of the city.  
CHAPTER 8. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 
 
Sec. 11-8001. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, certain words are defined as follows: 
(a)  Peddler. Any person traveling from place to place, house to house, or in or along the streets, within the city limits, carrying, conveying, or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, or personal property of any nature, offering and exposing them for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, sells or offers the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. 
(b)  Solicitor. Any person traveling from place to place, house to house, or in or along the streets within the city limits, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, or personal property of any nature, for future delivery or for services to be performed in the future, whether or not such individual carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of the sale, or whether or not such vendor is collecting advance payment on the sales. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8002. - License required. 
It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler or solicitor within the city, without having a valid license issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8003. - Exemptions. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Any person having a bakery or dairy route. 
(2)  Any person engaged in solicitation for noncommercial purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8004. - Application for license. 
Applications for licenses by solicitors and peddlers shall be made to the City of East Point police department, shall be sworn and in written form, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and physical description of applicant; 
(2)  Address of applicant; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business to be conducted and the goods to be sold, and if the goods are farm or orchard products, a statement whether they are produced or grown by the applicant; 
(4)  The name and address of the person, firm or corporation which the applicant represents; 
(5)  The names and addresses of at least two references as to the applicant's moral character, honesty, and integrity; 
(6)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(7)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the vehicle, together with the state vehicle license number; 
(8)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, and if so, the nature of the offense, and the punishment or penalty assessed; 
(9)  Such other information as the chief of police may deem necessary for the proper police protection of the city. 
An applicant for permit shall also be fingerprinted by the police department and shall supply the police department a current photograph within two (2) days prior to the date of the filing of the application. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8005. - License fees. 
The fee for solicitors and peddlers shall be: 
(1)  Ten dollars ($10.00) per day, or two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year for all peddlers and solicitors. 
(2)  Additional licenses may be issued to employees of a license holder on the payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year for each employee after approval and investigation by chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8006. - Issuance or denial of license. 
The police department shall investigate the application and shall issue or deny the license in writing within seven (7) days after the application has been made. If the license is denied, the reasons for the denial shall be given in writing. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8007. - Right of appeal following denial. 
If a license is denied, the applicant may appeal the denial in the manner provided in East Point City Code section 11-1011(d), the city ordinance relating to license appeals to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8008. - Transfer of license. 
Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be assigned or transferred, nor shall they be used by any person other than the person to whom they were issued. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8009. - Suspension and revocation of license. 
Licenses issued under this ordinance may be suspended or revoked for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraudulent obtaining of the license by giving false information on any substantial matter in the application for the license; 
(2)  Any violation of the provisions of this chapter; 
(3)  Conviction of the license holder of any felony or crime involving moral turpitude; 
(4)  Conducting the soliciting or peddling in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to be a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the people of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8010. - Right of appeal following suspension or revocation. 
Any licensee having his or her license suspended or revoked under this ordinance may appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city council a written statement of the grounds for appeal within thirty (30) days after notice of such suspension or revocation. The city council shall set the time and place for hearing such appeal, and notice of the time and place shall be given at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8011. - License to be carried. 
Every peddler or solicitor, at all times while engaged in peddling or soliciting shall carry the license issued to him or her under this ordinance, together with any other license required of him or her by the provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8012. - Vehicle tag. 
Every vehicle used for peddling or soliciting shall display, in a conspicuous place on the vehicle, a windshield tag or sticker furnished by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8013. - Regulations. 
The following rules and regulations shall be complied with by every peddler or solicitor: 
(1)  It is unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to sell or attempt to sell any goods, wares, or merchandise by means of any shout, outcry, sound, speaker or amplifier, or any instrument or device which can be heard for a distance greater than two hundred (200) feet, on any of the streets, alleys, parks, or other public places of the city or on any private premises in the city. 
(2)  A peddler or solicitor shall not have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, shall not be permitted to operate in any congested area where his or her operations might impede or inconvenience the public. 
(3)  It is unlawful for any person to solicit or peddle before the hour of 9:00 a.m. of any day, or after the hour of 7:00 p.m. of any day. 
(4)  It is unlawful for any peddler or solicitor for the purpose of peddling or soliciting to ring the bell, knock at the door or enter into any building when a sign has been posted on the building stating "No soliciting or peddling," or words to that effect. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
Sec. 11-8014. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or in which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 1188-99, § 1, 8-16-99)  
CHAPTER 10. - PROOF OF IDENTIFICATION 
 
Secs. 11-10001. - Valid proof of identification established. 
This chapter is created to establish that the City of East Point, Georgia recognizes the Mexican Matricula Consular, issued by the Mexican government, as sufficient and valid proof of identification for any City of East Point, Georgia government transaction when providing a positive identification is required. 
(Ord. No. 006-05, § 1, 5-16-05)  
CHAPTER 11. - ANIMAL CARE FACILITIES 
 
Sec. 11-11001. - Kennels and breeding and boarding establishments. 
(a)  Definitions: 
(1)  Kennel for the purposes of the Ordinance shall mean any buildings or structures or parts thereof or places used for the keeping of one or more dogs or other animals for breeding, boarding, treatment or for sale. 
(2)  Breeding and boarding establishments shall mean any premises (including a private dwelling) where more than two (2) breeding bitches are kept for the purpose of breeding for sale or any establishment that takes in animals for boarding for profit. 
(3)  Other animal shall mean any animal, other than a dog, which is kept as a household pet, but does not mean animals commonly known as livestock. 
(b)  No person shall, in the City of East Point, operate, own or control a kennel or breeding and boarding establishment unless a license to do so is procured. 
(c)  Every application for a license shall be in writing and shall state the name of the owner or operator, the location or proposed location of the kennel or breeding and boarding establishment, a description of the kennel or breeding and boarding establishment and outside area and runs intended to be used for dogs or other animals and the breeds and approximate number of dogs or animals to be kept. 
(d)  No license shall be issued for any kennel or breeding and boarding establishment at a location where, by reason of nuisance, noise or health, it would be undesirable to have such a facility. 
(e)  Every person who applies for such a license shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  No part of a kennel or breeding and boarding establishment shall be constructed or maintained closer than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the property line of any other kennel or breeding and boarding establishment. 
(2)  No part of a kennel or breeding and boarding establishment shall be constructed or maintained closer than 75-feet from any residential zoning district. 
(3)  Where a kennel or breeding and boarding establishment forms part of, or is physically attached to a building used for human habitation or to which the public have access, such kennel or breeding and boarding establishment shall have a concrete or other impermeable floor with a drain opening constructed as a plumbing fixture provided, however that the dogs or other animals may be kept in adequately, sized cages constructed solely of metal or wire or partly of metal and partly of wire and having metal or other impermeable bottoms; or kept in a matter approved by the director of planning and zoning. 
(4)  Where dogs or other animals are permitted to use an outside area, as part of a kennel or breeding and boarding establishment, there shall be constructed around such area a fence which may be chain link having a height of a least six (6) feet; the wall of an adjacent building may be included as part of the fenced in area. 
(5)  No animal shall be allowed outside for "runs" between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(f)  Upon consideration of the application, if council decides there may be sufficient grounds to refuse to grant the license, the applicant shall be given written notice thereof which shall set forth the grounds for denial. The applicant upon written request to the clerk, given within seven (7) days of the date of receiving the aforesaid notice, shall have the right to make representations to the council respecting the matter and shall be notified of the date of the meeting of council at which the application will be further considered. After holding such hearing for this purpose, or if no request for same is received from the applicant, the council may then decide to grant or refuse the license and the applicant will be notified of such decision. 
(g)  A license shall be issued for a period from January 1st to December 31st of each year and shall be renewed by May 15th in each calendar year. The fee for such license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(h)  Every person who hold a kennel or breeding and boarding establishment license shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  The license shall be displayed in a prominent place within the facility. 
(2)  Keep the dogs or other animals in a sanitary, well bedded, well ventilated, naturally lighted, clean quarters and maintain and keep such quarters at a healthful temperature at all times. 
(3)  Adequately feed and water the animals periodically each day and keep same in a clean, healthy condition. 
(4)  Meet and maintain all standards as required by the Georgia Department of Agriculture and keep the facility in good standing with said State regulating authority. 
(5)  Allow the chief building official and his/her designee or other persons as appointed by council to conduct inspections. 
(Ord. No. 003-08, § 2, 2-18-08)

Ch. 1. General Provisions 
Ch. 2. Stopping, Standing and Parking 
Ch. 3. Pedestrians

Cross reference Police department, § 6-1001 et seq.; school crossing guards, § 6-1071 et seq.; ambulances, § 11-4001 et seq.; vehicles for hire, § 11-5001 et seq.; railroads, § 3-3001 et seq.; traffic control for street and highway construction maintenance operations and utility work, § 13-4001 et seq. 
 
CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 915-86, § 1, adopted Aug, 4, 1986, repealed former Ch. 1, §§ 12-100112-1008, which pertained to general provisions regarding motor vehicles and traffic. Former § 12-1008 derived from Ord. No. 721-80, § 1, enacted Sept. 2, 1980, and the remainder of the provisions of former Ch. 1 did not contain history notation. Subsequently, Ord. No. 919-86, adopted Aug. 4, 1986, enacted a new Ch. 1, §§ 12-100112-1010, to read as herein set out. 
 
Sec. 12-1001. - Uniform rules of the road adopted by reference; penalties for violation. 
(a)  Pursuant to Georgia Traffic Law, Georgia Code of Title 40-1-1, 40-2-1 to 40-2-133, 40-3-1 to 40-3-95, 40-4-1 to 40-4-45, 40-5-1 to 40-5-124, 40-6-1 to 40-6-395, 40-7-1 to 40-7-6, 40-8-1 to 40-8-221, 40-9-1 to 40-9-103, 40-11-1 to 40-11-8, 40-13-1 to 40-13-64, 40-14-1 to 40-14-16, Title 33-34-1 to 33-32-7, Title 16-70-40 to 16-70-48, Title 32-1-1 to 32-1-11, 32-6-1 to 32-6-30, 32-6-50 to 32-6-51 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the City of East Point with like effect as if recited herein. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by Georgia State Law, every person convicted of violation of any provision of this code shall be punished according to the provisions of section 1-1006 of the Code of Ordinances, but in no event shall such fine or imprisonment exceed those provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-1002. - Temporary traffic regulations or controls. 
The East Point Police Department is hereby authorized to make temporary rules regulating traffic including but not limited to detours, lane closures, road closures in areas of accidents, parades, congested areas, other large public assemblages and areas that must be closed for public safety reasons. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-1003. - Speed limits. 
The maximum speed at which any motor vehicle can be operated shall be set and established by ordinance of the mayor and city council. A sign shall be clearly posted in each direction of the street stating the speed limit. Streets having no posted speed limit sign will be set at twenty-five (25) miles per hour maximum. It shall be unlawful and violation for any person to operate a motor vehicle in excess of such established or posted speed limits. This shall not apply to marked and permitted emergency vehicle in the performance of their official duties and on emergency calls. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-1004. - Obedience to stop and yield signs required. 
(a)  Stop signs. The driver of any vehicle shall obey all stop signs placed in accordance to the Manual on Uniform Control Devices (MUTCD). The driver shall bring his vehicle to a full stop and then proceed if the right-of-way is clear. 
(b)  Yield signs. The driver of any vehicle must yield right-of-way at yield signs. Exceptions to this section are granted to authorized emergency vehicles however, the authorized emergency driver must exercise due care at intersections. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-1005. - Obedience to traffic signals required. 
Obedience to traffic signals requires the driver of any motor vehicle shall obey any traffic signal located within the City of East Point. 
(a)  Green indications mean proceed through or turn right and left unless a sign at such place prohibits either turn. 
(b)  Yellow indications give warning that the related green movement is terminated and that a red indication will be exhibited immediately. Any driver who enters the intersection on a yellow indication does so at their own risk. 
(c)  Red indications signal the driver to stop completely at a clearly marked stop line and if there is no stop line, before entering the crosswalk on the rear side, and if no crosswalk is painted, to stop before entering the intersection. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-1006. - One-way streets. 
It is a violation for any driver to go the wrong way on a one-way street. One-way streets should be clearly marked with striping, arrow, and signs at intersections or where appropriate. Mayor and council shall designate one-way streets by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-1007. - U-turns prohibited. 
No vehicle shall be turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any curve, upon the crest of a grade where such vehicle cannot be seen by the driver of another vehicle approaching from either direction, where such turn cannot be made in safety without interfering with other traffic, or where a U-turn is prohibited by a traffic sign. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-1008. - Traffic signs, street markings and signals; authority. 
(a)  Traffic signs, striping, street marking, and traffic control signals shall conform to specifications in the current approved Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) adopted by the Georgia Department of Transportation Board. All signs, signals, and striping required hereunder for a particular purpose shall be made and placed in accordance with the MUTCD. All traffic control devices now in place and so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this part shall be official traffic control devices for the City of East Point. 
(b)  The East Point Police Department Traffic Division is hereby given authority to ensure compliance with the MUTCD in relation to street striping, markings and traffic signs. The installation and maintenance of the traffic control devices will be the responsibility of the department of public works for pavement markings, crosswalks, stop bars, and traffic signs and public utilities for traffic signalization devices. Such signs and markings will be approved by the city manager or city manager's designee. The need for requested signage will be verified by the police department traffic division and review by the planning department. The city manager shall notify the mayor and city council of installation within five (5) business days of completion of the installation. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86; Ord. No. 024-08, § 1, 7-21-08)  
Sec. 12-1009. - Operating motor vehicles without insurance. 
Any owner or any other person who knowingly operates, or knowingly authorizes another to operate a motor vehicle without effective insurance thereon, or without an approved plan of self insurance as required by Georgia Code Title 33, Chapter 34 the Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-1006 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 1, 8-4-86)  
CHAPTER 2. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 915-86, § 1, adopted Aug. 4, 1986, repealed former Ch. 2, as composed of Art. A, §§ 12-2001, 12-2002, 12-200412-2017, relative to general provisions governing stopping, standing and parking; Art. B, §§ 12-2031, 12-203312-2042, pertaining to no parking and restricted parking areas; and Art. C, §§ 12-205112-2053, relative to loading and unloading zones. The substantive provisions of former Ch. 2 derived from Code 1959, §§ 22-7722-92, 22-9422-103, 22-12222-124; Ord. No. 875-85, § 1, adopted March 4, 1985; and Ord. No. 888-85, §, enacted Oct. 7, 1985. 
Subsequently, Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, adopted Aug. 4, 1986, enacted a new Ch. 2 to read as herein set out in §§ 12-200112-2013. 
 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 12-2001. - Method of parking generally. 
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way roadway shall be stopped or parked with the right hand wheels parallel to and within twelve (12) inches of the right-hand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder. Each vehicle parked shall be headed in the direction of the traffic. In angle parking spaces, drivers must pull into parking spaces only. Backing into angle parking spaces is not allowed or permitted. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2002. - Permitted parking and no parking areas on public property; markings. 
(a)  Permitted and controlled parking areas of public property will be marked by the placement of signs stating when parking is permitted or the maximum allowable time before the parked vehicle must be moved. Permitted and non-time controlled areas or spaces will not have signs. 
(b)  No parking areas on public property [shall be] designated. No parking areas will be clearly indicated by an appropriate no parking sign or a yellow painted curb or both. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2003. - Leaving motor vehicle unattended. 
No person driving on in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended, without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, effectively setting the brake, and when the vehicle is standing upon any grade turning the front wheels to the curb or side of highway. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2004. - Generally prohibited areas. 
No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device in any of the following places: 
(1)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge of a curb of a street. 
(2)  On a sidewalk. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  On a crosswalk or within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk. 
(5)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant. 
(6)  Within thirty (30) feet of an intersection (all approaches). 
(7)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(8)  Within twenty (20) feet of driveway to a fire station. 
(9)  Within fifty (50) feet of a railroad crossing. 
(10)  Any place a no parking sign is present or a yellow curb is painted. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2005. - Lane obstruction. 
No driver shall stop or park any vehicle to obstruct a traffic lane. No driver shall stop any vehicle in a traffic lane to make deliveries or pickups as to obstruct traffic. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2006. - Parking on public streets. 
No vehicle shall be parked on a city street or public property for more than five (5) consecutive days in the same spot. Any vehicle parked for over five (5) days shall be presumed to be abandoned and may be impounded by the police department. It is also unlawful to store any truck, vehicle, chassis or body thereof in any public street. Any vehicle parked on a city street must have a valid tag and insurance and be able to move under it's own power. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2007. - Parking buses, boats, trailers, prohibited. 
No boat or boat trailers, pull campers, pole trailers, flat bed trailers, tankers, tractor trailers, or homemade trailers will be allowed to park on city streets or public property belonging to the City of East Point at any time. The only exception will be loading or unloading relating to business purposes. This exception should be short termed and should not interfere with other traffic. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2008. - Parking of trucks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to park trucks in excess of three-quarter (¾) ton on city streets city property. Any truck larger than three-quarter (¾) ton is expressly prohibited from parking on city streets. This includes but is not limited to tractors, tractor trailers, and buses. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2009. - Parking in loading zones; designated. 
No person shall park or stop in a loading zone except while actually engaged in loading or unloading of merchandise. The mayor and council shall designate loading zones by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2010. - Parking near intersection. 
It shall be unlawful to park, erect, place or leave any object, vehicle, trailer, or other thing in, at or near intersections or driveways as to obstruct the vision of drivers of vehicles approaching such streets or so that it is difficult for drivers entering such streets or driveways to readily see all other vehicles approaching. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2011. - Specific purpose prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle upon any street for the principal purpose of displaying vehicle for sale, advertising, greasing, or repairing the vehicle except for emergency repairs. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2012. - Violation; punishment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or owner of any vehicle, motorized or nonmotorized, to park or allow to be parked, such vehicle within the restricted parking areas. A violation of Chapter 2 may cause the vehicle to be impounded at the owner or driver's expense. Punishment of this chapter will be in accordance with section 1-1006 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2013. - Parking on private property. 
Owners of private property must have improperly parked or abandoned vehicles removed from their property in accordance with state law [title] 44-1-13. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  Vehicle reported stolen. 
(2)  Vehicle wanted by another police jurisdiction or involved in a crime. 
(Ord. No. 919-86, § 2, 8-4-86)  
Sec. 12-2014. - Disabled parking enforcement by disabled persons. 
(a)  The mayor and council may appoint persons to enforce the disabled parking laws of the city. Each person so appointed shall be a citizen of the United States and of the city, be of good moral character, and shall not have previously been convicted of a felony. In addition, each such person appointed shall be a disabled person as defined in Section 40-6-221(5) of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(b)  Each person appointed pursuant to this section shall submit an application to the city, and upon designation by the mayor and council, shall complete such training as directed by the chief of police, and shall take and subscribe an oath of office as prescribed by the mayor and council. 
(c)  The application required by subsection (b) above shall include the name and address of the applicant; his citizenship; a statement of qualification as a disabled person as that term is defined in Section 40-6-221(3) of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; and shall have attached to such application a 2" x 2" photograph of the applicant, together with a complete set of fingerprints. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the application, the chief of police or his designee shall cause a complete and thorough investigation to be made of the applicant's moral, physical, and mental qualifications. 
(e)  Any person appointed and sworn as a disabled parking enforcement officer shall have the power to serve citations for violations or failure to comply with disabled parking laws of the city in the same manner as any law enforcement officer of the state or city, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  No person so appointed shall be deemed a peace officer, nor shall such person be deemed an employee of the state, county, or city, nor receive any compensation therefrom. 
(2)  No such appointed person shall be required to complete training as a peace officer. 
(3)  No such appointed person shall have the power or duty to enforce other traffic or criminal laws of the state or the city. 
(4)  No person so appointed shall possess or carry firearms or other weapons for the purpose of enforcing disabled parking laws. 
(5)  No person so appointed shall be entitled to any indemnification from the state, county, or city for any injury or property damage sustained as a result of his enforcement activities. Each such appointed person shall specifically acknowledge that he or she has no rights to any claim of injury or property damage resulting from disabled enforcement activities. 
(6)  No government agency, department, or officer of the state, county, or city shall be liable or accountable for any act or omission of any person appointed to issue parking citations under this section. Each such appointed person shall specifically hold harmless the City of East Point, its employees, or agents from liability for any such act or omission by such appointed person. 
(7)  No person so appointed shall issue citations involving any space which is not marked with posted signs as required by Section 40-6-221(2)(A) or (B) of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(f)  No city vehicles shall be provided to or used by persons appointed under this section to enforce disabled parking laws. 
(Ord. No. 994-89, § 1, 9-18-89)  
Sec. 12-2014.5. - Vehicle immobilization devices prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon any vehicle any vehicle immobilization device, except as specified in subsection (b). 
(b)  This section shall [not] apply to any person who places upon a vehicle a vehicle immobilization device where such vehicle is owned, leased by or in the lawful possession of that person. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the term "vehicle immobilization device" shall mean any mechanical device that is designed or adapted to be attached to a wheel, tire, or other part of a parked motor vehicle so as to prohibit the motor vehicle's usual manner of movement of operation. 
(Ord. No. 025-05, § 1, 11-21-05)  
ARTICLE B. - RESIDENTIAL PERMIT PARKING 
 
Sec. 12-2015. - Statement of findings. 
The mayor and council finds that older residential areas of the city neighboring certain business, commercial, church and educational uses have a shortage of parking as a result of minimal lot widths and high concentrations of visitors during certain hours. The result of such problems is that residents of the city have insufficient parking to accommodate their own vehicles. Additionally, in certain areas, as a result of parking congestion, there is insufficient space for movement of emergency vehicles to adequately respond in the event of an emergency. The mayor and council find that such situations necessitate an innovative solution, which will relieve parking congestion while supporting city neighborhoods. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2016. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except when the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Blockface means that a portion of one (1) side of a street located between an intersecting street and the next occurring side street or between the termination of a street and the first occurring side street. 
Commuter vehicle means a motor vehicle, parked in a residential area, which is not registered to or operated by a resident of such area. 
Curb parking space means a twenty-four-foot long section of street, adjacent to the curb or edge of roadway, where a motor vehicle may lawfully park. 
Residential area means a contiguous or nearly contiguous area containing public roadways, which are primarily abutted by residential property and non-business property, such as parks and schools. 
Street address means the lot number assigned to a lot of record as shown on the official tax maps of the city. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2017. - Program established. 
(a)  There is established a residential permit parking program whereby motor vehicles bearing a special parking permit issued pursuant to this article may be parked on streets within certain areas known as residential permit parking areas. Parking a motor vehicle on a street within a residential permit parking area shall be: 
(1)  Prohibited entirely unless displaying a parking permit. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, restrictions established in this article shall be effective seven (7) days per week, including Saturday, Sunday and holidays, unless the motor vehicle displays a valid parking permit. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2018. - Procedure for initiating areas of residential permit parking. 
The chief of police may designate an area as a residential permit parking area where citizen complaints are of such magnitude and duration that the chief of police determines a need for such an area to exist. The determination of such a need by the chief of police shall be conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2019. - Eligibility of area for residential permit parking. 
(a)  In establishing the eligibility of a proposed residential permit parking area, the chief of police shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  Designation of the area as a residential permit parking area will result in one or more of the following expectations for the area: 
a.  A reduction in traffic congestion and illegal parking. 
b.  An improvement in vehicular and pedestrian safety. 
(b)  Having determined that the requirements for residential permit parking are met, the chief of police shall place the proposed residential parking permit area on the agenda of the next council meeting. If approved by the mayor and council, the chief of police shall assign an appropriate and unique identification letter to the area and shall notify the residents of the area that it had been approved as a residential parking permit area. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2020. - Application for permit. 
(a)  The application for a resident parking permit shall be made to the chief of police, or his designee, and shall provide the name of the owner or operator of the motor vehicle to be permitted; the residential address; the operator's state driver's license number; the motor vehicle make, model and license plate number, and other information requested on the application form. The applicant shall provide proof of residency. 
(b)  Visitor permits shall require no written application except as provided in section 12-2021 and 12-2022, however, the chief of police may require that previously issued and used permits be surrendered prior to replacement. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2021. - Issuance of permits. 
Following approval of a residential permit parking area, the chief of police, or his designee, shall issue resident permits and visitor permits as follow: 
(1)  Each residential permit parking area shall have a unique number and permit expiration date and permits shall be renewed every two (2) years. A permit shall be issued only to a motor vehicle owner or operator who resides on property fronting on a block face located within the residential permit parking area. Upon application, resident permits shall be issued in accordance with the following limitations: 
a.  Two (2) residential permits may be issued for each valid street address, which consists of one (1) residential structure containing only one (1) dwelling unit. 
b.  One (1) resident permit may be issued for each legally constituted and existing dwelling unit in any two (2) family or multiple family dwelling facility at a valid street address within the residential permit parking area. This includes apartments, condominiums, attached dwellings, row houses, town houses and the like. 
(2)  Upon request, two (2) visitor permits may be issued to the recipient of a resident permit and such visitor permits may be renewed or replaced in accordance with procedures established by the chief of police. 
(3)  A resident of a residential permit parking area which is eligible for a resident permit but does not apply for such permit may be issued two (2) visitor permits by making application as provided in subsection (1) of this section and omitting information which is not applicable. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2022. - Permit form and display. 
(a)  The resident parking permit shall be a decal and shall be affixed only to the motor vehicle for which it was issued. The decal shall be permanently attached to the inside lower corner of the rear window, driver's side and must be clearly visible from outside the vehicle. Information shown on the permit decal shall include but not be limited to the residential permit parking area identification letter, the permit number and the expiration date. 
(b)  The visitor permit shall be a temporary permit designed for use by transient visitors and guests of residents of a residential permit parking area. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, each visitor permit shall be valid for fifteen (15) days and shall provide all the rights and privileges of a resident permit. The visitor permit shall be of a form and shall be displayed as determined by the chief of police. 
(c)  The chief of police may issue a temporary permit, valid for not more than one (1) year, for a vehicle operated by a person who provides health care services or other essential services on a regular basis at an address within a residential permit parking area. Such temporary permit shall be a visitor permit bearing special validation and which is issued by the chief of police upon satisfactory proof of need presented by the resident at such address. A temporary permit shall not be issued for use by a person who provides services for a commercial activity conducted at a residence. 
(d)  A vehicle bearing a resident permit for one (1) residential permit parking area may display a visitor permit for a different residential permit parking area when the vehicle is in a valid visitor status within the area identified on the visitor permit. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2023. - Uniformity of parking regulations. 
Within each discrete residential permit parking area there shall be uniform parking regulations governing permit parking. Upon approval of a residential permit parking area, the chief of police shall have parking regulation signs installed within the area indicating the location of the permit parking area. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2024. - Limitations on permit use. 
A motor vehicle which displays a valid residential permit parking or visitor permit shall be allowed to stand or park in the residential permit parking area for which the permit has been issued without being limited by any restriction established in this article. Such permit does not authorize a motor vehicle to stand or to park in any place where or during any time when the stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle is prohibited or is designated for other uses. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
Sec. 12-2025. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of the article for a person to furnish false information in an application for any permit authorized by this article or to represent falsely that such person is eligible for such permit. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a person to produce or display a facsimile or counterfeit parking permit in order to evade parking restrictions in a residential permit parking area. 
(c)  Violation of any provision of this article shall constitute an offense and shall be punishable as provided under section 1-1006. 
(Ord. No. 005-01, § 1, 3-5-01)  
CHAPTER 3. - PEDESTRIANS 
 
Sec. 12-3001. - Subject to traffic regulations. 
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control as provided in section 12-1001, but may be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this chapter.  
Sec. 12-3002. - Right-of-way in crosswalk. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall stop and remain stopped to allow a pedestrian to cross the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching and is within one (1) lane of the half of the roadway on which the vehicle is traveling or onto which it is turning. For the purposes of this subsection, "half of the roadway" means all traffic lanes carrying traffic in one (1) direction of travel. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impractical for the driver to yield. 
(c)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the conditions stated in subsection (b) of section 12-3004. 
(d)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(Code 1959, § 22-134)  
Sec. 12-3003. - Use of right half of crosswalks. 
Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of crosswalks. 
(Code 1959, § 22-135)  
Sec. 12-3004. - Crossing at other than crosswalks. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway unless he has already, and under safe conditions, entered the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway if he uses the roadway instead of such tunnel or crossing. 
(c)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(d)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway intersection diagonally unless authorized by official traffic-control devices. When authorized to cross diagonally, pedestrians shall cross only in accordance with the official traffic-control devices pertaining to such crossing movements. 
(Code 1959, § 22-136)  
Sec. 12-3005. - On roadways. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  When sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a street or highway shall when practicable walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder, no more than twenty-four (24) inches from the curb or edge of roadway, facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. 
(c)  No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle or as to impede the normal flow of traffic. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided by O.C.G.A Title 40, Ch.6, any pedestrian upon a roadway shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(e)  No pedestrian shall enter or remain upon any bridge or approach thereto beyond the bridge signal, gate, or barrier after a bridge operation signal indication has been given. 
(f)  No pedestrian shall pass through, around, over, or under any crossing gate or barrier at a railroad grade crossing or bridge while such gate or barrier is closed or is being opened or closed. 
(g)  No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride. 
(h)  No person shall stand on or in proximity to a street or highway for the purpose of soliciting the watching or guarding of any vehicle while parked or about to be parked on a street or highway. 
(i)  Upon conviction for a violation of this section, the following fines shall be imposed: 
First offense 	$ 50.00 
Second offense 	 100.00 
Third offense 	 250.00 
;hg0;Fourth and subsequent 
offenses 	 500.00 
up to $1,000.00 
 
The fine shall be in addition to any jail and/or community service time considered appropriate in the circumstances. In any case, the judge may in his or her discretion substitute community service time for a scheduled fine when considered appropriate. 
(Code 1959, § 22-137; Ord. No. 114-96, § 1, 11-4-96; Ord. No. 013-00, § 1, 6-19-00)  
Sec. 12-3006. - Manner of crossing roadways. 
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway except at right angles to the curb and by the shortest route to the opposite curb, except in crosswalks. 
(Code 1959, § 22-138)  
Sec. 12-3007. - Drivers to exercise due careDuty with respect to blind persons carrying white canes. 
Any driver of a vehicle who approaches within three (3) feet of a person who is in a street or highway or at an intersection and who is wholly or partially blind, and who is carrying a walking cane or stick white in color or white tipped with red, shall immediately come to a full stop, and before proceeding, shall take such precautions as may be necessary to avoid accident or injury to the person wholly or partially blind. 
(Code 1959, § 22-139)  
Sec. 12-3008. - SameDriving near children. 
No person shall drive any vehicle so near to any children that one of such children could be thrown or caused to jump into the way of such vehicle before the same could be stopped by the driver thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 22-140)  
CHAPTER 4. - TOWING, IMPOUNDING AND DISPOSING OF VEHICLES; PRIVATE TRESPASS TOWING[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, adopted Sept. 3, 1990, deleted former Ch. 4, §§ 12-400112-4010, relative to towing, impounding and disposing of vehicles, and enacted a new Ch. 4 to read as herein set out in §§ 12-400112-4007. The provisions of former Ch. 4 derived from Code 1959, §§ 22-16122-166, 22-168, 22-169; Ord. No. 705-80, § 1, adopted Jan. 7, 1980; and Ord. No. 990-89, § 1, adopted July 17, 1989. 
 
Sec. 12-4001. - Competitive bids for towing and impounding of vehicles. 
The city is authorized to enter into a competitive sealed bid annually for a contract between the city and the person, firm or corporation in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, to provide for the towing and impoundment of motor vehicles or property, mobile homes, or other property from any public street, alley, drive, park, ball field, or other public property. The purchasing agent of the City of East Point will furnish a copy of this chapter to each person, firm or corporation submitting competitive sealed bids hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, 9-3-90; Ord. No. 1009-90, § 1, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 12-4002. - Notice of request for bids. 
The purchasing agent will request written competitive sealed bids to render the police department of the City of East Point towing, wrecker, and impoundment services, annually, for periods of twelve (12) months. Such request for bids shall be published in the official newspaper for the City of East Point for two (2) consecutive weeks prior to accepting sealed bids. Such request shall state the time and place such competitive sealed bids will be publicly opened and considered, and that all such offers shall conform to the requirements of this chapter. When the competitive sealed bids are opened, said bids shall be sent to the chief of police of the City of East Point to be reviewed and considered. 
(Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, 9-3-90; Ord. No. 1009-90, § 1, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 12-4003. - Awarding of lowest and best bid. 
The chief of police of the City of East Point shall review and consider all bids submitted pursuant to section 12-4002. In addition, said chief of police or his designee shall inspect the storage lots for impounds, to determine the lot capacity, and to ascertain the existence of an eight-foot blinded fence, with night security lights, a suitable headquarters facility to transact business, and that the owner or operator of the lot has in operating condition at all times at least three (3) wreckers assigned permanently to the storage lot. Two (2) of the three (3) wreckers shall be roll-backs. In addition, the lot facility shall have an express telephone system to the East Point Communications Center. Following this review and inspection, the chief of police shall recommend, in writing, to the mayor and city council, the lowest and best bid. 
(Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, 9-3-90; Ord. No. 1009-90, § 1, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 12-4004. - List of charges to be furnished with bid. 
Charges for the following services shall be submitted with each competitive sealed bid: 
(a)  Simple towing for auto, ¾-ton pickup or less, all type motorcycles, and all trailers less than eighteen (18) feet. 
(b)  Simple towing of vehicles over one ton, all trailers over eighteen (18) feet, tractors, tractor-trailers, or other large trucks or vehicles. 
(c)  Fee for dropping drive shafts and releasing of air brakes. 
(d)  Fee for removing vehicles from inaccessible places or locations. 
(e)  Daily storage fee for autos, ¾-ton trucks or less, all types of motorcycles, and trailers less than eighteen (18) feet. 
(f)  Daily storage fee for one ton trucks, all trailers over eighteen (18) feet, tractors, tractor-trailers, mobile homes, and any other property. 
(g)  Contractor will post rates in office area in letter of no less than two (2) inches. 
(h)  Contractor will also post private rates of simple towing in the office area. 
(Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, 9-3-90; Ord. No. 1009-90, § 1, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 12-4005. - Required covenants to be included in contract. 
No contract shall be awarded pursuant to this chapter unless the person, firm or corporation to which it is awarded covenants and agrees with the City of East Point that said person, firm or corporation can and will: 
(1)  Maintain adequate equipment and sufficient labor force to meet the city's demand for service on a full twenty-four-hour per day basis every day of the year including holidays. Standby crews and equipment are to be arranged so as to meet emergency situations under normal conditions. 
(2)  Contractors are obligated to release impounded vehicles or property between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. every day of the year. 
(3)  All wreckers shall have two-way radios in each vehicle. 
(4)  All contractor's employees will be neat, clean and wear uniform-type clothing.
