(5)  Carry sufficient insurance to protect the city against all cost, expense, injury, damage and loss on account of the conduct or negligence of the contractor or his agents, and not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) public liability insurance on the equipment used for towing and wrecker service. 
(6)  Carry all fire, theft, collision and other insurance necessary for the complete coverage of each vehicle or other item of personal property, and the contents thereof, removed from any of the places herein mentioned, on behalf of the city, and to otherwise carry fire, theft, collision and other insurance necessary to operate wreckers on any public roads. 
(7)  To keep all impounded vehicles and property on a lot that will hold at least two hundred (200) vehicles. The lot must be secure and enclosed, and must meet city zoning regulations if located inside the City of East Point. 
(8)  The contractor will supply to the police department of the City of East Point all impound books at no cost to the city. 
(9)  The contractor must agree to assume all liability for vehicles and personal property located therein, that is stolen or damaged while said vehicles or property are in the possession, custody, or control of the contractor. 
(10)  That the contractor will only release vehicles impounded by the police department of the City of East Point when a release is obtained from said police department. 
(11)  That any vehicles towed by the contractor, and later confiscated by the City of East Point, will be towed by contractor, at no additional cost to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, 9-3-90; Ord. No. 1009-90, § 1, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 12-4006. - Disposition of impounded vehicles. 
The contractor must dispose of all unclaimed, impounded vehicles, in accordance with the existing laws of the State of Georgia, including those statutes and regulations currently in force, or as may be hereinafter adopted by the State of Georgia, that govern the disposition, sale, or disposal of impounded vehicles. At the request of the contractor, the East Point communications department will obtain and furnish owner registration information on impounded vehicles, at no cost to the contractor. All forms, notices, and publications shall be completed, published or otherwise furnished, by the contractor. All public sales by the contractor must be carried out in accordance with existing state law, including O.C.G.A. Section 11-1-201(31.1). Vehicles or other property sold pursuant to court order shall be listed by the year, make accordance with existing state law, including O.C.G.A. Section 11-1-201(31.1). Vehicles or other property sold pursuant to court order shall be listed by the year, make and vehicle identification number (VIN) and advertised at the Fulton County Courthouse as required, and in the official newspaper of the City of East Point, once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks before the sale date. The contractor shall be allowed to include an advertisement cost on vehicles sold at auction. Any proceeds from the sale of vehicles hereunder shall remain with the contractor, as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, 9-3-90; Ord. No. 1009-90, § 1, 10-15-90)  
Sec. 12-4007. - Liability for damages. 
In no event does the city assume any liability for damages for either willful or negligent conduct of the person, firm or corporation to whom such contract is awarded. 
(Ord. No. 1007-90, § 1, 9-3-90; Ord. No. 1009-90, § 1, 10-15-90)  
CHAPTER 6. - MINI MOTORCYCLES ON PUBLIC ROADWAYS AND PARKS  
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 12-6001. - Introduction. 
The City of East Point finds that drivers of mini motorcycles are driving such vehicles on the public roadways within the city limits without proper state licensing and state registration requirements and without state required equipment. The city desires to ensure that mini motorcycles are being operated in a manner consistent with the comfort, repose, health, peace, and safety of the residents of the city. The city shall regulate mini motorcycles driven within the city limits, to the extent provided within this article. 
(Ord. No. 017-05, § 1, 8-15-05)  
Sec. 12-6002. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Mini motorcycle means every pocket bike, pocket rocket and mini bike, that is equipped for either on road or off road use but is not in compliance with state licensing and state registration requirements and does not contain state required equipment. 
(2)  Minor means any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(3)  Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding tractors, all terrain vehicles, and mopeds. Motorcycle, for purposes of this section, shall include only motor driven cycles that are manufactured for on road use and operated in compliance with licensing and state registration requirements and containing state required equipment. 
(4)  Motor driven cycle means every motorcycle, including every motor scooter, with a motor which produces not to exceed five (5) brake horsepower, every bicycle with a motor attached, and every moped. 
(5)  Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled other than an electric personal assistive mobility device. 
(6)  Private road or driveway, private property or race track means every way or place in private ownership used by the owner or persons having express or implied permission from the owner but not used by other persons. 
(7)  Public roadway, street, alley, sidewalk, city park or any city property means any roadway, street, alley, sidewalk, city park or any city property within the city limits. It shall not include private roads or driveways, private property or race tracks where use of mini motorcycles is permitted. 
(Ord. No. 017-05, § 1, 8-15-05)  
Sec. 12-6003. - Mini motorcycles prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for a person to ride or operate, or for a parent or guardian of a minor to permit a minor to ride or operate a mini motorcycle on any public roadway, street, alley, sidewalk, city park or any city property within the city limits of the City of East Point. It shall be unlawful for a person to ride operate, or for a parent or guardian of a minor to permit a minor to ride or operate a mini motorcycle on any private property without the express consent of the property owner or on any property where there exists a conservation easement. 
(Ord. No. 017-05, § 1, 8-15-05)  
Sec. 12-6004. - Exclusions from prohibition. 
This section shall not apply to any person operating a moped, motorcycle, tractor or all terrain vehicle or any motor vehicle that is equipped for on road use and compliant with all state requirements and regulations. This section shall not apply to any persons with disabilities operating a motor assisted wheelchair or similar device. 
(Ord. No. 017-05, § 1, 8-15-05)  
Part 13 - OFFENSES[1] 
Ch. 1. General Provisions 
Ch. 2. Offenses Against the Public Welfare 
Ch. 3. Railroads 
Ch. 4. Traffic Control for Street and Highway Construction Maintenance Operations and Utility Work 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note Cities are prohibited from enacting criminal ordinances preempted by state law, Ga. Code Ann., § 69-1018(a)(2). Common examples of areas where municipal criminal ordinance authority is preempted are as follows: abatement of nuisances, Ga. Code Ann., § 72-9901; anti-littering, Georgia Litter Control Law, Ch. 18-16C; abusive or obscene language, § 26-2610; bill posting, Ch. 85-161; damaging or defacing government property, § 26-2613; distributing obscene materials, Ch. 26-21; false fire alarm, § 26-2608; fireworks control, § 26-2011; obstructing highways, sidewalks, etc., § 26-2611; resisting arrest, § 26-2505; trespassing on or damaging private property (malicious mischief), Ch. 26-15. Note that these are crimes for which city police may arrest but the municipal court does not have jurisdiction to hear; only the county superior court or the state court has such jurisdiction. 
 
CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 13-1001. - Aiding and abetting. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to assist, aid or abet in the commission of any offense against the laws or ordinances of the city, or in the concealment or escape of any offender, or to obstruct, prevent, delay or interfere with the apprehension and arrest of any offender of the laws of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-2)  
Sec. 13-1002. - Conspiracy. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conspire with another or others to violate any law, ordinance, rule or regulation of the United States, the state, the county, the city or of any department, board, bureau, commission, officer or authority of that city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-4)  
Sec. 13-1003. - Impersonating an officer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, not an officer authorized to wear the same, to wear any uniform or badge of an arresting officer, or any likeness thereto, or to impersonate an arresting officer. 
(Code 1959, § 14-22)  
Sec. 13-1004. - Impersonating another. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate or falsely represent himself to another person. 
(Code 1959, § 14-23)  
Sec. 13-1005. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  Prohibited conduct. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons within the incorporated areas of the city to engage in any conduct described in the following subsections: 
(1)  To act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear for the safety of his life, limb, or health; 
(2)  To act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed; 
(3)  To cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl, or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health, or property of another; 
(4)  To assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose of or intent to engage in gaming; 
(5)  To be in or about any place, alone or with another or others with the purpose of or intent to engage in any fraudulent scheme, trick, or device to obtain any money or valuable thing; or to aid or abet any person or persons in doing so; 
(6)  To be in or about any place where gaming or illegal sale of possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed, or tolerated, for the purpose or intent to engage in gaming or the purchase, use, possession or consumption of said illegal drugs, narcotics, or alcoholic beverages; 
(7)  To direct "fighting words" toward another, that is words which by their very nature tend to incite a breach of peace; 
(8)  To interfere, by acts of physical obstruction, with another's pursuit of lawful occupation; 
(9)  To congregate with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and to fail to clear that public way after being ordered to do so by a police officer or other lawful authority; 
(10)  To disrupt, by actions which tend to incite a breach of peace, the activities of any house of worship, hospital, home for the elderly, or any lawful meeting, gathering, or procession; 
(11)  To throw bottles, paper, cans, glass, sticks, stones, missiles, or any other debris on public property. 
(12)  To be in or about any designated drug-free zones at any time during the exclusion period and only after receipt of written notice of civil exclusion pursuant to City of East Point Code section 13-1028. 
(b)  Penalty. Upon finding of guilt for the violation of this section, the offender shall be subject to imprisonment for a term not exceeding twelve (12) months or by fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both. 
(Ord. No. 966-88, § 1, 7-18-88; Ord. No. 1139-96, § 1, 10-7-96; Ord. No. 019-05, § 1, 8-15-05 Ord. No. 030-07, § 1, 9-17-07)  
Sec. 13-1005.1. - Disorderly while under the influence. 
(a)  Acts constituting violation. It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to be disorderly while under the influence on the streets, sidewalks or other public places. The following acts are declared to be in violation of this section: 
(1)  Any person who acts in a reckless manner so as to create an unreasonable risk of harm to himself, to other persons or to property in the vicinity, while he or she is under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(2)  Any person who shall defecate or urinate on the streets or sidewalks or in the halls or elevators of public or commercial buildings, or on any property open to public view in the city while he or she is under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(3)  Any person who, without provocation, uses to or of another, in such person's presence, fighting words while he or she is under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(4)  Any person who shall act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another while he or she is under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(5)  Any person who shall lie down or otherwise obstruct, block or impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic on any sidewalk, street, or entrance or exit to any other public way, house of worship, business, public hall, theater, public conveyance or other public place and who shall refuse to remove themselves when ordered to do so by a city police officer or other lawful authority while he or she is under influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(6)  Any person who shall act in a boisterous, turbulent, or agitated manner, or who shall use profane, vulgar, loud or language while he or she is under the influence of alcohol or other drugs, while on the streets, sidewalks, or other public places within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Penalty. Upon a finding of guilty for violation of this section, the offender shall be subject to imprisonment for a term not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days or by fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), either of such penalties to be in the discretion of the municipal judge. Such punishment may be probated by the municipal judge for those offenders desiring to participate in a detoxification program. 
(c)  Habitual abusers. Any person who shall have been convicted or have forfeited collateral under the provisions of subsection (b) of this section three (3) times in the preceding twelve (12) months may be deemed a habitual alcohol abuser and may be probated by the court to an outpatient treatment resource for a period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Ord. No. 030-07, 9-17-07)  
Sec. 13-1006. - Air rifles, blank pistols, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or shoot an air rifle, a pistol which shoots blank cartridges or a flip or slingshot. 
(Code 1959, § 14-3)  
Sec. 13-1007. - Injury or damage to others. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly cause loss, injury or damage to any person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly work inconvenience, loss, injury or damage to another by any trick, agency or other means.  
Sec. 13-1008. - Injury to propertyStreet signs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, obliterate, mar, remove, take down or in any manner interfere with or disturb any sign containing the name of any street or public place, whether it be on public or private property. 
(Code 1959, § 14-29)  
Sec. 13-1009. - SameShade trees. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully cut, bruise or otherwise damage any shade tree, shrubbery or other trees or plants in any public park or on any street or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-30)  
Sec. 13-1010. - Lost property, reporting by finder. 
It shall be the duty of any person who finds money, property or effects of any character whatsoever within the city not belonging to such person, to report such money, property or effects with an accurate description thereof to the chief of police of the city within twenty-four (24) hours from the time of finding same. 
(Code 1959, § 14-33)  
Sec. 13-1011. - Motor vehicles on city bike track. 
It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle of any kind to be operated upon the city bike track at any time of day or night by anyone. 
(Code 1959, § 14-33.1)  
Sec. 13-1012. - Obstructing officers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder or obstruct any officer of the city or any employee of the city in the discharge of his legal duty. 
(Code 1959, § 14-37)  
Sec. 13-1013. - Reserved.  
Sec. 13-1014. - Sales of questionable characterDuty of purchaser. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or receive anything of value within the city from any person whose right to sell or dispose of such article is not known to such purchaser or receiver, or at a price so unreasonably low or under such circumstances that any reasonably prudent and honest person would suspect the article was stolen, or question the right of the person selling or disposing of the same to sell or dispose of it, without reporting in writing at once on the date of purchase or receipt thereof to the police department such purchase or receipt of such article of value, giving the name, address and description of the person from whom such article is received or purchased, a complete description of the article purchased or received, the price paid and the probable value of such article purchased or received. 
(Code 1954, Ch. 19, § 54; Code 1959, § 14-46)  
Sec. 13-1015. - SamePolice to keep proper records, etc. 
It shall be the duty of the police department of the city to keep and preserve a permanent record of the reports made to it under the provisions of section 13-1014, and such records shall be open to the public for inspection at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1959, § 14-47)  
Sec. 13-1016. - Scaring or frightening another. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully scare or frighten another person. 
(Code 1959, § 14-48)  
Sec. 13-1017. - Utilities and cable television; obtaining service by device, trick or theft of equipment. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to employ any kind of coin, device, arrangement or trick to obtain any electric current, water, gas or other service without payment of regular charges therefor. 
(b)  Theft of electricity. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation within the city to consume electricity for which said person, firm or corporation does not pay the established and prevailing rate for the consumption of electricity, by means of tampering with, altering, or devising any other scheme or plan to obtain said electricity in a manner to avoid payment for same. 
(c)  Theft of cable television services or devices, or equipment. It shall be unlawful for any person to avoid or attempt to avoid or to cause another to avoid the lawful charges, in whole or in part, for any cable television service (CATV) or for the transmission of a message, signal or other communication, or to obtain by trick, device or theft any equipment or device belonging to a cable television service, by use of any fraudulent scheme, means, or method, or the use of any mechanical, electrical or electronic device; provided, however, that this code section shall not apply to amateur radio repeater operation involving a dial interconnect. 
(Code 1959, § 14-50.1; Ord. No. 687-78, § 1, 8-21-78; Ord. No. 839-83, § 1, 3-9-83)  
Sec. 13-1018. - Weapons, drawing or flourishing prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to draw from his pocket or other place of concealment, in an excited or boisterous manner or in any manner calculated to cause a breach of the peace, any pistol or weapon of any kind, or to flourish the same in like manner or to draw such weapon with threats of using the same on any person; provided, this section shall not apply to persons acting in justifiable self-defense. 
(Code 1959, § 14-54)  
Sec. 13-1019. - Possession of one ounce or less of marijuana; penalty; treatment for first violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess one ounce or less of marijuana within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Any person guilty of violating this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for such violation. 
(c)  No person alleged to have violated subsection (a) above shall be allowed to elect to be treated as an ordinance violator other than on the first such occasion of such violation. 
(Code 1959, § 14-55) 
State Law reference Marijuana prohibited, Ga. Code Ann., § 79A-9917.  
Sec. 13-1020. - Duty of citizens to aid in suppressing breaches of the peace, etc.; obstructing police officers. 
Any person residing in the city between the ages of eighteen (18) and fifty (50) years, who, upon being summoned by any arresting or peace officer of the city to aid in suppressing an affray, breach of the peace or other outrage, refuses so to do, or refuses to arrest or aid in arresting any offender against the laws of the city, or any person who shall oppose, resist or obstruct any police officer of the city in the discharge of any duty shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1959, § 7-16)  
Sec. 13-1021. - Following policeman or arresting officer after desist order. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to follow any policeman or arresting officer while he has any person under arrest, after being ordered by the arresting officer to desist. 
(Code 1959, § 7-17)  
Sec. 13-1022. - Fund solicitations on public property prohibited. 
No person, firm or corporation shall solicit any funds from the general public for charitable, eleemosynary or fraternal purposes in or upon public property within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-156)  
Sec. 13-1023. - Hours of solicitation. 
No person, firm or corporation shall conduct any solicitations from the general public upon private property except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. and in no event prior to sunrise nor later than sunset daily. Solicitations before or after the above stated times are prohibited except by prior appointment and with the consent of the party being solicited. 
(Code 1959, § 2-157)  
Sec. 13-1024. - Parking mobile homes outside of camps. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful within the city for any person to park any mobile home on any street, alley, highway or other public place, or on any tract of land owned by any person, occupied or unoccupied, within the city, except as provided in this Chapter 2 of Part 10. 
(b)  Emergency or temporary stopping or parking is permitted on any street, alley or highway for not longer than one hour, subject to any other further prohibitions, regulations or limitations imposed by the traffic and parking ordinances for that street, alley or highway.  
Sec. 13-1025. - Drinking, offering alcoholic beverages in public prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to publicly drink or publicly offer to any other person within the city any alcoholic beverage, or to drink or offer such beverage to any other person on any street, sidewalk or driveway; or in the doorway, passageway, entrance, window, vestibule or porch to any store, garage, residence or other building within the city; or in any park, tennis court, school ground, automobile, trolley, bus, motor truck or other kind of vehicle within the city; or at any place within the city auditorium, city hall, fire department or city jail; or within any church, schoolhouse, filling station, rest room, barbershop, grocery store, garage, parking lot, cafe, drugstore, soda fountain, theater, hardware dry goods or other kind of mercantile establishment; or within any office, ice cream parlor, dance hall or lodge hall; or at or in any other public place or place to which the public is invited, congregates or goes, including poolrooms, ball grounds or similar places within the city; provided, this section shall not prohibit the drinking of such beverages by persons legally entitled to drink the same privately within their own homes with their guests, or privately within their own place of business; provided further that this section shall not apply within the premises of licensees operating under a duly granted license to retail alcoholic beverages by the drink. 
(Code 1959, § 4-4)  
Sec. 13-1026. - Uniform enforcement of rules of conduct on public transit. 
(a)  Certain acts prohibited on transit. 
(1)  A person who commits or attempts to commit any of the following acts in a public transit bus, a rapid rail car, or a rapid rail station or intermodal bus station shall be guilty of a misdemeanor: 
a.  Spits, defecates, or urinates; 
b.  Discards litter, except into receptacles designated for that purpose; 
c.  Smokes tobacco in any form; 
d.  Consumes food or beverage or possesses any open food or beverage container, provided that this paragraph shall not apply to an operator of a public transit bus at an authorized layover point or to a person providing food or beverage to any child under age five (5); 
e.  Plays any radio, cassette, cartridge, or tape player, or similar device unless such device is connected to an earphone that limits the sound to the hearing of the individual user; 
f.  Carries or possesses any explosives, acids, other dangerous articles, or live animals, except for the following; 
1.  A guide dog or service dog as described in O.C.G.A. § 30-4-1, provided that such guide dog or service dog is accompanied by a physically disabled person, blind person, person with visual disabilities, deaf person, or a person who is responsible for training a guide dog or service dog; and 
2.  Small pets confined to rigid pet carriers with locks or latches; 
g.  Obstructs, hinders, interferes with, or otherwise disrupts or disturbs the operation, operator, or passengers of a public transit bus or rapid rail car; 
h.  Boards any public transit bus through the rear exit door, unless so directed by an employee or agent of the carrier; 
i.  Remains aboard any public transit bus or rapid rail car after such vehicle has completed its schedule route and passengers have been advised to exit the vehicle or remains aboard any public transit bus or rapid rail car after having been warned and after such vehicle has entered a garage or other restricted area not open to the public; 
j.  Enters, exits, or passes through any emergency door of any rapid rail car or public transit bus in the absence of a bona fide emergency; or 
k.  Enters the operator's cab or driver's seat of any rapid rail car or public transit bus in the absence of a bona fide emergency. 
(2)  Employees of a public transportation authority or carrier while at work performing the duties of their employment shall be exempted from the restrictions of paragraphs h., i., j., and k. of subsection (a)(1). 
(3)  A person convicted of a first offense of violating subsection (1) of this Code section shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Upon a second or subsequent conviction, a person shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) days, or both. 
(4)  This Code section shall be cumulative to and shall not prohibit the enactment of any other general and local laws, rules, and regulations of state or local authorities or agencies, and local ordinances prohibiting such activities which are more restrictive than this Code section. 
(b)  Fare evasion. A person who commits or attempts to commit any of the following acts shall be guilty of a misdemeanor: 
(1)  Sells, makes, or possesses any coin, note, token, transfer, transaction card, or similar article which has been altered from its original condition contrary to its intended use to enter or gain entry into or on any bus, rail vehicle, or station; 
(2)  Sells or exchanges any token, transfer, transaction card, ticket, fare medium, or similar article used or to be used as payment for entry into or on any bus, rail vehicle, or terminal without the express consent of the public transit agency owning or operating such vehicles or stations; 
(3)  Offers entry or provides entry into or on any bus, rapid rail car, or station to any person without the payment of the proper fare to the public transit agency owning or operating such vehicles or stations; 
(4)  Gains entry into or on any bus, rapid rail car, or station without the payment of the proper fare to the public transit agency owning or operating such vehicles or stations; or 
(5)  Gains entry into or on any bus, rapid rail car, or station through the use of a transfer, transaction card, or other similar fare media which is the property of another person. 
(c)  Parking at public transit. 
(1)  In all parking lots, parking decks, and other such facilities owned or operated by any public transit authority or established for the exclusive purpose of providing parking for passengers of rapid rail or public transit buses, it shall be unlawful to: 
a.  Stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than in marked spaces designed for that purpose; 
b.  Stop, stand, or park a vehicle on any yellow curb; 
c.  Stop, stand, or park a vehicle in any location which results in impeding ingress or egress to said facility or which results in impeding the free passage of any other vehicle; 
d.  Leave any vehicle unattended in areas designated as "kiss-ride" or designated as "attended vehicles only"; 
e.  Stop, stand, or park any taxicab or other vehicle for hire, whether attended or unattended, in any area not specifically designated for such vehicles; 
f.  Stop, stand, or park any vehicle for the purpose or loading or unloading passengers, except in areas specifically designated for that use, such as "kiss-ride" or passenger drop-off" areas; 
g.  Stop, stand, or park any vehicle for a period in excess of 24 hours unless such parking area is designated "overnight" or long-term" parking; 
h.  Stop, stand, or park any vehicle for any purpose other than to board the rapid rail car or public transit bus serving such parking lot; or 
i.  Create or maintain any fire or flame, including fires or flames for cooking or grilling, or to fail to extinguish said fire or flame and to remove from such public transit parking facility all debris and residue associated with the creation and maintenance of said fire or flame. 
(2)  Any person violating subsection (b)(1) of this Code section shall be subject to a fine levied by the municipality or, in the case of properties located outside the boundaries of a municipality, by the county in which the offenses occurs. Such offense shall be cited by the issuance of written citation which shall be left on the violator's vehicle and which shall contain, at a minimum: 
a.  The nature of the violation; 
b.  The amount of the fine which will be levied for such violation; 
c.  That the cited individual has the right to contest the citation and be given an opportunity to be heard; 
d.  The location of the court in which the cited individual must appear within five (5) days of the date of the citation to contest same; and 
e.  The location at which fines may be paid. 
(3)  Nothing in this Code section shall be construed to limit the enforcement of any other provision of state law which may be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 914-86, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 1172-98, § 1, 9-21-98)  
Sec. 13-1027. - Possession of firearms or other weapons on city property prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess a firearm, knife, or other weapon designed for the purpose of offense or defense upon property or in buildings owned or operated by the city. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers, peace officers retired from state or federal law enforcement agencies, judges, magistrates, solicitors, or district attorneys. 
(Ord. No. 997-89, § 1, 11-17-89)  
Sec. 13-1028. - Drug-Free zones. 
Drug-Free zones are those areas of the city as designated by the city council which are: 
(a)  Not less than six (6) city blocks but not more than one hundred (100) blocks; or, where designation by blocks is inappropriate: 
(1)  Not more than one-half (½) square mile in size, or 
(2)  Any area designated as a city park or portion thereof; and 
(b)  Areas where the number of arrests for conduct prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 16-13, 16-13-30, 16-13-30.1, and 16-13-31 for the twelve-month period preceding the original designation is significantly higher than for other similarly sized areas of the city. 
(c)  The police department shall provide a recommended list of drug free zones to the city council as needed. The mayor and city council shall then declare the areas as drug free zones. All drug free zones shall remain in effect for three (3) years from date of resolution. 
(d)  Designation of drug-free zones: If the city council designates an area meeting the criteria of section 13-1028 of this Code to be a drug-free zone, council shall do so by ordinance, said designation to be valid for an initial period of three (3) years. Thereafter, the council may extend the time of designation as it deems appropriate, but in no event shall the total be more than ten (10) years. 
(e)  The council may remove the designation in the event it deems that appropriate. The removal of the designation also shall be by ordinance. 
(f)  Civil exclusion: A person is subject to exclusion for a period of six (6) months from the public streets, sidewalks, and other public ways in all designated drug-free zones designated in section 1028 of Part 13, Chapter 1 of the Code if that person has been arrested or otherwise taken into custody within a designated drug-free zone for any of the following crimes: 
(1)  An attempt to unlawfully possess a controlled substance, in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-33; or 
(2)  A criminal conspiracy to unlawfully possess a controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-33; or 
(3)  Unlawful possession of a controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30(a) or 16-13-31; or 
(4)  An attempt to unlawfully deliver a controlled substance, in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-33; or 
(5)  A criminal conspiracy to unlawfully deliver a controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-33; or 
(6)  Unlawful delivery of a controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30(b) or 16-13-31, or 
(7)  An attempt to unlawfully deliver an imitation controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30.1; or 
(8)  A criminal conspiracy to unlawfully deliver an imitation controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-33; or 
(9)  Unlawful delivery of an imitation controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30(I) or O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30.1 or O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30.2; or 
(10)  An attempt to unlawfully possess an imitation controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-33; or 
(11)  A criminal conspiracy to unlawfully possess an imitation controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-33; or 
(12)  Unlawful possession of an imitation controlled substance in violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30(I) or O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30.1 or O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30.2. 
(g)  If a person excluded from all designated drug-free zones is found in any drug-free zone during the exclusion period, that person is subject to immediate arrest for criminal trespass pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21, or criminal trespass pursuant to City of East Point Code section 13-1029. 
(h)  Issuance of exclusion notices: The chief of police is designated as the person in charge of the public streets, sidewalks, and the public ways in drug-free zones for the purposes of issuing exclusion notices in accordance with this chapter. The chief of police may authorize employees of the police department to issue exclusion notices in accordance with this article. 
(i)  Procedure: At the time a person is arrested within a drug-free zone for unlawful possession or distribution, or attempted possession or distribution, of a controlled substance or of an imitation controlled substance as prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 16-30-30, 16-13-30.1, 16-13-30.2, 16-13-31 and 16-13-33, the officer making such arrest may deliver to the person a written notice excluding the person from drug-free areas. The notice shall specify the area(s) from which that person is excluded and contain information concerning the right to appeal the exclusion notice to a hearing officer. The person to whom the exclusion notice is issued shall sign a written acknowledgment of receipt of the exclusion notice. If that person refuses to do so, the arresting officer shall make a written record of refusal. 
(j)  Appeal: 
(1)  An appeal of the exclusion must be filed, in writing, within five (5) calendar days of the issuance of the notice. 
(2)  The exclusion shall not take effect during the pendency of the appeal. If no appeal is taken, the exclusion shall take effect on the sixth calendar day after issuance of the notice. 
(3)  Copies of documents in its control and which are intended to be used by the city at the hearing shall be made available to the appellant at least two (2) days prior to the hearing. 
(4)  The city shall have the burden to show by a preponderance of evidence that the exclusion is based on conduct proscribed by O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30, 16-13-30.1, 16-13-30.2, 16-13-31, or 16-13-33. 
(5)  A determination by a court having jurisdiction of the matter that the officer who issued the exclusion notice had probable cause at that time to arrest the person to whom the exclusion notice was issued for violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30, 16-13-30.1, 16-13-30.2, 16-13-31, or 16-13-33, shall be prima facie evidence that the exclusion was based on conduct proscribed by those statutes. 
(k)  Variance: 
(1)  Issuance: All variances shall be in writing, for a specific period, and only to accommodate a specific purpose, all of which shall be stated on the variance. Variances from an exclusion may be granted at any time during the exclusion period by the chief of police or his designee, who shall grant a variance to any person who can establish that: 
a.  The person was a bona fide resident of the drug-free zone prior to receipt of the exclusion notice; or 
b.  The person otherwise requires access to a facility within the drug-free zone to preserve his or her health or well-being. Examples of bona fide reasons to grant a variance may include, but are not limited to, lawful employment within the zone; necessary access to a social service agency which offers services unavailable at any location outside the zone; health care or other treatment unavailable outside the zone; legitimate enrollment in a school or training program within a zone; necessary access to public building(s), such as a courthouse, located within a zone; other reasons related to health or well-being. 
(2)  Voidance: The person shall keep the variance on his or her person at all times the person is within the drug-free zone. 
a.  In the event a person having a variance is found to be outside the scope of the variance's terms, the variance shall immediately become void and that person is thereupon subject to arrest for criminal trespass. 
b.  In the event a person holding a variance is arrested for conduct prohibited by state or federal law involving controlled substances, the variance shall immediately become void and that person shall be ineligible for any variances for a period of one (1) year from the date of the arrest. 
(Ord. No. 1147-97, § 7, 7-21-97)  
Sec. 13-1029. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 013-01, § 1, adopted June 18, 2001, repealed former section 13-1029 in its entirety which pertained to criminal trespass and derived from Ord. No. 1148-97, § 1, adopted Aug. 18, 1997.  
CHAPTER 2. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC WELFARE  
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 13-2001. - Business establishments operating all night require employee on duty; place of business defined; penalty. 
(a)  The operation and maintenance of any place of business which is open to the general public during the hours of 11:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m., without the owner of such business making adequate provisions for the protection of such place of business from vandalism, thefts and fire, constitutes a menace to the public health, safety, morals and welfare of the citizens of the city, in that the operation of such business as aforesaid creates an unnecessary fire hazard, and necessitates and places an additional and unnecessary burden upon the police department of the city which deprives other citizens of proper protection for their persons and homes. The city council does further take cognizance of the fact that such businesses operating as aforesaid have frequently been subjected to vandalism and other crimes and that their continued operation without adequate protection will further unnecessarily endanger the persons patronizing said business, as well as the persons and property of all the citizens of the city. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation who operates and maintains a place of business in the city which is open to the general public shall have at least one (1) employee on duty upon the premises of the place of business at all times during the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., if the business is operating and open to the general public, unless such person, firm or corporation coming under the provisions of this section shall first present to the city council a plan for the adequate protection of its property from fire, theft, and vandalism, and shall obtain by resolution from city council permission to operate and remain open to the general public without the attendance of an employee during the aforesaid hours. Permission may be revoked at any time without notice, upon presentation of evidence that such plan is insufficient to carry out the objectives of this section. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section "place of business" shall be defined as any building, structure or enclosure used primarily for the purpose of housing any business, entertainment, trade or profession. 
(Code 1959, § 14-3.1)  
Sec. 13-2002. - Business establishments; placard giving information in case of emergency required. 
All persons, firms and corporations doing business in the city shall keep and maintain upon the front door of such place of business a card or plaque which shall not be less than three (3) inches by five (5) inches in size and which shall contain the name, address and residence telephone number of the employee of such business to be contacted in case of emergency. 
(Code 1959, § 14-3.2)  
Sec. 13-2003. - CurfewMinors. 
It shall be unlawful for any minor sixteen (16) years of age or younger to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, shopping centers, or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusements, eating places, vacant lots or any other place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. on any day and 5:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays, the effective hours are between 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. the following day. It shall be unlawful for any minor seventeen (17) years of age or younger to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, shopping centers, or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusements, eating places, vacant lots, or any other place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful custody and authority to be at such places, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 5:00 a.m. the following day including Saturdays and Sundays; and provided that the following provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(a)  When a minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian, or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(b)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by their parent or guardian or adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; 
(c)  When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity; 
(d)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above referenced places during the proscribed period of time; 
(e)  When the minor is attending or travelling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion; 
(f)  When the minor is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal travel, with interstate travel through the City of East Point, excepted in all cases from the curfew. 
It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any minor sixteen (16) years of age or younger to permit, or by insufficient control, to allow, such minor to be in or upon the public streets or any other places listed previously within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. on any day and 5:00 a.m. the following day, except in circumstances set out in subsections (a) through (f) of this section; and on Fridays and Saturdays between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any minor seventeen (17) years of age or younger to permit, or by insufficient control, to allow such minor to be in or upon the public streets or any other places listed previously within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day including Saturdays or Sundays and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. The police department shall enact rules and operational procedures to track violations and notifications of parents. Upon the first offense of a minor in violation of section 13-2003, the parent or guardian will be given a verbal warning by a police officer. This warning shall be documented by the officer. On the second or subsequent offenses, a person shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and costs, or imprisonment in the East Point municipal jail for not more than sixty (60) days, or be subject to any one (1) punishment; subject to all limitations contained in the charter of the city. Each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1140-96, § 1, 10-21-96) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 1140-96, § 1, adopted Oct. 21, 1996, repealed former sections 13-2003 and 13-2003.1 in their entirety and enacted new provisions as set out in section 13-2003. Former sections 13-2003, 13-2003.1 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1022-91, § 1, adopted July 1, 1991, and Ord. No. 1075-94, § 1, adopted June 6, 1994.  
Sec. 13-2004. - Disorderly persons; assembly prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for disorderly persons or others to assemble in a disorderly manner in any house within the city, or to the disturbance of the citizens residing in the community where such assembly is had. 
(Code 1959, § 14-10)  
Sec. 13-2005. - Emergency maintenance of order. 
(a)  When the mayor and any four (4) or more members of the city council or any five (5) or more members of the city council exclusive of the mayor, determines in writing from information acquired by any of them from any generally reliable source, or shall be furnished by the chief, or any other member of the police department, or other agency or department of the city, or from any other generally reliable source, that any of the following conditions, or potential immediate exposure thereto, exists or is an imminent threat thereof, within said city, or some area thereof, it shall be the duty of the mayor or the city officer charged with the duty of acting in the mayor's place, to enforce the provisions of this section if he has reasonable cause to believe that unless he enforces it some one or more of such conditions or state of facts will get out of control, or will forthwith exist, and are in the process and about to become dangerous for human life and city property within the city, to-wit: 
(1)  Unjustifiable concerted personal violence, by or against, any number, group, or class of persons, or advocating indiscriminate open class or group defiance of lawfully constituted authority; 
(2)  Existence of an organized labor dispute, with picketing which shall have erupted into violence, or an assault on or by one (1) or more persons; 
(3)  Unusual open concert of group-defiance of lawfully constituted authority or advocacy of open concerted group defiance of legally constituted local governmental authority; 
(4)  Any unusual general undercover, or concealed, plan to advocate or defy local governmental authority, or instigate a rebellion against local lawful authority against any group, class, or number of persons; 
(5)  Any unlawful group or class activity calculated to obstruct, delay, or prevent enforcement of any law or ordinance; 
(6)  Any unlawful group or class activity calculated to obstruct justice, assault persons, or destroy or damage property; 
(7)  Any unlawful group or class activity calculated to prevent, interfere with, or delay the lawful performance by any city officer or employee of his or her official duties; 
(8)  Any unlawful group, class, or organization or activity for the accomplishment of any of the foregoing; 
(9)  Illegal forcible seizure by violence of or damage to any private or public property by any group, class or organization of persons, without any legal warrant or authority for so doing, and without the valid consent of the owner or possessor of such property; providing that a picket line composed of more than one (1) person marching within ten (10) feet of any other picket except another marching abreast, whether peaceably or not, shall constitute a seizure of the place of business so picketed, but not so if only two (2) march abreast and peaceably, and remain so at all times, and keep abreast or at least ten (10) feet apart; 
(10)  Group or class demonstrations or boycotts directed against enforcement of any public, private or local law, ordinance, rule, regulations, custom or practice of any lawful public, private or local organization, person or persons, business, agency, department, officer, or employee, or against the customs or practice of any class of persons, to coerce, force, or intimidate them, or any of them, into yielding to the demands of wishes of any or all of those persons causing such boycotts or demonstrations; which shall have been planned or actually commenced; 
(11)  When the city, its mayor, chief of police, city council, or any member thereof, or any other officer or employee shall have been expressly or impliedly notified, or put on notice by any one (1) or more persons, or by any class, group, or organization of persons, or an apparently responsible agent thereof that violent criminal rioting, boycotting, demonstrating, concerted defiance of all local city government and authority of city officials by a group or class of people has been planned for any of such purposes, and is scheduled for execution in this city or about a specified time. 
(b)  If and when it shall have been determined, as aforesaid, that any one (1) or more of such conditions exist, or that they have been planned and the existence and threatened execution thereof is imminent, it shall be the mayor's duty with the chief of police, fire, electric, water, buildings and grounds, parks department, public works and garage department to immediately appoint and arm a sufficient number of able-bodied men who, with the city's regular fire and police forces, will be adequate to watch, guard and protect all city buildings, equipment, facilities, utilities, lines and properties, and provide reasonable security for essential employee travel to and from essential employments between 8:00 p.m. of one day and 6:30 a.m. of the next day; and pay such extra emergency personnel the same rate of compensation as that of regular first-year policemen, until the next regular meeting of the city council when the state of the city shall be paid before and reviewed by the city council, and provision for the future than made by that body. But unless the city council then provide otherwise the mayor's prior action shall stand approved, and shall continue as before to the next regular or special called city council meeting. 
(c)  During any hours this curfew section shall be enforceable it shall be lawful for any alcoholic beverage place of business or other retail or wholesale alcoholic beverage outlet to be or remain open, or for any one to deliver, possess for delivery, serve, furnish, or consume outside the bona fide home of the consumer, to sell or offer for sale, or possess for the purpose of sale in the city any malt, spirituous or vinous whiskey or alcoholic beverage, or for any gasoline service station or firearms store to be or remain open; provided, that the gasoline service station, or stations, designated by the mayor and superintendent of the city garage may be or remain open with adequate police protection to service city vehicles. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any persons, except in case of necessity, to be out of or away from their homes while this section is being enforced during the period of time between 8:00 p.m. of one day and 6:30 a.m. of the next day, without a special curfew permit issued for good cause by the mayor or chief or assistant chief of police of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-11.1)  
Sec. 13-2006. - Excavations, holes; leaving unguarded prohibited. 
(a)  Any opening in any wall or side of which descending and ascending at an angle of ninety (90) degrees or more, if the depth of such opening is in excess of twelve (12) inches as measured from the lowest point at the bottom thereof in a vertical or perpendicular line to the normal level of the place or condition of such opening, if such opening is in excess of six (6) inches in width, shall be considered a well, hole, excavation, cave or ditch within the meaning of this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to cause or permit any unguarded open well, hole, cave, excavation, ditch or other place or condition or like danger on or in any public or private premises to be or remain a danger to any person rightfully in, or about such premises. 
(Code 1954, Ch. 19, § 13; Code 1959, § 14-12)  
Sec. 13-2007. - Firearms, discharging. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fire, discharge or shoot any gun, pistol or other firearm within the city, unless it be a regularly licensed shooting gallery or in defense of self, habitation or property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fire, discharge or shoot any gun in buildings owned or operated by the city as well as any and all other property owned or operated by the city. It shall also be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm within any city parks unless expressly authorized by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1959, § 14-14; Ord. No. 009-08, 3-17-08; Ord. No. 012-08, 4-21-08) 
Cross reference Air rifles, blank pistols, sling-shots, § 13-1006; drawing or flourishing weapons, § 13-1018. 
State Law reference Firearms which are discharged within fifty feet of a state highway constitute offense against the state, Ga. Code. Ann., § 26-2909.  
Sec. 13-2008. - "Dive" defined; prohibited; frequenting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or any organization or group of persons to have, keep, operate or maintain any establishment herein defined as a "dive." 
(b)  A "dive" is defined as any place or establishment where: 
(1)  Bay rum; or illegal alcoholic liquids, or other illegal drugs are found, possessed, kept or sold; and 
(2)  Any person is permitted to come and drink any bay rum or illegal alcoholic liquids or to possess or use any other illegal drugs; and 
(3)  Any person consumes or uses any bay rum or illegal alcoholic liquids or other illegal drugs or commits any illegal sexual acts. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to go in to or visit or to be present in a "dive," as herein defined, for the purpose of: 
(1)  Consuming any bay rum or illegal alcoholic liquids or other illegal drugs; or 
(2)  Selling, distributing or disposing of any bay rum or illegal alcoholic liquids or other illegal drugs.  
Sec. 13-2009. - Indecency in public prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to appear wholly or partially naked in public in an indecent manner or to perform publicly any indecent, immoral, or lewd act, gesture, dance, play or song. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, indecent lewd or immoral shall be determined by the average person applying contemporary community standards. If through application of such standards the average person finds that the nakedness, semi-nakedness, act, gesture, dance, play or song, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest; and is presented in a patently offensive way; and as a whole lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value, such nakedness, semi-nakedness, act, gesture, dance, play or song shall be indecent.  
Sec. 13-2010. - GamblingPlaying cards for money; prohibited use of premises. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to play any game with cards for money or other valuable things within the city, and it shall be unlawful for any person to permit any persons to play cards for money in any room or building of which such person may be the owner or agent of the owner. (Code 1959, § 14-16)  
Sec. 13-2011. - SameLotteries. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to play a lottery, participate in a lottery or to purchase any chance, ticket, number or thing, tangible or intangible, in or connected in any way with a lottery. 
This section shall not be construed to prohibit any lawful activity relating to the Georgia Lottery for Education Act (O.C.G.A. § 50-27-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1959, § 14-17)  
Sec. 13-2012. - SameMachines of chance generally; prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have, keep or maintain any machine or device for the purpose of being operated within the city if any money or value is paid, promised, deposited, required, charged, contracted for or received in connection with the privilege of playing or operating such machine or device if all of the usual or customary results of playing or operating such machine or device cannot be known in advance of each play or operation by the person playing or operating the same. 
(Code 1959, § 14-18)  
Sec. 13-2013. - Hotels and boarding-housesRegisters required. 
All hotels, tourist courts and boardinghouse keepers within the city shall keep registers in which shall be entered daily the names and addresses of each and all of their guests, which register shall show the date of each and all of their guests, which register shall show the date of their arrival and the date of their departure. 
(Code 1959, § 14-20)  
Sec. 13-2014. - SameInspection of registers. 
All registers of any hotel, tourist court or boardinghouse, required by the provision of section 13-2013, shall be open to the inspection of police officers when so requested at reasonable times, and it shall be the duty of the hotel, tourist court and boardinghouse keepers to exhibit such registers to such police officers when requested to do so. 
(Code 1959, § 14-21; Ord. No. 086-018 , 3-19-18)  
Sec. 13-2015. - Injury to city property; fire, water and communication paraphernalia. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to open, disconnect or tamper with any fireplug, hydrant, signal box, switch, system or line, or to injure, remove, open, close, plug, clog or disconnect any water pipe, sewer, telephone or electric line, water hose, reservoir; tank, plug or hydrant within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-28)  
Sec. 13-2015.1. - Injury resulting from hazardous materials. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following words shall have the indicated meaning or meanings: 
(1)  Hazardous material shall mean and include radioactive materials, liquefied natural gas (LNG), chlorine gas, and polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB). 
(b)  In the event of any damage to city property, or discharge of hazardous materials from the shipping packages or containers or the threat of such discharge which results from the transport, storage, holding, detention, delivery for transport, or acceptance for transport of hazardous materials in this city, the city may recover from any shipper, carrier, bailor, bailee, or any other person or persons responsible for such storage, transportation, holding, detention, delivery or acceptance, all costs, including direct as well as indirect, incurred by the city in the prevention, abatement or removal of such discharge or threatened discharge, including reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred with respect to recovery. 
(c)  The mayor is hereby authorized to direct the bringing of any legal action necessary and desirable to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 715-80, § 1, 3-3-80) 
Editor's note Section 1 of Ord. No. 715-80, enacted March 3, 1980, specifically amended the Code but did not designate a section number; therefore, the assignment of § 13-2015.1 to said provisions has been at the editor's discretion.  
Sec. 13-2016. - Loitering around places of public worship during services. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who is not a participant in the worship services, or who is not an employee of the church in the course of his employment, when it appears that such person is committing any act likely to interfere with the peaceful conduct of activities of the church or place of public worship, to loiter or remain in front of or around any church or other place of public worship during services conducted therein after being directed by any policeman or member of the congregation to move away. 
(Code 1959, § 14-32) 
Cross reference Obstructing streets by loitering therein, § 13-1005.  
Sec. 13-2016.1. - Loitering, generally; police order to disperse. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  "Loitering" shall mean remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concept of spending time idly; to be dilatory; to linger; to stay; to saunter; to delay; to stand around, and shall also include the colloquial expressions "hanging around" and "hanging out." 
(2)  "Public place" shall mean any place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment, or other lawful purpose, but does not necessarily mean a place devoted solely to uses of the public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of any store, shop, restaurant, tavern or other place of business and also public grounds, areas or parks. 
(b)  Prohibited behavior. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone and/or in consort with others in a public place in such manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians. 
(2)  Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress, and regress, therein, thereon and thereto or thereabout. 
(c)  Order to stop. When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (b) herein, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such orders shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 745-81, §§ 1, 2, 6-15-81) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 745-81, adopted June 15, 1981, did not specify a section number to be assigned to its provisions; the editor has numbered §§ 1 and 2 as § 13-2016.1 of this Code.  
Sec. 13-2017. - Noises; loud, unnecessary, etc., prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  A-weighted sound level shall mean the sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network, The level is designated Db(A) or dBA. 
(2)  Ambient sound level shall mean the total sound pressure level in the area of interest excluding the noise source of interest. 
(3)  Decibel shall mean a unit of measure used in describing the relative loudness or level of sound. 
(4)  Noise control officer (NCO) shall mean any police officer or officially designated employee of the municipality who has received training in the standards for the measurement of ambient sound level or absolute sound level and is empowered to issue a summons for violations of this article, based upon the use of ambient sound levels or absolute sound levels. 
(5)  Receiving property shall mean the use or occupancy of the property, which receives the transmission of sound. 
(6)  Sound level shall mean the weighted sound pressure level obtained by the use of a sound level meter and frequency weighting network, such as A, B or C as specified in American National Standards Institute specifications for sound level meters (ANSI S 1.4-1971, or the latest approved revision thereof). If the frequency weighting employed is not indicated, the A-weighting shall apply. 
(7)  Sound level meter shall mean an instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time averager, output or display meter, and weighting networks used to measure sound pressure levels, which complies with American National Standards Institute standard 1.4-1971 as revised. 
(8)  Sound pressure level (SPL) shall mean the ratio in decibels of the square of the root mean square sound pressure divided by the square of the standard reference sound pressure of 20/gmPa. Mathematically, this is expressed as 1O*log p2/P2 ref, = 20*log P/P ref, P ref, = 20/gmPa. 
(9)  Consumer fireworks and fireworks shall have the meanings ascribed in O.C.G.A. §25-10-1, as it may be amended. 
(b)  Unlawful noise. It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued any loud, or unusual noise or any noise which unreasonably or unnecessarily either disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others in the city. 
(c)  Exemptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to or be enforced against: 
(1)  Any vehicle of the city while engaged in necessary public business. 
(2)  Excavations or repairs of streets by or on behalf of the city, county or state at night when public welfare and convenience renders it impossible to perform such work during the day. 
(3)  The reasonable use of amplifiers or loud speakers in the course of public address which is noncommercial in character. 
(4)  The reasonable use of sounds used as a warning or used to avoid imminent danger or made during or as a result of an emergency situation, such as sirens, warning or danger whistles, alarms or any other similar sound. 
(5)  Any emergency vehicle or equipment used in the interests of law enforcement or for the interests of the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others in the city. 
(d)  Specific activities prohibited. The following acts, among others, shall constitute a violation of paragraph (b), but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place in the city except as a danger or emergency warning. 
(2)  Radios phonographs, etc. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or devise for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quite and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants, or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person who is in the room vehicle or chamber in which such machine or devise is operated and who is a voluntary listener thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of thirty (30) feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(3)  Yelling, shouting. etc. Yelling or shouting, on the public streets, at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
(4)  Animals, birds, etc. The keeping of any animal or bird, which shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity by making long, continual or frequent noise. 
(5)  Exhausts and etc. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorboat or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises there from. 
(6)  Defect in vehicle or load. The use, operation, repair, starting, rebuilding or testing of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(7)  Loading and unloading. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle. 
(8)  Construction or repairing of buildings. The erection, demolition, alteration or repair of any building or structure other than between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and sundown on weekdays and 9:00 a.m. and sundown on weekends and holidays, except on urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit from the city building inspector, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three (3) days and which permit may be renewed for three day increments until the emergency ceases. 
(9)  Schools, religious worship building, courts, and hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, religious worship building or court while the same is in session or adjacent to any hospital, and which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital; provided, that conspicuous signs are displayed about such institutions indicating the presence of such institutions. 
(10)  Peddlers, vendors and etc. The shouting and crying of peddlers, vendors and etc., which disturb the peace, and quite of the neighborhood. 
(11)  Noises to attract attention. The use of any drum or other instrument or devices for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show, sale, and etc. 
(12)  Pile drivers, hammers, and etc. The operation of pile drivers, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud noise without a special permit from the city must adhere to times outlined in number (9) above. 
(13)  Sound vehicles. The use of mechanical loud speakers or amplifiers on trucks or other moving standing vehicles for advertising or to other commercial purpose. 
(14)  Tire noises. The operation or use of any motor vehicle in such a manner that causes or allows to be emitted squealing, screeching or other such sound from any motor vehicle's tire-contact with the ground due to acceleration or excessive speed unless such noise is as a result of an emergency in travel or emergency breaking to avoid imminent danger. 
(15)  Consumer fireworks and/or fireworks. The use, ignition, or causing any firework(s) or consumer firework(s) to be ignited except during the days and times described in O.C.G.A. §25-10-2, as it may be amended. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued, except as otherwise permitted, any noise in excess of the noise levels set forth in Table 1. 
_____
TABLE 1. 
Receiving property 	Time 	Average Sound Level Limit 
Residential a.m. 	9:00 a.m.9:00 p.m. 	70 dBA 
Residential p.m. 	9:00 p.m.9:00 a.m. 	60 dBA 
Commercial 	At all times 	65 dBA 
Industrial 	At all times 	75 dBA 
 
_____
(f)  Temporary variance permits. Any person who own or operates any noise source may apply to the community services department for a temporary variance from one or more of the provisions of this section, unless such noise source is specifically exempted pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c). The community services department may grant a temporary variance permit provided that: 
(1)  Additional time is necessary for the applicant to alter or modify the activity in order to comply with the provisions of this section; or 
(2)  The activity, operation or noise source will be of a temporary duration not to exceed fourteen (14) days and cannot be done in a manner that would comply with the provisions of this section; or 
(3)  No reasonable alternative is available to the applicant; and 
(4)  The activity, operation or noise source will not constitute a danger to public health. 
(g)  Enforcement procedures. 
(1)  The NCO shall enforce the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Anyone violating any provision of this article shall be issued a citation by the NCO or any official designee thereof. 
(3)  In lieu of issuing a citation, the NCO may issue an order requiring abatement of any sound source alleged to be in violation of this article. Such order shall specify a reasonable time, not to exceed sixty (60) days, within which such abatement must occur and may specify guidelines in order to effect such abatement. 
(4)  Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day during which any violation occurs shall constitute a separate, additional offense. 
(Code 1959, §§ 14-34, 14-35; Ord. No. 023-00, § 1, 9-5-00; Ord. No. 023-05, § 1, 11-7-05; Ord. No. 094-018 , 9-17-18)  
Sec. 13-2018. - Open-air eating places, lighting requirements. 
It shall be the duty of every person serving or selling at retail any food or beverage, except water, apparently to be consumed in, on, at or near the premises where sold or served, to keep the premises, drives, parks, lots, yards, alleys, walks, streets, lanes or other areas where the patrons park, stop, stand, sit or wait to purchase or be served, so lighted that all such patrons drinking or eating in, on, at, near or about such places of business and the streets, lanes, alleys, walkways, yards, parks, lots or other areas, and any automobile or other vehicle occupied by such patrons and the occupants thereof may be clearly and readily seen and identified by any person within ten (10) feet of such patrons or vehicles; provided, the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person serving food or drink exclusively and wholly within the enclosed completely lighted kitchens, rooms or buildings in which the food or drinks sold or served are usually kept when such place of business is not open for business at night or on Sunday. 
(Code 1959, § 14-38)  
Sec. 13-2019. - Palmistry or fortunetelling. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on or practice the art, wizardry or calling commonly known as "palmistry" or "fortunetelling" within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 14-39) 
Annotations It is a proper exercise of a municipality's police power to declare the practice of fortunetelling unlawful within city limits. Williams v. Jenkins 211 Ga. 10 (1954); Gladstone v. Galton 145 Fed. 2D 742. 
State Law reference County authorized to prohibit, Ga. Code Ann., § 23-2706.  
Sec. 13-2020. - Prostitution prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to do any of the following: 
(1)  Engage in prostitution; 
(2)  Procure or solicit for the purpose of prostitution; 
(3)  Reside in, enter or remain in any place, structure, building, vehicle, trailer or conveyance for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution; 
(4)  Keep, set up or maintain a house of ill fame, a brothel or a bawdy house; 
(5)  Receive any person or persons for purposes of lewdness, assignation or prostitution into any vehicle, place, conveyance, trailer structure or building; 
(6)  Permit any person to remain for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution in any vehicle, conveyance, trailer, place, structure or building; 
(7)  Walk on or loiter about the streets, sidewalks, alleys, or thoroughfares for the purpose of soliciting for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution.  
Sec. 13-2020.1. - Transporting or receiving persons or loitering for illegal purposes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly transport a person into or within the city limits of the city for the purpose of promoting that person's engaging in prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly receive, offer or agree to receive another into any place or building for the purpose of performing an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering or knowingly to permit others to remain there for any such purpose. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly provide money or anything of value to another for the purpose of inducing another to transport a person into or within the city limits of the city for the purpose of promoting that person's engaging in prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering or for the purpose of inducing another to receive a person into any place or building for the purpose of performing an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter while a pedestrian or in a motor vehicle, in or near any thoroughfare or place open to the public, parking lots of hotels and motels, in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether this purpose is manifested are that such person is a known prostitute, pimp, sodomist, masturbator-for-hire or panderer and repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop, or engages passers-by in conversation, or repeatedly stops, or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, or waving of arms or any bodily gesture for the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution, sodomy, masturbation-for-hire or pandering. No arrest shall be made for a violation of this subsection unless the arresting officer first affords such person the opportunity to explain his conduct, and no one shall be convicted of violating this subsection if it appears at trial that the explanation given was true and disclosed a lawful purpose.
